    Upon application being made by any person for a license to keep, conduct or operate a rifle range or gun club or other place within the city upon or in which firearms may be discharged, the city treasurer shall cause to be made an inspection of the premises upon or in which it is desired or intended to keep, conduct or operate such rifle range, gun club or other place upon or in which firearms may be discharged. The inspection shall be for the purpose of ascertaining whether such premises are sufficiently ample to permit the discharge thereon or therein of firearms without endangering the safety of the public or persons living adjacent to such premises and to ascertain whether the targets or butts are so placed and are to be so kept and maintained as to permit the use of such premises and the discharge thereon or therein of firearms with the maximum of safety to the public and to persons living adjacent to the premises and to persons using the premises. If it appears that the premises are sufficiently ample and that the equipments thereof are such as will produce the maximum of safety as herein required, a license shall be issued for the rifle range, gun club or other place as hereinbefore provided; otherwise, the license shall be refused. 
(Code 1969, § 8-65) 
Secs. 8-163-8-175. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - MUSIC FESTIVALS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-176. - Definition. 
    In this article "music festival" means any show or act, or aggregation of shows or acts, or any combination of shows or acts, or any combination of several enterprises, which provides live musical entertainment, whether carried on or engaged in or conducted in any field, park or in any other way outdoors, and whether carried on, engaged in or conducted as one enterprise or by several concessionaires, and whether one (1) or no admission fee is charged for admission to all such shows or entertainments, or a separate fee for admission is charged for each entertainment; at which festival more than three hundred fifty (350) persons are in attendance during the operation thereof. 
(Code 1969, § 8-71(a)) 
Sec. 8-177. - Exemptions. 
    This article shall not apply to any public body. For purposes of this article, "public body" shall mean the state, any county, township, special district, school or school district, municipality, or any official, board, commission or department thereof, or other political subdivision of the state, now or hereafter created. 
(Code 1969, § 8-71(c)) 
Sec. 8-178. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-10. 
Sec. 8-179. - Length, frequency of operation. 
(a)  No music festival, once approved, shall remain in operation in any one (1) location for more than one (1) day, nor for a period exceeding ten (10) hours, and in no case later than 10:00 p.m. on such day. 
(b)  No music festival shall be located on any one (1) particular site more than three (3) times during any calendar year. 
(Code 1969, § 8-72) 
Secs. 8-180-8-195. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 8-196. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person as owner, lessee, operator, manager, officer or agent of the premises or the music festival, or in any other capacity, to give, conduct, produce, present or offer any music festival entertainments or performances within the city, except under the permit duly issued in accordance with this division. 
(Code 1969, § 8-71(b)) 
Sec. 8-197. - Application. 
(a)  A permit to give, conduct, produce or present a music festival shall be applied for by the owner or lessee, or the agent of either, of the premises upon which the music festival is to take place, jointly with the promoter or sponsor of the music festival. 
(b)  Each application shall be in writing on a printed form supplied by the city clerk and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The site or location of the proposed music festival and the zoning classification thereof; 
(2)  A precise description of the kinds and names of entertainments to be offered, the number, and a diagram indicating where they are to be located on the proposed site; 
(3)  The number and location of off-street parking spaces, as well as toilet facilities to be used by patrons of the music festival, to be indicated on the diagram referred to in paragraph (2) above; 
(4)  An indication of the dates the music festival is to be in operation, and the hours during which the music festival is to be open to the public; 
(5)  Any other information that the city council shall from time to time determine necessary in making a determination as to whether the application shall be granted; 
(6)  The name of the owner, owners, lessee, lessees, proprietor, operator or manager of the subject premises and the music festival and, in addition thereto, the name of the proprietor, operator, promoter or manager of each entertainment or performance which collectively make up the music festival, and the legal relationship of each to the applicants of the music festival. 
(Code 1969, § 8-73) 
Sec. 8-198. - Private home parties. 
    Private home parties shall be exempted from sections 8-199, 8-202 and 8-204, but all other requirements of this article shall apply. For purposes of this article, "private home parties" are those social events or gatherings held solely at a private single-family residence, featuring live musical entertainment arranged for by the resident owner and consisting of only one (1) band or performer, and at which no guest in attendance shall pay any admission fee or other required concession cost. Private home parties are subject to the provisions of the noise ordinance. 
(Code 1969, § 8-71(d); Ord. No. O18-047, 6-12-18) 
Sec. 8-199. - Application fee. 
    Each application for the permit required by this division shall be accompanied by an application fee in the amount specified in section 8-1. 
(Code 1969, § 8-77) 
Sec. 8-200. - Council approval required. 
    Each application submitted under this division, when completed, shall be submitted to the city clerk with the request that the application be placed on the agenda of the city council for its review. Approval of the city council shall be required for issuance of any permit under this division. 
(Code 1969, § 8-78) 
Sec. 8-201. - Denials. 
    The city council shall have the discretion to grant or deny any application submitted under this division or any part thereof on the basis that the music festival or any particular entertainment offered as part of the music festival is obscene, unsafe, illegal, fraud on the general public, or because of its location would create traffic hazards, noise or otherwise create a nuisance to adjoining property owners, or in some way is detrimental to the health, welfare and safety of the citizens of Aurora. 
(Code 1969, § 8-79) 
Sec. 8-202. - Insurance requirements. 
    Prior to the approval of any application submitted under this division, the applicants shall submit to the city a certificate of insurance showing the owner, lessee, proprietor, operator and manager of the subject premises and the music festival, as well as those persons acting in a similar capacity with respect to each entertainment or performance which collectively make up the music festival, as named insureds and, further, naming the city as an additional insured in an amount of not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) covering public liability, and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) covering property damage, such policy insuring liability that may arise from the operation or maintenance of the music festival or any part thereof. 
(Code 1969, § 8-74) 
Sec. 8-203. - City held harmless from liability. 
    The owner, lessee, proprietor, operator and manager of the subject premises and music festival shall, in addition to the application provided under this division, deliver to the city an agreement in writing holding the city harmless from all liability resulting from the operation of the music festival and, further, agree to indemnify the city from all liability resulting from any injury to patrons, bystanders, passersby or any individual as a result of the operation or maintenance of the music festival. 
(Code 1969, § 8-75) 
Sec. 8-204. - Restoration of premises; performance bond. 
    The applicants for a music festival permit shall restore the premises to the same condition as the premises existed prior to the operation of the music festival, including, but not limited to, removal of all facilities and equipment related to the music festival, or any part thereof, trash, garbage and miscellaneous debris. To insure performance under this section, the applicants shall submit, prior to approval of any permit application, a performance bond in the amount of not less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) guaranteeing the restoration of the premises as provided in this section. 
(Code 1969, § 8-76) 
Cross reference- Surety bonds, indemnity bonds, etc. § 2-318. 
Secs. 8-205-8-220. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - JUICE BARS, DRY CABARETS, TEENAGE CABARETS, AND OTHER NONALCOHOLIC BARS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-221. - Applicability. 
    This article shall apply to any dance hall, nonalcohol bar, dry cabaret, juice bar, or teenage cabaret which is designed, used or intended to be used primarily for participation by the public assembling for entertainment or amusement purposes, including, but not limited to music, music videos and dancing. This article shall not apply to any establishment which is licensed to serve alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. No. O89-68, § 2, 7-18-89) 
Sec. 8-222. - Hours of operation. 
    No person, firm, corporation or other legal entity shall operate any juice bar, dry cabaret, teenage cabaret or other nonalcohol bar between the hours of 1:01 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday, and between midnight on Sunday through Thursday and 6:00 a.m. on the following day; nor permit persons under seventeen (17) years of age to enter or remain upon the premises after 10:30 p.m. on Sunday through Thursday or after 11:30 p.m. on Friday and Saturday. This section shall not be construed to prevent regular employees from performing necessary work within the premises during such prohibited hours of operation. 
(Ord. No. O89-68, § 2, 7-18-89) 
Secs. 8-223-8-235. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 8-236. - Required. 
    No person shall keep, conduct, or operate any juice bar, dry cabaret, teenage cabaret or other nonalcoholic bar without first being licensed to do so as provided in this division. 
(Ord. No. O89-68, § 2, 7-18-89) 
Sec. 8-237. - Application. 
    Any person desiring to keep, conduct or operate any juice bar, dry cabaret, teenage cabaret or other nonalcohol bar in the city shall make written application to the mayor for a license to do so, setting forth the name of the applicant and the place where it is desired to keep, conduct or operate such juice bar, dry cabaret, teenage cabaret or other nonalcohol bar. Said application shall be accompanied by the application fee specified in section 8-1, a copy of the occupancy permit, and a copy of the food and beverage license. Application for renewal of such license shall be made to the mayor. 
(Ord. No. O89-68, § 2, 7-18-89) 
Sec. 8-238. - Reserved. 
Sec. 8-239. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  Licenses issued under this division may be revoked or suspended for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days by the mayor after notice and hearing as provided in subsections (c) and (d) of this section for any of the following cases: 
(1)  Any fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement contained in the application for the license. 
(2)  Any violation by the licensee of ordinance provisions relating to the license, the subject matter of the license, or the premises occupied. 
(3)  Conviction of the licensee or manager of any crime described in section 8-120(2)(a)-(g). 
(4)  Failure of the licensee to pay any fine or penalty owing to the city. 
(5)  The occurrence of two (2) or more disturbances at the subject premises within a ninety-day period, or two (2) or more incidents involving injury or bodily harm to patrons, bystanders, or police officers within a ninety-day period, provided that the mayor finds, upon the recommendation of the police chief, that as a result of the disturbances or incidents involving injury or bodily harm, a public nuisance exists which endangers the health, safety or welfare of the citizens of Aurora. 
(6)  The occurrence of two (2) or more suspensions within any twelve-month period, provided that the mayor finds that a public nuisance exists which endangers the health, safety or welfare of the citizens of Aurora. 
(b)  Such revocation, if ordered, shall not preclude prosecution or imposition of any other penalties provided for the violations of other applicable ordinances of the city. 
(c)  Notice of the hearing for revocation or suspension of a license shall be given in writing, specifically setting forth the grounds of the complaint, as well as the time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the licensee at his last known address at least five (5) days prior to the date set for the hearing. 
(d)  At the hearing, the corporation counsel shall present the complaint and shall represent the city. The licensee shall be permitted to retain counsel and shall have the right to submit evidence and cross-examine witnesses. The mayor shall preside and shall render the decision. 
(Ord. No. O89-68, § 2, 7-18-89) 
Chapter 9 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, adopted Mar. 28, 2000, amended ch. 9 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, said sections pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table. 
State Law reference- Powers of home rule units, Ill. Const. art. VII, § 6; Animal Welfare Act, 225 ILCS 605/1 et seq.; Animal Control Act, 510 ILCS 5/1 et seq.; Humane Law for Animals Act, 510 ILCS 70/1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 9-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal includes any living vertebrate, domestic or wild, not including man. 
    Animal control manager is an employee of the City of Aurora who shall be primarily responsible for enforcing the provisions contained in this chapter, and who has the power and authority to issue and serve citations for any violation of this chapter and to designate other employees to do so as well. 
    Animal control officer is an employee of the City of Aurora who shall be under the direct supervision of the animal control manager and pursuant to his or her direction may enforce the provisions contained in this chapter, and has the power and authority to issue and serve citations for any violation of this chapter. 
    Bird includes warm-blooded, two-legged, egg laying vertebrates with feathers and wings. 
    Bite means seizure with the teeth or jaws of an animal so that the skin of the human being or animal has been gripped, pierced or broken and further includes contact of the saliva of the biting animal with any break of the skin of the human being or animal bitten. 
    Carrier, racing, hobby and show pigeons means pigeons as defined in the "Carrier, Racing, Hobby and Show Pigeon Act of 1993." 
    Cat means all members of the feline family (Felis Catus). 
    Dangerous animal means any animal listed in section 9-15 herein as amended from time to time. 
    Dog includes all animals, regardless of sex, of the canine species (Canis Familiaris). 
    Domestic animal means any animal, except a farm or dangerous animal, which has been domesticated so as to live and/or breed in a tame condition as a household pet or guardian. For the purpose of this chapter, ferrets, rabbits and pot-bellied pigs are determined to be domestic animals. 
    Domestic animal at large means any animal that is not leashed and under the control of the owner or a responsible person over ten (10) years of age. If the animal is on the owner's property, it is at large if it is not contained on the property by means of an invisible fence with appropriate signage, fence, chain, owner's direct supervision, leash or other visible means of restraint sufficient to protect pedestrians on public property. 
    Euthanasia means death brought about by any medically recognized method which produces instant loss of consciousness and results in painless death. 
    Farm animal includes but is not limited to, horses, mules, bison, cattle, goats, sheep, swine and fowl. 
    Foster home means a permitted and registered entity that accepts the responsibility for stewardship of domestic animals that are the obligation of a licensed animal shelter or licensed animal rescue organization. 
    Fowl includes the larger, domesticated birds used as food, including chickens, ducks, emus, geese, peafowl, ostriches and turkeys. 
    Humane society is any not-for-profit corporation chartered under the laws of the State of Illinois for the object of animal welfare and humane treatment. 
    Kennel means any establishment wherein any person engages in the business of boarding, building, buying, grooming, letting for hire, training for a fee or selling dogs; provided, however, that the ownership of dogs which are a part of the household shall not constitute the operation of a kennel. Kennel shall not include any animal control and care facility, any kennel, pound or training facility operated by any subdivision of local, state or federal government, any humane society or veterinary hospital. 
    Leash means a cord, rope, strap, chain or other device not to exceed six (6) feet in length that is commercially produced and whose primary purpose is the temporary restraint of domestic animals, and which is securely fastened to the collar or harness of a domestic animal and which shall be of sufficient strength to keep such domestic animal under control. 
    Other enterprise means any public or private animal attraction or exhibition staged temporarily or permanently, with or without charge to viewers, in compliance with applicable ordinances of the City of Aurora, statutes of the State of Illinois and federal laws, including but not limited to zoos, circuses, pony rides, rodeos, dog shows, cat shows, livestock exhibitions, horse shows, other shows or expositions utilizing or displaying animals, and businesses of any kind that place animals on display to the public for promotion or advertising purposes. 
    Owner means any person having a right of property in an animal, or who keeps or harbors any animal, or for purposes of this chapter, who has an animal in his care or custody or acts as its custodian, or who knowingly permits it to remain on or about any premises owned or occupied by him. 
    Person means any individual, firm, corporation, partnership, association or other legal entity. 
    Pet means any species of domestic animal customarily regarded as suited to live within an abode used for human occupancy. 
    Stray animal means any animal not under restraint and not in the presence of its owner. 
    Tether means a chain, cord, rope, strap, cable or other device used to confine an animal to one fixed location that is commercially produced and which primary purpose is the temporary restraint of domestic animals and which shall be of sufficient strength to keep such domestic animal confined. 
    Trap means to capture, or attempt to capture, by setting or placing a leg hold trap, cushion-hold trap, body-gripping trap, cage or box trap, spring trap, dead/fall trap, pit/trap, snare or other similar device to capture, hold or kill any animal. 
    Veterinarian means a practicing veterinarian licensed by the State of Illinois. 
    Veterinary hospital means any establishment maintained and operated by a licensed veterinarian for diagnosis, treatment and/or surgery of diseases and injuries of animals. 
    Vicious animal is any animal that bites or attacks, or which is known to have bitten or attacked, a human being or other animal on two (2) or more separate occasions within any twenty-four-month period, without provocation whenever that person or animal was peacefully conducting themselves where they were lawfully entitled to be provided, however, that the animal control manager has the discretion to declare any animal as vicious after only one such bite whenever the animal control manager believes the circumstances warrant such a declaration. Once an animal has been declared vicious, the designation remains for the life of the animal. 
(Ord. No. O94-18, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. O94-97, § 1, 9-20-94; Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00; Ord. No. O02-99, § 1, 9-10-02; Ord. No. O06-12, § 1, 2-28-06; Ord. No. O07-98, § 1, 8-28-07) 
Sec. 9-2. - Limit on number of animals, foster home. 
(a)  There shall be a maximum limitation per household of four (4) domestic animals, not to exceed two (2) of any one (1) species, excepting households previously lawful on the effective date of this amendatory ordinance and so continuing; provided however, that any newborn animals shall be allowed to remain in the household despite the limitation of this section for up to two (2) months from the date of birth, or if given specific written permission by the animal control manager. The animal control manager or his or her designee may impound immediately every animal exceeding the limit per household. 
(b)  Application to the animal control manager or his or her designee may be made for one (1) additional domestic animal, not to exceed four (4) domestic animals per household, upon compliance with the following provisions: 
(1)  The applicant must demonstrate that for the five (5) years preceding its application, the applicant was in compliance with all applicable City Codes, and had not received any citations for violation of chapter 9 of this Code or the comparable sections of the municipal code of its former residence. 
(2)  The applicant must demonstrate that all animals in its care have received required vaccinations or treatments for the past five (5) years, and that all animals in its care have been microchipped and spayed or neutered. 
(3)  The applicant must demonstrate that all animals in its care were properly registered with the appropriate registering body for the past five (5) years, and complete the registration for the additional animal within one (1) business day of approval of the application. 
(4)  The applicant must agree to a home inspection to verify the living conditions of the animals, as well as the available area for the animals' safety and comfort. 
(5)  The applicant further must agree that any documented violations of chapter 9 after the additional animal joins the household may result in the immediate termination of the additional pet permission. 
(c)  No person convicted of a felony shall own a dog weighing greater than twenty (20) pounds unless sufficient proof to the satisfaction of the animal control manager can be provided proving the dog does not have any aggressive tendencies. 
(d)  A foster home may have not to exceed two (2) adolescent or adult domestic animals, or one (1) adult female domestic animal with its litter, or one (1) litter of domestic animals, for a maximum of eight (8) weeks per animal, in addition to its own two (2) domestic animals at any given time. Application for extension of time may be made to the animal control manager who shall have the sole discretion to determine whether to grant or deny such extension. Permits to operate as a foster home shall be as issued through any animal shelter or animal rescue organization placing the fostered animals prior to the placement of any animal for fostering. Registration must be made at the animal shelter prior to accepting any animal for fostering. All foster animals must be micro chipped within seven (7) days of the registration. The applicant must demonstrate that for five (5) years preceding its application, the applicant was in compliance with all applicable city codes and had not received any citations for violation of chapter 9 of the City of Aurora code of ordinances or the comparable sections of the municipal code of its former residence. 
(Ord. No. O94-18, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00; Ord. No. O02-99, § 2, 9-10-02; Ord. No. O06-12, § 2, 2-28-06; Ord. No. O07-98, § 1, 8-28-07; Ord. No. O14-018, § 1, 5-13-14) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 9-5. 
Sec. 9-3. - Registration and responsibility of animal owners. 
(a)  Every person who owns, keeps or harbors a dog or cat within the limits of the city shall, within thirty (30) days of acquisition of the dog or cat, register the dog or cat or cause it to be registered for a license with the county clerk or his authorized agent. 
(b)  Every person who owns, keeps or harbors a domestic animal within the limits of the city shall, within thirty (30) days of acquisition of such animal, and annually on such date as may be determined by the city treasurer, register the animal or cause it to be registered for a license with the city and obtain a license tag as evidence of such registration. License tags shall be displayed and/or attached to the collar of the registered animal at all times. Domestic animals weighing under ten (10) pounds and typically exclusively confined to a cage are exempt from licensure hereunder. 
(c)  Every person who owns, keeps or harbors a domestic animal within the limits of the city shall, within thirty (30) days of acquisition of such animal, acquire and maintain thereafter at all times general liability insurance in sufficient amounts so as to cover any costs resulting from the behavior/actions of such animal. 
(d)  All proceeds resulting from the imposition of the domestic animal license fee shall be used for the ongoing operation of the animal shelter. 
(e)  All foster homes shall register their name and address, the name and number of permanent animals in the home, the number of foster animals, up to two (2), for which the foster home is licensed, the license from the licensed animal shelter or licensed animal rescue organization for which they foster and any other information that the animal shelter may, from time to time, require. 
(f)  All breeders shall register their name and address, their business name and address, if different, the name and number of permanent animals in the home, the type(s) of breeds or animals bred, the license from the State of Illinois and any other information that the animal shelter may, from time to time, require. 
(g)  The animal control manager or his/her designee may impound any animal found to be in violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. O94-18, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00; Ord. No. O06-12, § 3, 2-28-06; Ord. No. O07-98, § 1, 8-28-07) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 9-6. 
Sec. 9-4. - Pet business license. 
    No person shall engage in the business of pet shop operator, kennel operator, animal shelter, veterinary hospital, pound, zoo or other business dealing in birds, domestic animals or dangerous animals or any combination thereof without a license issued by the State of Illinois. All such businesses shall be kept free and clean of decaying food and filth of any kind and shall be maintained under safe and sanitary conditions at all times, and in compliance with this chapter and state regulations. The animal control manager or his/her designee may impound any animal found to be in violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00; Ord. No. O07-98, § 1, 8-28-07) 
Sec. 9-5. - Canine unit exemption. 
    Trained police dogs utilized by an official law enforcement agency and assigned to a sworn peace officer as part of a canine team/unit shall be exempt from all provisions of this chapter as well as any applicable provision of any other chapter of this Code. 
(Ord. No. O94-18, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 9-8. 
Sec. 9-6. - Carrier, racing, hobby and show pigeons. 
    To the extent of any conflict between this chapter and the "Carrier, Racing, Hobby and Show Pigeon Act of 1993", that Act shall prevail, provided however, that: 
(1)  Where there is no conflict, this chapter shall apply to carrier, racing, hobby and show pigeons; 
(2)  All persons keeping carrier, racing, hobby and/or show pigeons shall register with the animal control manager annually, indicating the name, address, and number of such pigeons being kept, and such other evidence that such person is in compliance with the Act as the animal control manager shall deem necessary and appropriate; 
(3)  Every pigeon loft shall comply at all times with the building code and property maintenance code provisions in effect in the City of Aurora; 
(4)  Every pigeon loft and premises where such a loft is located shall be maintained in a clean, orderly condition at all times; and 
(5)  Every property where such pigeons are kept shall be subject to chapter 29, subsection 29-205(7) and the associated penalty provisions thereto. 
(6)  No pigeon loft shall exceed eight (8) feet in height or be built, constructed or maintained within fifty (50) feet of any property line. 
(Ord. No. O94-18, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00; Ord. No. O07-98, § 1, 8-28-07; Ord. No. O10-006, § 1, 3-9-10; Ord. No. O10-041, § 1, 7-27-10) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 9-9. 
Sec. 9-7. - Raising, boarding, selling of animals. 
(a)  No person shall raise animals for sale within the city limits unless properly zoned, nor keep for profit any kennel for the boarding of animals unless properly zoned. 
(b)  No person shall sell dogs within the city limits where the lineage/medical history of the animal and its parents are unknown, or where there is any potential for aggressive behavior where the history or lineage of the animal is known to, or should be known by, the owner. 
(c)  The animal control manager or his/her designee may impound any animal found to be in violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. O94-18, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00; Ord. No. O07-98, § 1, 8-28-07) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 9-10. 
ARTICLE II. - NUISANCE ABATEMENT 

Sec. 9-8. - Rabies inoculation. 
(a)  Every owner of a domestic animal four (4) months of age or older and for which there exists a vaccine for that species, shall, each year, cause such domestic animal to be inoculated against rabies by a licensed veterinarian, and provide the domestic animal with a collar or harness and attach thereto an official rabies vaccination tag which shall be worn by the domestic animal at all times. However, if the vaccine used is one recognized by the state department of agriculture, for a three-year period of immunity and the domestic animal is over twelve (12) months of age at the time of inoculation, the interval between inoculations may be extended to three (3) years. 
(b)  Any domestic animal which is not inoculated against rabies as required herein is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and such domestic animal may be apprehended and impounded upon the order of the animal control director or his or her designee. 
(Ord. No. O94-18, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00; Ord. No. O02-99, § 3, 9-10-02; Ord. No. O07-98, § 1, 8-28-07) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 9-7. 
Sec. 9-9. - Rabies-infected animals. 
(a)  Any animal suffering from rabies is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and such animal may be destroyed by the animal control manager or his or her designee, or by any police officer if such animal cannot be safely apprehended and impounded. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of every owner of an animal thought to be infected with rabies to place it immediately in a veterinary hospital or, upon demand, to surrender such animal to any police officer, the animal control manager or his or her designee. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of every person who discovers any animal thought to be suffering with rabies, or that any person or animal has been bitten by any animal thought to be suffering from rabies, to report such fact immediately to the police department or the animal control manager. 
(Ord. No. O94-18, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00; Ord. No. O02-99, § 4, 9-10-02) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 9-11. 
Sec. 9-10. - Domestic animals at large and fencing requirements. 
(a)  No person who owns, keeps or harbors a domestic animal shall cause or permit such animal to run at large within the city. Any domestic animal running at-large is hereby declared a public nuisance, whether currently licensed or not, and may be promptly impounded as provided in this chapter. 
(b)  Persons who utilize "invisible fencing" to contain any animal must display prominently on their property immediately adjacent to the public right-of-way a sign which indicates that any animal located thereon is contained by way of "invisible fencing." Invisible fencing installed after March 31, 2000, must be set back from the public right-of-way a minimum of four (4) feet. 
(c)  Fencing utilized to contain a domestic animal must be of sufficient height and strength to contain the particular domestic animal intended to be contained thereby, such fencing must be maintained in good condition to perform its intended containment function at all times, and comply with the appropriate codes of the city with respect to fences. 
(Ord. No. O94-18, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00; Ord. No. O07-98, § 1, 8-28-07) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 9-12. 
Sec. 9-11. - Animal disturbing the peace. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or any person who keeps or harbors any animal, or for any person who has the power or authority to prevent same, to suffer or permit any such animal to bark, howl, cry or make other frequent or loud noise so as to disturb the peace and quiet of any place, family, person or neighborhood in the city. Such disturbance of the peace is a public nuisance, and it shall be unlawful for any person to suffer or permit such nuisance to exist on their property. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to a properly zoned and constructed kennel, animal hospital or pound. 
(Ord. No. O94-18, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 9-13. 
Sec. 9-12. - Nuisance feeding prohibited. 
    The feeding of any mammal by any means, including hand feeding or the placing or setting out of food to be left attended or unattended, which creates or has the potential to create a hazard to public health or safety is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and to be unlawful. 
(Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00; Ord. No. O14-018, § 1, 5-13-14) 
Sec. 9-13. - Bites and attacks, vicious animals. 
(a)  Bites and attacks. It shall be the duty of every owner of an animal to prevent such animal from biting or attacking any person, animal or property of another. Any animal that, without provocation, bites or attacks any person, animal or property of another is hereby declared to be a nuisance; and such animal may be apprehended and impounded by the animal control manager, his or her designee or an animal control officer. In such a case, the animal control manager has the discretion to 1) allow the owner to retain ownership of the animal with certain restrictions being placed on the owner, in writing by the animal control manager or 2) declare the animal vicious after only one (1) such bite or attack, and in that event, the provisions in subsection (b) below shall apply. 
(b)  Vicious animals. It is unlawful to keep or harbor in the city any vicious animal as hereinabove defined unless: 
(1)  Such animal is confined indoors by its owner or confined on the owner's premises at all times in a five-sided enclosure (four (4) sides and roof) that is reasonably designed to prevent escape. If the enclosure has no floor that is secured to the sides, then the sides of the enclosure shall be embedded into the ground no less than two (2) feet deep. The enclosure must be in compliance with article III of this chapter at all times. 
(2)  Such animal shall not leave its owner's premises without the prior written approval of the animal control manager or his or her designee, and then only for the purpose of obtaining veterinary care, grooming or leaving the city limits. When beyond the premises of the owner for the above-mentioned reasons, the animal must be securely muzzled and restrained by a leash and under the physical restraint and control of the owner at all times. 
(3)  The owner of a vicious animal shall display in a prominent place on his/her premises a clearly visible warning sign indicating that there is a vicious animal on the premises, stating "WARNING-VICIOUS ANIMAL-KEEP AWAY!" A similar sign is further required to be posted on the exterior of the enclosure in which the animal is kept. The sign must be visible and legible from the public right-of-way and from fifty (50) feet away from the animal's enclosure. 
(4)  Such animal is kept according to any written restrictions placed by the animal control director. 
(5)  Such animal has had a microchip installed or injected on the animal at the owner's expense. The microchip must be installed in or injected under the skin of the animal by a licensed veterinarian and shall be designed so that, when scanned by an electronic reader, it is capable of providing the identification of the dog's owner. Proof of such microchip installation or injection must be made to the animal control manager, in writing, within thirty (30) days of the date of the bite. This paragraph shall apply retroactively to all animals declared vicious on or after June 1, 1998. 
(6)  The animal shall be spayed or neutered, at the owner's expense, within thirty (30) days of the date of the bite. 
(7)  Within ten (10) business days of the declaration that the animal is vicious, the owner must procure and maintain in effect liability insurance, including coverage of claims arising from the conduct of the owner's animal, in an amount not less than two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00). The insurance policy shall include a provision whereby the insurer shall notify the animal control department not less than thirty (30) days prior to a cancellation or lapse of coverage. 
(c)  Any such vicious animal that is not so confined or that. when unprovoked, bites or attacks any person or animal, or which is found to be in violation of this chapter or any written restriction placed by the animal control manager, is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and such animal may be apprehended and impounded by the animal control manager, his or her designee, or an animal control officer. If such animal is impounded, the owner shall have no right to redeem the animal except in the discretion of the animal control manager, and then only pursuant to certain further written restrictions which (s)he may place thereon. If the vicious animal's subsequent unprovoked attack caused severe injury or death to any person or animal, then the animal control manager may order the humane destruction of the vicious animal. 
(d)  It shall be the duty of any person who has been bitten, or having knowledge of a person being bitten, scratched or otherwise injured so as to cause abrasion to the skin of such person being bitten or scratched by a domestic animal, to report the incident to the police department or animal control department within twenty-four (24) hours of the incident, giving the name and address of the owner of such animal, the license number of the animal, if ascertainable, and the time and place of the incident. 
(e)  If all the restrictions placed upon the vicious animal by the animal control manager, or his or her designee, are not completed within the time frame established by the order of restriction or by the court system, then the animal control manager, his or her designee or an animal control officer may impound the vicious animal. 
(Ord. No. O94-18, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. O94-97, § 2, 9-20-94; Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00; Ord. No. O02-99, § 5, 9-10-02; Ord. No. O07-98, § 1, 8-28-07) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 9-14. 
Sec. 9-14. - Dangerous animals. 
(a)  No person shall own, keep or harbor within the city: 
(1)  Any snake, reptile or lizard that is physically capable of injuring any person, regardless of age, by bite, poison, constriction or other means; 
(2)  Any lion, tiger, cougar, jaguar, panther, bobcat, mountain lion, lynx, ocelot, leopard, any hybrid thereof or any other similar feline animal; 
(3)  Any wolf, coyote, jackal, fox, wild dog, or hybrid thereof; 
(4)  Any bear or bison; 
(5)  Any rodent weighing more than one (1) pound, with the exception of guinea pigs; 
(6)  Any non-canine animal not native to the North American continent and which when full grown normally attains a weight in excess of two hundred (200) pounds. 
(7)  Any monkey, gorilla, chimpanzee or other similar ape-like primate. 
(b)  Any animal, snake, reptile, lizard, rodent or other creature covered by subsection (a) is declared a public nuisance, and such animal may be impounded by the animal control manager, his or her designee, or an animal control officer. If such animal cannot be relocated safely to an entity licensed to handle the dangerous animal in the sole discretion of the animal control manager, the animal control manager may order the humane destruction of such animal. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to properly zoned and constructed zoos, animal shelters, veterinary hospitals, pounds, federally licensed exhibits, circuses, animal refuges, scientific or research laboratories of educational or other licensed institutions, or other enterprise. 
(Ord. No. O94-18, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. O94-97, § 3, 9-20-94; Ord. No. O95-87, § 1, 10-17-95; Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00; Ord. No. O07-98, § 1, 8-28-07) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 9-15. 
Sec. 9-15. - Keeping animals other than domestic animals. 
(a)  No person shall own, keep or harbor within the city any dangerous animal, bees, farm animal, insect, or other animal which is feral naturae in the eyes of the law, and each day such animal is kept in violation of this section shall constitute a separate offense. It is no defense to a violation of this section that the owner or keeper of any such animal which is prohibited in this section has attempted to domesticate such animal. Provided, however, that in the discretion of the animal control manager, written permission may be granted upon application for a special and limited purpose to have such animals present in the city, such as for pony rides, petting zoos and the like. 
(b)  Any such animal found to be within the city may be apprehended and impounded by the animal control manager or his or her designee. The disposition of such animal covered by this section shall be in accordance with the provisions of state law. Where no state law applies, the owner or person shall have no right of redemption in such animal, and the animal control manager shall have the authority to dispose of said animal as (s)he deems fit. 
(c)  Additionally, for farm-zoned property annexed into the City of Aurora, the owner(s) of the property at the time of annexation shall be allowed to maintain existing farm animals on such property until the property ceases to be used as a farm, or until residentially zoned and occupied property comes within two hundred (200) yards of any portion of the annexed property, whichever is earlier. 
(Ord. No. O94-18, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. O94-97, § 4, 9-20-94; Ord. No. O95-87, § 2, 10-17-95; Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00; Ord. No. O02-99, § 6, 9-10-02) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 9-16. 
Sec. 9-16. - Confinement of animals in heat. 
    The owner of any domesticated animal in heat shall not keep, harbor or otherwise maintain such animal in the city unless the same is confined in a boarding kennel, veterinary hospital or the owner's house during the entire period such animal is in heat; except that it shall be lawful for a domestic animal in heat to be walked if the animal remains on a leash and is not permitted to run at large. Any animal in heat not so confined is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and may be apprehended and impounded by the animal control manager or his or her designee. 
(Ord. No. O94-18, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00; Ord. No. O02-99, § 7, 9-10-02) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 9-18. 
Sec. 9-17. - Owner's responsibility for removal of excreta. 
    The owner of every animal shall be responsible for the removal and sanitary disposition of excreta deposited by his animal anywhere in the city. When accompanying the animal outside his property, the owner shall have on his person suitable means for the removal of such excreta which must then be placed in a refuse container for sanitary removal. 
(Ord. No. O94-18, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 9-19. 
Sec. 9-18. - Removal of dead animals. 
(a)  Any animal killed on the streets of the city shall be removed at once by the person who killed the animal. 
(b)  Every animal owner must remove, or cause the removal of, any animal which has died from the City of Aurora no later than forty-eight (48) hours after the animal has died. 
(Ord. No. O94-18, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 9-20. 
ARTICLE III. - HUMANE TREATMENT OF ANIMALS 

Sec. 9-19. - Humane care for animals. 
(a)  Every owner shall provide for each of his animals: 
(1)  Sufficient quantity of good, wholesome food and water; 
(2)  Adequate shelter and protection from weather conditions; 
(3)  Veterinary care when needed; and 
(4)  Humane care and treatment. 
(b)  The animal control manager or his/her designee may impound any animal found not to be receiving any aspect of humane care as set forth in subsection (a) herein. 
(Ord. No. O94-18, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. O07-98, § 1, 8-28-07) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 9-21. 
Sec. 9-20. - Cruelty to animals prohibited. 
(a)  No person or owner shall treat any animal cruelly in any manner, including, but not limited to the following: 
(1)  By overloading, overdriving, overworking, hitting, engaging in sexual contact, torturing, tormenting, mutilating or killing any animal, or cause or knowingly allow same to be done; 
(2)  By cruelly working any old, maimed, infirm, sick or disabled animal, or cause or knowingly allow same to be done; 
(3)  By failing to provide any animal in his care or custody with proper food, water, air and sanitary shelter. Such shelter to be sufficient to provide adequate bedding and protection from the weather, and space within sufficient for the animal to stand in an upright position, and lie down stretched out so that no part of its body need touch the sides of the shelter structure. Animals kept in an outside enclosure must have sufficient space for movement and exercise according to the animals size and weight; 
(4)  By failing to provide necessary veterinary attention to sick animals in need which are in any persons care or custody; 
(5)  By abandoning any animal where it may become a public charge or may suffer injury, hunger or exposure; 
(6)  By carrying, keeping, driving or causing to be carried, driven or kept, any animal in a cruel manner; 
(7)  By leaving or confining any animal in a motor vehicle, trailer or other enclosure in such a manner that it places the animal in a life or health threatening situation due to exposure to heat or cold, without sufficient ventilation or other protection from such heat or cold; 
(8)  By wounding or killing, or attempting to wound or kill, or by knowingly poisoning or causing to be poisoned, any animal, with the exception of rats and mice, and then only by using approved department of agriculture poison appropriate for rodents; 
(9)  By tethering any animal to a fixed object unless such tether or leash is so placed or attached that they cannot become entangled with another animal or object, and shall be of sufficient length in proportion to the size of the animal to allow the animal proper exercise and convenient access to food, water and shelter. Such tethering shall be located so as not to allow such animal to trespass on public property or private property belonging to others, nor in such a manner as to cause harm or danger to persons or other animals. Only commercially produced products whose primary purpose is the restraint of domestic animals may be used to tether, leash or otherwise restrain an animal. 
(10)  By transporting an animal on any public thoroughfare in any vehicle unless such animal is totally enclosed within such vehicle, within a secured container carried upon such vehicle, or securely cross-tethered to such vehicle in such a way as to prevent any injury to the animal. 
(b)  When the animal control manager, animal control officer, or the designee of the animal control manager finds a violation of this section which has resulted in an animal being in such condition that no remedy or corrective action by the owner is possible, or if the owner fails or refuses to provide such remedy or corrective action, the animal control manager, his or her designee or an animal control officer may remove such animal from the property or vehicle and impound the animal. The owner or person otherwise responsible for said animal shall be strictly liable for all expenses incurred. Further, the owner or person otherwise responsible for said animal shall have no right of redemption in the animal. 
(c)  If the owner cannot be located after reasonable search, or if the owner shall be known to be absent due to illness, incarceration or other circumstance, the animal may be removed by the animal control manager, his or her designee or an animal control officer and impounded. The owner shall be held strictly liable for all expenses incurred. 
(Ord. No. O94-18, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. O95-87, § 3, 10-17-95; Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00; Ord. No. O02-99, § 8, 9-10-02; Ord. No. O07-98, § 1, 8-28-07) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 9-22. 
Sec. 9-21. - Animals used for entertainment prohibited acts. 
(a)  No person shall own, capture, breed, train or lease any animal or fowl or reptile which he or she knows or should know is intended for use in any show, program or other activity featuring or otherwise involving a fight between such animal and any other animal or person, or the intentional killing of any animal for the purpose of sport, wagering or entertainment. 
(b)  No person shall promote, carry on, advertise, collect money for or in any other manner assist or aid in the presentation for purposes of sport, wagering or entertainment, any show, program or other activity involving a fight between two (2) or more animals/persons or the intentional killing of any animal. 
(c)  No person shall sell or offer for sale, ship, transport or otherwise move or deliver, or receive any animal which he or she knows or should know has been captured, bred or trained, or will be used to fight another animal or be intentionally killed, for the purpose of sport, wagering or entertainment. 
(d)  No person shall manufacture for sale, shipment, transportation or delivery any device or equipment which that person knows or should know is intended for use in any show, program or other activity featuring or otherwise involving a fight between two (2) or more animals or the intentional killing of any animal for purposes of sport, wagering or entertainment. 
(e)  No person shall sell or offer for sale, ship, transport or otherwise move any equipment or device which such person knows or should know is intended for use in connection with any show, program or activity featuring or otherwise involving a fight between two (2) or more animals or the intentional killing of any animal for purposes of sport, wagering or entertainment. 
(f)  No person shall make available any site structure or facility, whether enclosed or not, which he or she knows or should know is intended to be used for the purpose of conducting any show, program or other activity involving a fight between two (2) or more animals or the intentional killing of any animal. 
(g)  No person shall attend or otherwise patronize any show, program or other activity featuring or otherwise involving a fight between two (2) or more animals or the intentional killing of any animal for the purposes of sport, wagering or entertainment. 
(Ord. No. O94-18, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 9-23. 
Sec. 9-22. - Trapping of animals prohibited. 
    It shall be a violation of this chapter for any person to trap, attempt to trap or aid and abet any person in trapping any domestic animal, provided, however, that this section shall not apply to any authorized city employee acting in the course of his/her official duties, or any other person so authorized in writing by the animal control manager, and shall not apply to any appropriately licensed nuisance wildlife trapper. 
(Ord. No. O94-18, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00; Ord. No. O02-99, § 9, 9-10-02) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 9-24. 
ARTICLE IV. - IMPOUNDMENT 

Sec. 9-23. - Authority of animal control manager. 
    The animal control manager and/or such employees as (s)he may designate for that purpose, is authorized to impound animals wherever impoundment is called for in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O94-18, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00; Ord. No. O02-99, § 10, 9-10-02) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 9-25. 
Sec. 9-24. - Record-keeping, reports, disposition of fees paid. 
(a)  The animal control manager shall keep an accurate account of animals impounded, released and/or destroyed. All fees received are to be given to the city treasurer or his authorized agent each week. A monthly report will be made to the office of the mayor, such report to be included in the monthly report to the city council. 
(b)  Additionally, the animal control manager shall (upon request by the corporation counsel) report to the law department a case of animal attack upon a person or domestic animal resulting in the infliction of the animal's bite, concerning which the animal control manager receives information under section 9-13. The report shall be made within forty-eight (48) hours after the occurrence of such attack, or as soon thereafter as the animal controller may receive such information hereunder, and shall be in writing using forms prepared by the law department for such purposes. 
(Ord. No. O94-18, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00; Ord. No. O02-99, § 11, 9-10-02) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 9-27. 
Sec. 9-25. - Redemption. 
    For every animal taken up and impounded as provided in this chapter there shall be paid to the division of animal control the fee specified in section 9-27. Only the owner may redeem the animal and the owner will be required to provide proof of ownership sufficient to the requirements of the animal control manager prior to the animal being released. Any animal impounded shall be microchipped before its release to its owner, with the owner paying the fifteen dollar ($15.00) fee therefore. 
    Additionally, any animal for which four (4) documented payments of reclamation fees have been paid in twenty-four (24) months shall be spayed or neutered prior to its release to its owners as hereinafter provided. The animal shall be transported to the veterinarian of the owner's choice, upon payment of the veterinarian's spay or neuter fee, and waiver of any liability against the city, for immediate spay or neuter. If the animal cannot be spayed or neutered, as determined by a veterinarian, in writing, due to age or a medical condition, the animal shall be spayed or neutered upon the removal of the veterinarian's restriction or the achievement of a designated date. If proof of the animal's sterilization is not presented to the animal shelter within five (5) days after the lifting of the veterinarian's restriction or the achievement of the veterinarian designated date, or should the owner fail to comply with the above requirements then the animal will be impounded by the animal control manager or designee as a public nuisance and may not be redeemed by its owner. 
(Ord. No. O94-18, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00; Ord. No. O02-99, § 12, 9-10-02; Ord. No. O06-12, § 4, 2-28-06; Ord. No. O07-98, § 1, 8-28-07) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 9-28. 
Sec. 9-26. - Disposition of unclaimed animals. 
(a)  If an impounded animal is not redeemed within four (4) days after being impounded, the animal shall be placed for adoption, destroyed or disposed of by the animal control manager. Day one (1) of said four-day grace period shall be the first full calendar day following impoundment. 
(b)  Whenever it shall become necessary to destroy an animal, the method of destruction shall be in accordance with accepted practices of euthanasia from a humane standpoint. 
(Ord. No. O94-18, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00; Ord. No. O02-99, § 13, 9-10-02) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 9-29. 
ARTICLE V. - FEES 

Sec. 9-27. - Fees. 
    The fees required by this chapter shall be as follows: 
(a) Dog and cat registration license fees: 1 year 3 year Seniors Lifetime   Registered show cat/dog, altered and microchipped cat/dog Free N/A Free $18.00   Altered cat/dog $10.00 $20.00 $5.00 $25.00   Unaltered cat/dog $50.00 N/A $25.00 N/A  
Additionally, a replacement tag fee of one dollar ($1.00) per tag shall be assessed to replace a lost tag. Residents who are handicapped and own specially trained dogs or cats to help alleviate such handicap, shall receive licenses at no charge. Such handicapped residents and seniors shall not be assessed replacement tag fees. Registered show cats/dogs are not required to wear the registration tag during or in immediate preparation for a show. 
(b)  Animal adoption fees: For male or female animals, a forty dollar ($40.00) fee for neutering, a ten dollar ($10.00) fee for rabies vaccination, and a forty dollar ($40.00) administrative fee shall be charged for a total of ninety dollars ($90.00) in fees. 
(c)  Impoundment redemption fees: 
(1)  The redemption fee for the first and second offense, per family and/or address, shall be twenty dollars ($20.00) and thirty dollars ($30.00) respectively, and the amount of the license fee due for the current year, if any; plus 
(2)  The cost of keeping such animal while in the animal control and care facility at a rate not to exceed ten dollars ($10.00) per day or fraction thereof. 
(3)  The redemption fee for the third offense shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) and the fourth offense shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00), the redemption fee for the fifth offense shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00), and the redemption fee for the sixth and subsequent offenses shall be three hundred dollars ($300.00). 
(4)  For any animal impounded as the result of an emergency call and response by the animal control division, an additional fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) shall be charged toward administrative costs. 
(5)  Any fees imposed pursuant to this section may be waived by the animal control manager upon surrender of ownership rights to the animal in question. 
(d)  Release of ownership rights fees: In order for an owner to release his/her rights of ownership in an animal to the animal control division, a fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) shall be paid per animal/litter of animals, provided however, that for animals whose owners reside outside the corporate limits of the city, such owner shall pay twice the rate provided for herein. 
(e)  Disposal fees: For the service provided in disposing of animals which have died, a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) may be charged. For animals whose owners reside outside the corporate limits of the city, such owner shall pay twice the rate provided for herein. 
(f)  Euthanasia fees: For the service provided in humanely destroying domestic animals, a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be charged. 
(g)  Tranquilizing fee: Whenever any animal requires tranquilization in the sole discretion of the animal control manager or his or her designee, the owner of such animal shall be required to reimburse the city twenty dollars ($20.00) for its costs in so tranquilizing. 
(h)  Pickup fee: Whenever any domestic animal registered with the city dies within the corporate limits of the city, the city may pick up the remains of the animal for a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). Senior citizens may apply for a waiver of this fee from the animal control manager, based upon the documentation of need. 
(i)  Actual costs of seizure and confinement: Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter, the city may ascertain and bill the owner or keeper of any animal that is being harbored or maintained in violation of this chapter the actual costs incurred by the city in seizing and confining such animal. 
(Ord. No. O94-18, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00; Ord. No. O02-99, § 14, 9-10-02; Ord. No. O06-12, § 5, 2-28-06; Ord. No. O07-98, § 1, 8-28-07) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 9-4. 
ARTICLE VI. - ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES 

Sec. 9-28. - Interference with enforcement. 
    It shall be a violation of this chapter for any person to obstruct, impede or interfere with the capture, impound or disposal of any animal in accordance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00) 
Sec. 9-29. - Enforcement exemption from liability. 
    The division of animal control, its agents, employees or other persons authorized to enforce the provisions of this chapter shall not be held liable for the injury, death or disease which may occur to any animal as a consequence of the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00) 
Sec. 9-30. - Destruction of dangerous animals. 
    If any dangerous or vicious animal cannot safely be taken and impounded, such animal may be destroyed by any police officer. The disposition of the destroyed animal shall be in accordance with the provisions of state law. 
(Ord. No. O94-18, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 9-26. 
Sec. 9-31. - Administrative adjudication. 
(a)  The animal control manager, his or her designees and the animal control officer(s) are deemed peace officers and may prepare and serve citations personally or by certified mail, for violation(s) of this chapter. 
(b)  Whenever a violation of this chapter is observed by the animal control manager, his or her designees or any animal control officer, in addition to subsection (a) above, s/he shall have the authority to institute, by the filing of a written pleading, a proceeding for enforcement of this chapter before the City of Aurora Administrative Hearing Officer. Additionally, any person receiving such a citation may request an administrative hearing to contest the matter. Said administrative adjudication of any violation of this chapter shall be authorized and conducted pursuant to 65 ILCS 5/1-2.1 et seq. 
(c)  The fine for violating any provisions of the Animal Control Ordinance may result in a fine ranging from one hundred dollars ($100.00) to ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for each offense. 
(Ord. No. O94-18, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00; Ord. No. O02-99, § 15, 9-10-02; Ord. No. O07-98, § 1, 8-28-07) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 9-3. 
Sec. 9-32. - Penalty. 
(a)  Every owner or any other person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon a finding of liability, be punished by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per violation, per day the violation exists. Each occurrence of any violation of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense. This penalty shall be in addition to other penalties or remedies provided by this chapter, or by state or federal law. 
(b)  Every owner or any other person penalized pursuant to subsection (a) above and where the animal that is the subject of the violation is unaltered and/or not microchipped at the time of said violation, shall be eligible for a refund of fifty dollars ($50.00) back on any fine so paid in the event such owner or other person provides proof to the animal control manager, within thirty (30) days of said violation, sufficient in her determination that said animal has been appropriately altered and/or microchipped since the date of said violation. 
(c)  A violation of sections 9-13, 9-14, 9-20 or 9-21 is hereby declared to be a Misdemeanor III with all of the attendant penalties as provided in subsection 10(c) of chapter 1 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. O94-18, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. O00-32, § 1, 3-28-00; Ord. No. O07-98, § 1, 8-28-07) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 9-2.
