    The officer in command at the scene of a fire shall have the power to summarily remove, at the owner's expense, any property, including motor vehicles, whenever it shall become necessary to preserve such property from fire; to clear obstructed fire lanes and access routes; to prevent the spreading of fire; or to protect adjoining property. Neither the city nor a public employee acting in the scope of his employment shall be liable for any injury or damage resulting from such a removal of property. 
(Code 1969, § 17-21) 
Sec. 17-31. - Removal, destruction of structures. 
    The officer in command at a fire may direct the firemen to cut down and remove any building, erection or fence, for the purpose of checking the progress of any fire, and the fire marshal or other officer in command shall have the power to destroy any building or erection during the progress of a fire, for the purpose of extinguishing or checking the same. 
(Code 1969, § 17-22) 
Sec. 17-32. - Public to obey officers. 
    Every person who shall be present at the scene of an emergency shall be subject and obedient to the orders of the officer in command at the scene of an emergency, and in case any person shall refuse to obey such orders, he shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. No person not a member of the fire department shall be bound to obey any of such officers unless the officers bear their respective badges of office, or unless their official character is known to him, and an officer shall have the power to arrest any person so refusing to obey such lawful orders. 
(Code 1969, § 17-25; Ord. No. O88-71, Exh. A, 6-21-88) 
Sec. 17-33. - Impersonating firemen. 
    No person not a member of the fire department shall impersonate a fireman or officer of the fire department. 
(Code 1969, § 17-24) 
Sec. 17-34. - Proof of ownership of salvaged property. 
    No person shall be entitled to take away any property in the possession of the fire department saved from any fire until he shall make satisfactory proof of ownership thereof. 
(Code 1969, § 17-26) 
Sec. 17-35. - Ambulance service; amount and report of charges. 
(a)  The city, through the fire department, shall provide emergency ambulance service to all city residents. The chief of the Aurora fire department may limit the number of emergency centers to which the Aurora Fire Department shall provide transportation, unless circumstances and/or medical emergencies otherwise dictate; those centers being Copley Memorial Hospital and Mercy Center Hospital. 
(b)  The fees to be paid to the city for any emergency ambulance service rendered by the fire department shall be as established in section 17-1. 
(c)  The treasurer shall forthwith bill all applicable charges to the patient and take all necessary action to collect the same. 
(Code 1969, § 17-31; Ord. No. O95-35, § 1, 6-20-95) 
Sec. 17-36. - Emergency communications interference. 
(a)  Reliable emergency radio communications are critical for fire department operations. Lack of radio communication within a building or structure presents conditions which can contribute to the spread of fire in burning buildings or structures, endangering the occupants and firefighters in and around such buildings or structures. 
(b)  When conditions exist with radio communication equipment which interfere with the efficiency and use of fire protection equipment and/or response of the fire department, a bi-directional radio amplification system shall be required to be installed within or on the interfering building or structure to ensure a ninety-five (95) percent reliability factor for radio use therein. This system will be designed to operate in conjunction with the equipment utilized by the fire department. 
(c)  When any fire communications enhancement system required hereunder is installed and becomes inoperative, thus affecting the fire safety of the building, structure or occupants therein, fire officials shall order the system, unit or device to be repaired and returned to service, or the building or structure may be required to be vacated pursuant to article III of this chapter, until the inoperative system, unit or device is repaired and returned to service. It shall be the responsibility of the owner or occupant to make annual tests, repairs, alterations or additions to assist them. 
(d)  Buildings and structures in existence prior to the effective date of this section, where conditions exist with radio communications equipment which interfere with the efficiency and use of fire protection equipment and/or response of the fire department, shall be required to conform to a ninety-five (95) percent reliability factor for radio use, within six (6) months from the date of notification by fire officials. 
(Ord. No. O97-135, § 1, 12-9-97) 
Secs. 17-37-17-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FIRE CHIEF[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Department heads generally, § 2-277. 

Sec. 17-51. - Oath. 
    The fire chief shall, before entering upon the duties of his office, take the oath of office prescribed by law for city officers. 
(Code 1969, § 17-3) 
Sec. 17-52. - Supervisory powers, duties. 
    The fire chief shall be the chief officer of the fire department and in subordination to the mayor and the council, and shall have full command and control over the department and over all members thereof, with full power and authority over its organization, government and discipline. To that end, subject to the approval of the mayor, he may prescribe and establish, from time to time, such rules and regulations as he may deem advisable. 
(Code 1969, § 17-4) 
Sec. 17-53. - Custody of apparatus. 
    The fire chief shall have the custody of the engines, trucks, ladders and other property and equipment belonging to the fire department. 
(Code 1969, § 17-5) 
Sec. 17-54. - Charges against firemen. 
    The fire chief shall prefer charges against any member of the fire department, before the civil service commission in accordance with the provisions of chapter 33, article II of this Code, and the rules and regulations of the commission, for incompetency, neglect of duty, disobedience of orders, or violations of any of the standing rules and regulations of the department. 
(Code 1969, § 17-7) 
Sec. 17-55. - Record keeping. 
    The fire chief shall keep or cause to be kept, in books to be provided for that purpose, a full and complete record of all transactions in the fire department and of all property placed in his charge or custody and such other records as shall be required by the business of the department. 
(Code 1969, § 17-8) 
Sec. 17-56. - Annual report. 
    The fire chief shall annually, at the close of each fiscal year, make a written report to the city council, showing the general condition of the department under his management, including pertinent information regarding the fires occurring in the city during the preceding year, loss and such other information as he may deem important to the city. 
(Code 1969, § 17-9) 
Sec. 17-57. - Repair of apparatus. 
    The fire chief shall, whenever any of the fire engines, trucks, hooks and ladders or other apparatus need to be repaired, cause such repairs to be made, within the limits of the provisions of the budget established for that purpose. 
(Code 1969, § 17-10; Ord. No. O99-96, § 3, 11-9-99) 
Sec. 17-58. - Uniform and badge regulations. 
    The fire chief shall make suitable regulations under which the officers and men of the department shall be required to wear some appropriate uniform and badge. 
(Code 1969, § 17-11) 
Sec. 17-59. - Surrender of effects of office on leaving. 
    Upon the expiration of his term of office, or his resignation thereof or removal therefrom, the fire chief shall, on demand, deliver to his successor in office all books, records, apparatus, equipment and property of every description in his possession, belonging to the city or appertaining to his office. 
(Code 1969, § 17-13) 
Sec. 17-60. - Assistant chiefs, fire marshal, battalion chiefs, appointments; removal. 
    The fire chief may appoint such assistant chiefs as he deems necessary, on the basis of merit and performance, from among the fire marshal and battalion chiefs in the fire department. The fire chief shall appoint the fire marshal on the basis of merit and performance from the officers of the fire department. The fire chief may appoint such battalion chiefs as he deems necessary on the basis of merit and performance, from among the captains in the fire department. The fire chief may demote any assistant chief, fire marshal, or battalion chief to the rank previously held for failure to properly or adequately perform his duties or for other just cause. 
(Ord. No. O90-51, § 2, 5-15-90; Ord. No. O00-76, § 1, 7-11-00; Ord. No. O05-11, § 2, 1-25-05) 
Sec. 17-61. - Deputy fire chief. 
(a)  The fire chief may create one (1) position within the fire department to be known as deputy fire chief. The fire chief shall select the person to serve in this position, subject to final appointment by the mayor with the concurrence of the city council. Such position shall be selected from the then-current members of the ranks of assistant chief, fire marshal and battalion chief and shall report to the fire chief, and shall be exempt from the classified civil service. 
(b)  The fire chief may remove such person from the position of deputy fire chief for failure to properly or adequately perform the duties of such person, as determined by general order and in the discretion of the fire chief, or for other just cause. Upon removal from such position, the person shall revert back in rank to the previous rank held prior to appointment hereunder. 
(c)  In the fire chief's absence, the deputy chief shall assume the duties and responsibilities of the fire chief. 
(Ord. No. O05-11, § 3, 1-25-05) 
Secs. 17-62-17-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SERVICE OUTSIDE CITY 

Sec. 17-76. - Authorized generally. 
    The fire department of the city may respond to calls outside the corporate limits of the city as provided in this division; provided, the fire department may respond to calls outside the corporate limits of the city only on the conditions as provided in this division, further provided, the fire department shall respond to calls outside the corporate limits of the city only if in the judgment of the fire chief or officer in charge of the fire department, the responding to such calls will not impair fire protection within the corporate limits of the city, or will not endanger the life, health or property of persons residing within the corporate limits of the city and further provided that in the event of response to properties outside the corporate limits of the city which properties are not covered by a contract with the city as provided in section 17-81, charges for said services provided shall be assessed as set forth in section 17-1. 
(Code 1969, § 17-74; Ord. No. O02-126, § 2, 11-26-02 ) 
Sec. 17-77. - Authorized for places of assembly. 
    The fire department may respond to fire calls at any distance from the city to any school, hospital, church, sanitarium, institution or place of public gathering or assembly to assist in the saving of human life. 
(Code 1969, § 17-75) 
Sec. 17-78. - Cooperative agreements. 
    The fire department may, by agreement, furnish any nearby municipality, person, partnership, corporation, special district, governmental body or agency, federal laboratory or other legal entity with cooperative assistance in case of fire endangering life or property, provided that: 
(1)  In the case of a municipality, the fire occurs within the corporate limits of the municipality requesting such assistance. 
(2)  If such municipality, person, corporation, special district, governmental body or agency, federal laboratory or other legal entity is not equipped to, or does not agree to, furnish reciprocal cooperative assistance, the agreement shall stipulate the amount of service charge to be paid to the city. 
(Code 1969, § 17-76) 
Sec. 17-79. - Application for service. 
    The owners, or their agents or servants, of property, real, personal or mixed, which is outside the corporate limits of the city shall make applications in writing to the fire chief of the city for contract fire protection services for such property. 
(Code 1969, § 17-77) 
Sec. 17-80. - Inspection, approval of property; approval of application. 
    The fire marshal shall investigate all property outside the corporate limits of the city when application is made for contract fire protection service for such property, and shall report to the mayor the result of his investigation together with his recommendation. If the mayor is of the opinion that such property is not so occupied, situated or constructed so as to endanger persons or property, or to be especially liable to fire or liable to cause injury or damage by collapsing or otherwise, the mayor shall approve such application. 
(Code 1969, § 17-78) 
Sec. 17-81. - Contracts for service; conditions, charges. 
    After receipt of an application therefor and inspection of an application therefor and inspection and approval of property as hereinabove provided for, the city may contract to furnish fire protection services to owners of property lying outside the corporate limits of the city. The conditions of such a contract are that: 
(1)  No obligation shall be incurred to protect properties more than three (3) miles from the city limits. 
(2)  All properties covered shall be subject to the fire rules and regulations of the city and subject to inspection by the fire marshal of the city at any time. 
(3)  The use of all buildings and the repairs, alterations, additions and construction of buildings, and properties covered under this contract shall hereafter conform to the fire prevention code, the building code and other applicable codes of the city and be subject to inspection by authorized personnel of the city. 
(4)  The fee for such fire protection service for each one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or part thereof of the assessed valuation of the property to be covered by a contract shall not be less than the combined rate of: 
a.  The rate developed by dividing the total expended by the city fire protection fund during the last completed fiscal year by the latest total assessed valuation of property within the corporate limits of the city. 
b.  The rate developed by dividing the total expended for the city firemen's pension fund for the last completed fiscal year by the latest total assessed valuation of property within the corporate limits of the city. 
The rate shall not be more than one hundred fifty (150) percent of such total rate developed; provided, that the fee for fire protection service outside the corporate limits of the city shall not be less than fifteen dollars ($15.00) per year charged for each contract entered into. 
Such fee shall be paid annually in advance to the treasurer of the city on or before May 1 of each year and shall be prorated monthly for the portion of the fee year only in the case of original application. 
(5)  Any person, firm or corporation desiring such contract fire protection service shall, as part of said contract, sign an agreement to annex which shall require immediate annexation into the city when the subject property becomes contiguous to the corporate limits of the city. 
(6)  Neither the city nor any of its officers or employees shall be liable for failure to provide fire protection service to the property involved; nor shall the city under any circumstances be held liable for any loss or damage by reason of its failure to extinguish fires within the territory described in any such contracts; and further provided, that fire protection service to property involved shall be supplied only if, in the judgment of the fire chief or officer in charge of the fire department, the rendering of such service will not impair fire protection within the corporate limits of the city and will not endanger life, health or property of persons residing within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 17-79; Ord. No. O87-5689, § 1, 7-21-87) 
Sec. 17-82. - Cancellation of contracts. 
    The mayor of the city may cancel or revoke any contract entered into to provide fire protection service to property outside the corporate limits of the city at any time upon written notice of the owners of such property, for violation of any of the terms of such contract or for violation of any of the provisions of this division by the party contracting for fire protection service with the city, or at any time when in his judgment it is to the best interest of the citizens of the city, or that the rendering of such fire protection service will impair fire protection within the corporate limits of the city or will endanger the life, health or property of persons residing within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 17-80) 
Secs. 17-83-17-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIRE PREVENTION CODES AND STANDARDS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 12. 
Codes and standards as adopted in Ch. 12 will be applicable to Ch. 17. 

Sec. 17-101. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person who violates any provision of this article or the codes adopted by this article, or who fails to comply with any order made pursuant thereto, or who, without having appealed, builds in violation of a permit or statement of specifications issued and approved hereunder, or who, subsequent to an appeal, fails to comply with any order as affirmed or modified by the bureau of fire prevention, administrative hearing officer or court of competent jurisdiction, shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-10. Each violation or prohibited condition for which a fine has been imposed must be corrected by such person within a reasonable time; and unless otherwise specified, each ten-day period that a violation or prohibited condition continues after the allowed time for compliance shall be deemed a separate violation and shall be punishable as such. 
(b)  The application of the above penalty shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. 
(c)  Administrative or other proceedings at law to enforce the provisions of this article shall be commenced by a fire code citation, which shall be issued by the fire marshal or such fire inspector as he may designate, both of whom are deemed peace officers for purposes of this article, in the following manner: 
(1)  By preparing a fire code citation ticket and serving the same on any person in charge of, or as owner of, the property on which the violation exists; or 
(2)  By serving the citation by certified mail, return receipt requested, in case no such person may be located upon due diligence. 
(d)  Every ten (10) days that a violation continues after the time for compliance granted has expired shall be deemed a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. 
(e)  An administrative or other legal action may be commenced for prosecution of violations under subsection (a). 
(f)  Notwithstanding the above subsections, violations of those portions of the codes adopted by this article that regulate the annual testing of fire detection, alarm and extinguishing systems shall be punishable as follows: 
(1)  Property owners who fail to provide copies of annual test results to the Aurora Fire Prevention Bureau after being given a written thirty-day notice shall be fined three hundred dollars ($300.00). 
(2)  If, after ten (10) days from the date of the above fine, the property owner has failed to provide copies of annual test results to the Aurora Fire Prevention Bureau, said property owner shall be fined up to an additional one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(3)  If, after ten (10) days from the date of the fine set forth above, the property owner has failed to provide copies of annual test results to the Aurora Fire Prevention Bureau, the subject structure shall be posted "Unsafe Occupancy". 
(g)  Any person parking a vehicle in a properly designated fire lane shall be punished as provided in the Code of Ordinances of the City of Aurora, Illinois, section 27-63. 
(Code 1969, § 17-52; Ord. No. O04-96, § 1, 10-12-04; Ord. No. O12-056, § 1(Exh. A), 7-10-12) 
Sec. 17-102. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O12-056, § 1(Exh. A), adopted July 10, 2012, deleted § 17-102, which pertained to appeals and derived from Code 1969, § 17-50. 
Sec. 17-103. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O12-056, § 1(Exh. A), adopted July 10, 2012, deleted § 17-103, which pertained to modifications and derived from Code 1969, § 17-49. 
Sec. 17-104. - Establishment and duties of bureau of fire prevention. 
(a)  This article shall be enforced by the bureau of fire prevention in the fire department of the city which is established and which shall be operated under the supervision of the fire chief. 
(b)  The fire marshal shall be appointed by and serve at the pleasure of the fire chief. Such appointment shall be from the officers of the fire department. 
(c)  The fire chief may detail such members of the fire department as inspectors as shall from time to time be necessary. The fire chief shall recommend to the civil service board the employment of technical inspectors who, when such authorization is made, shall be selected through an examination to determine their fitness for the position. The examination, to be compiled by the civil service commission and the fire chief, shall be open to members and nonmembers of the fire department, and appointments made after examination shall be for an indefinite term with removal for cause. 
(d)  The fire marshal shall cause to inspect all structures and premises, except single-family dwellings and the interior of dwelling units in two-family and multiple-family dwellings, for the purpose of ascertaining and causing to be corrected any conditions liable to cause fire, contribute to the spread of fire, interfere with fire-fighting operations, endanger life or any violations of the provisions or intent of this Code or any other ordinance affecting life safety. 
(e)  The fire marshal is authorized to enter the structure or premises at any reasonable time to inspect. Prior to entering into a space not otherwise open to the general public, the fire official shall make a reasonable effort to locate the owner or other person having charge or control of the structure or premises, present proper identification and request entry. If requested entry is refused or not obtained, the fire official shall pursue recourse as provided by law. 
(Code 1969, § 17-48; Ord. No. O01-98, § 1, 9-18-01; Ord. No. O12-056, § 1(Exh. A), 7-10-12) 
Sec. 17-105. - Reserved.

No. O95-35, § 1, adopted June 20, 1995; Ord. No. O01-98, § 1, adopted Sept. 18, 2001; and Ord. No. O03-51, § 1, adopted May 27, 2003. 
Sec. 17-106. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O12-056, § 1(Exh. A), adopted July 10, 2012, deleted § 17-106, which pertained to technical standards definitions and derived from Code 1969, § 17-43. 
Sec. 17-107. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O12-056, § 1(Exh. A), adopted July 10, 2012, deleted § 17-107, which pertained to International Fire Code 2000 amendments and derived from Code 1969, § 17-44; Ord. No. O95-35, § 1, adopted June 20, 1995; Ord. No. O01-98, § 1, 9-18-01; Ord. No. O03-51, § 1, adopted May 27, 2003; and Ord. No. O07-101, § 1, adopted Sept. 11, 2007. 
Sec. 17-108. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O12-056, § 1(Exh. A), adopted July 10, 2012, deleted § 17-108, which pertained to Life Safety Code and NFPA Standards amendments and derived from Ord. No. O03-51, § 1, adopted May 27, 2003. 
Sec. 17-109. - Establishment of limits and routes for hazardous gases, liquids and materials. 
    Vehicular transportation of explosives and blasting agents and hazardous chemical and other dangerous articles is prohibited in the city except by special application to and approval by the fire marshal and city council. 
(Code 1969, § 17-45; Ord. No. O95-35, § 1, 6-20-95; Ord. No. O12-056, § 1(Exh. A), 7-10-12) 
Sec. 17-109.1. - Fireworks. 
    It shall be unlawful to sell, offer for sale, give, store, use, possess, explode, fire, ignite or discharge any fireworks or other pyrotechnics within the corporate boundaries of the city. No public exhibition of fireworks shall be made or given unless the exhibition of the same is previously approved, by the fire marshal, upon written application, and the exhibition is supervised by the fire marshal, the fire chief, or their designees. Specifically permitted consumer fireworks as listed in 425 ILCS 30 shall be exempt from the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. O05-76, § 1, 6-14-05; Ord. No. O12-056, § 1(Exh. A), 7-10-12) 
Sec. 17-110. - Fire department access. 
(a)  All premises which the fire department may be called upon to protect in case of fire and which are not readily accessible from public streets shall be provided with access routes and fire lanes so that all buildings on the premises are accessible to fire department apparatus. Such access routes and fire lanes shall be designated by the fire marshal of the bureau of fire prevention when in his judgment they are necessary for effective firefighting operations. 
(b)  Parking of motor vehicles or otherwise obstructing fire lanes shall be prohibited at all times. Any owner of property designated as a fire lane who fails to post such signs and keep such lanes cleared of parked motor vehicles and other obstructions shall be in violation of this chapter. Any person parking a vehicle in a properly designated fire lane shall be punished as provided in section 27-63. 
(Code 1969, § 17-47(A); Ord. No. O88-71, Exh. A, 6-21-88; Ord. No. O94-64, § 1, 6-21-94; Ord. No. O02-159, § 1, 12-10-02; Ord. No. O12-056, § 1(Exh. A), 7-10-12) 
Secs. 17-111-17-125. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O12-056, § 1(Exh. A), adopted July 10, 2012, deleted § 17-111, which pertained to water supplies for fire department use and derived from Code 1969, § 17-47(B). 
ARTICLE IV. - FIRE ALARM SYSTEMS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Central fire alarm system, § 17-5; police alarm systems, § 36-56 et seq. 

Sec. 17-126. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Central fire alarm monitoring system means the equipment located at the fire alarm headquarters for receipt of subscribers' alarms over an approved direct wire system, and not part of any auxiliary fire alarm system. 
    Central station means a supervising station that is listed for central station service. 
    Dial alarm means any device which is a telephone device or telephone attachment that automatically or electronically selects a general use telephone line used for emergency or general business purposes. 
    Direct wire alarm means any fire alarm device running directly from a specific location to fire alarm headquarters and connected by wires. 
    False alarm means an alarm signal which indicates the existence of an emergency situation when in fact, no such emergency exists. 
    Fire alarm headquarters means the premises where direct line telegraph, telephone, radio and generally all other fire department-related communications are received and from which firefighting equipment and personnel are dispatched. 
    Fire alarm system means a system or portion of a combination system consisting of components and circuits arranged to monitor and annunciate the status of fire alarm, suppression, trouble or supervisory signal-initiating devices and to initiate the appropriate response to those signals. 
    Fire alarm user means the person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind in control of the property protected by a fire alarm. 
    Franchisee means a person holding a franchise, contract or agreement with the city for the installation and maintenance of a central fire alarm monitoring system at the fire alarm headquarters. 
    Monitoring location means a location that utilizes a system or a group of systems in which the operations of circuits and devices at a protected property are signaled to, recorded in, and supervised, having competent and experienced operators who, upon receipt of a signal, take such action as required by the National Fire Alarm Code. 
    Remote alarm system means any fire alarm device or aggregation of any fire alarm devices installed on or within a single building or on or within more than one (1) building or area adjacently located on a common site at a specific location consisting of transmitting devices which, when operated manually or automatically, cause an alarm to be transmitted through other means to the fire alarm headquarters of the city for transmission to any or all fire stations of the city. 
    Subscriber means any person who contracts for or receives service or maintenance with respect to a fire alarm system from an alarm business. 
(Code 1969, § 17-91; Ord. No. O99-84, § 1, 10-12-99; Ord. No. O12-056, § 1(Exh. A), 7-10-12) 
Sec. 17-127. - Policy. 
    It shall be the policy of the City of Aurora to respond to all fire alarms, and nothing in this article shall authorize the fire department to refuse to provide service to any fire alarm user. 
(Code 1969, § 17-105; Ord. No. O99-84, § 1, 10-12-99) 
Sec. 17-128. - Alarm installation approval. 
    Required. It shall be unlawful to install and maintain, or to cause to be installed or maintained, any fire alarm system in public schools or occupancies under contract for fire protection with the city without first obtaining approval of the fire marshal. One-family detached dwellings shall be exempt. 
(Code 1969, §§ 17-92-17-95; Ord. No. O99-84, § 1, 10-12-99; Ord. No. O12-056, § 1(Exh. A), 7-10-12) 
Sec. 17-129. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O12-056, § 1(Exh. A), adopted July 10, 2012, deleted § 17-129, which pertained to compliance with standards for maintenance, use and derived from Code 1969, § 17-91; Ord. No. O95-35, § 1, adopted June 20, 1995; and Ord. No. O99-84, § 1, adopted Oct. 12, 1999. 
Sec. 17-130. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O12-056, § 1(Exh. A), adopted July 10, 2012, deleted § 17-130, which pertained to minimum standards prescribed and derived from Code 1969, § 17-97; and Ord. No. O99-84, § 1, adopted Oct. 12, 1999. 
Sec. 17-131. - Fire alarm user registration. 
    It shall be unlawful for any fire alarm user to lease, own, or be in control of any premises wherein a fire alarm system is operated or maintained without first registering with the fire prevention bureau as a fire alarm user. 
(Code 1969, § 17-98; Ord. No. O99-84, § 1, 10-12-99) 
Sec. 17-132. - Fire alarm certificate of acceptance. 
    All fire alarm systems must receive a certificate of acceptance from the fire prevention bureau after inspection to operate legally in the City of Aurora. The certificate of acceptance indicates that the fire alarm system has been designed, installed and tested in accordance with this article and is approved for fire alarm dispatch to the fire department. 
(Code 1969, § 17-99; Ord. No. O99-84, § 1, 10-12-99; Ord. No. O12-056, § 1(Exh. A), 7-10-12) 
Sec. 17-133. - Inspections. 
    The fire prevention bureau may inspect any fire alarm system at any time they deem necessary or advisable. All fire alarm users shall allow the fire prevention bureau and/or the fire department access to the premises upon which the fire alarm systems are installed, for the purpose of inspection, during regular business hours. 
(Code 1969, § 17-100; Ord. No. O99-84, § 1, 10-12-99) 
Sec. 17-134. - Disconnecting unsatisfactory systems. 
    If a given fire alarm system is found to be unsatisfactory or in improper working order, the fire prevention bureau may require that the system be disconnected until such time as corrections are made to the satisfaction of the fire prevention bureau. The fire chief and/or fire prevention bureau may require a fire watch in its sole discretion should a disconnection be required. If fire department personnel are required to serve on fire watch, the fire alarm user must reimburse the City of Aurora at the actual cost of such personnel and equipment. Any fire alarm placed out-of-service pursuant to this section must be repaired and placed back in service within a time period specified by the fire prevention bureau, provided however, that the fire alarm user may, in accordance with all applicable state, local and federal laws, determine not to reinstall or repair said system. Should the fire alarm user determine not to repair said system, all components of the fire alarm system shall be removed from the premises, and a written notice shall be given to the fire marshal advising him of this change within fourteen (14) days thereof. 
(Code 1969, § 17-101; Ord. No. O99-84, § 1, 10-12-99) 
Sec. 17-135. - Maintenance. 
    Each fire alarm user is solely responsible for the installation maintenance, repair, upkeep and operation of his/her own fire alarm system. All fire alarm systems with the exception of one-family detached dwellings shall be tested and system components cleaned annually by a licensed testing agency or licensed electrical contractor. Documentation of the fire alarm system testing and maintenance shall be submitted to the fire prevention bureau within fourteen (14) days of such testing/cleaning. When a fire alarm system not associated with a one-family detached dwelling is out of service for any reason, the fire chief, a battalion chief, or their designee, may, at their sole discretion, require the fire alarm user to implement a fire watch at the user's expense until such time as the fire alarm system is back in service. If fire department personnel are required to serve on fire watch, the fire alarm user must reimburse the city the actual cost of such personnel and equipment. 
(Code 1969, § 17-102; Ord. No. O95-35, § 1, 6-20-95; Ord. No. O99-84, § 1, 10-12-99; Ord. No. O03-49, § 1, 5-13-03) 
Sec. 17-136. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O12-056, § 1(Exh. A), adopted July 10, 2012, deleted § 17-136, which pertained to dial alarm system and derived from Code 1969, § 17-103; and Ord. No. O99-84, § 1, adopted Oct. 12, 1999. 
Sec. 17-137. - Retransmission of alarms. 
    Manual retransmission of alarms shall not be allowed from a location not on the subscriber's premises other than in single-family detached homes. Where manual retransmission of both alarm and trouble signals from an approved central station are accomplished and automatically documented within thirty (30) seconds, such retransmission may be allowed upon specific approval of the fire prevention bureau. 
(Code 1969, § 17-104; Ord. No. O99-84, § 1, 10-12-99; Ord. No. O12-056, § 1(Exh. A), 7-10-12) 
Sec. 17-138. - Testing equipment. 
    No person shall conduct any test or demonstration of any permitted fire alarm system without first having notified the fire prevention bureau and the monitoring location, and if unable to contact, then the fire department and the 911 Dispatch Center shall be notified of said test or demonstration. 
(Ord. No. O99-84, § 1, 10-12-99) 
Sec. 17-139. - False fire alarms. 
(a)  Exception. Alarms resulting from any of the following causes shall not be considered to be a false alarm as that term is defined in this article provided that such event is verified by the fire prevention bureau: 
(1)  A fire causing structural damage to the protected premises. 
(2)  An earthquake affecting the city. 
(3)  A tornado or hurricane affecting the city. 
(4)  Flooding of the protected premises. 
(5)  Lightning causing physical damage to the protected premises. 
(6)  Telephone line malfunction verified to the fire prevention bureau by an authorized telephone company supervisor within seven (7) days of the occurrence. 
(7)  Electrical service interruption verified to the fire prevention bureau by an authorized electric company supervisor within seven (7) days of the occurrence. 
(8)  Plumbing or electrical malfunctions unrelated to the alarm system at the protected premises. 
(b)  Grace period. Fire alarm users shall be granted a thirty (30) day grace period from the date of final acceptance testing before alarms emanating from the protected premises shall be deemed to be false alarms. 
(c)  Out-of-service alarms. A fire alarm which gives three (3) or more false alarms within a twelve-hour period may be considered by the fire prevention bureau to be in improper working order pursuant to section 17-132 of this article. 
(Ord. No. O99-84, § 1, 10-12-99; Ord. No. O12-056, § 1(Exh. A), 7-10-12) 
Sec. 17-140. - Penalties. 
    A violation of any section of this article excluding section 17-139, shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). A violation of section 17-139 shall be punishable as follows: 
1.  For the first false alarm in one (1) calendar year, no fine shall be assessed, unless the fire prevention bureau shall show willful and wanton misconduct on the part of the fire alarm user, his employees or agents. 
2.  For a second (2nd) false alarm in one (1) calendar year, a fine of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) shall be assessed for each fire department response thereto. 
3.  For a third (3rd) and fourth (4th) false alarm in one (1) calendar year, a fine of one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00) shall be assessed for each fire department response thereto. 
4.  For a fifth (5th) false alarm and for each and every succeeding false alarm in one (1) calendar year, a fine of three hundred dollars ($300.00) shall be assessed for each fire department response thereto. 
5.  For any false alarm emanating from a fire alarm user who has not received a permit or certificate of acceptance from the fire prevention bureau for the operation of a fire alarm system in the City of Aurora, a fine of four hundred dollars ($400.00) shall be assessed for each and every false alarm. 
6.  In addition to the fines set forth above, any fire alarm user who refuses or fails to pay within forty-five (45) days of the date of any such false alarm fine assessment, said fire alarm user shall be deemed to have an additional violation of this article, punishable by an additional fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each day that said fines remain unpaid, and said fire alarm user shall further pay all legal fees and costs of the City of Aurora in connection with such false alarm(s). 
7.  The City of Aurora may file a lien against the protected premises for any outstanding fine which is reduced to judgment. 
8.  Any person issued an invoice under this section shall have the right to seek a hearing in front of the hearing officer subject to the provisions stated herein below. 
a.  For purposes of this section, the hearing officer shall be the individual who holds administrative hearings involving violations of the city's property maintenance code under article VII of chapter 12 of the city's Code of Ordinances. 
b.  Any person seeking a hearing by the hearing officer shall file a written petition for hearing within twenty (20) days after receipt of the applicable invoice. The petition must be received by the treasurer or in the treasurer's office prior to the expiration of the twenty (20) day period, or on the first date the treasurer's office is open for business after such date if closed on such date. Mailing such petition on such date shall be insufficient. If the petition is not filed within this time period, then the invoice shall become final and not subject to further review, and the city may proceed with collection of the debt. 
c.  The petition shall state the reason or reasons why the invoice is incorrect or invalid, as the case may be, and state the relief sought from the hearing officer. Upon receipt of the petition from the treasurer, the hearing officer shall promptly set a time and date for a hearing on the petition and shall notify the petitioner of the same not less than seven (7) days prior to the date set for hearing. A hearing date may be continued by the hearing officer for any good cause. 
d.  At such hearing, the hearing officer shall give the petitioner an opportunity to be personally heard and present whatever information or witnesses as he considers pertinent and relevant to the issue. Upon conclusion of such hearing, and after consideration of any information presented by the petitioner and such other information as may be available to the hearing officer, a decision shall be made by the hearing officer either canceling, modifying or affirming the applicable invoice, and notice of such decision shall be given in writing to the petitioner and treasurer. 
e.  The decision of the hearing officer reached at the conclusion of such hearing shall be final, and the treasurer may enforce such decision in the manner provided for under this section or such other manner as may be available by law. 
(Ord. No. O99-84, § 1, 10-12-99; Ord. No. O01-56, § 1, 6-12-01; Ord. No. O12-056, § 1(Exh. A), 7-10-12; Ord. No. O17-009, § 1, 2-28-17) 
Sec. 17-141. - Waiver of liability. 
    The City of Aurora assumes no liability for the transmission of alarm signals, prerecorded alarm messages or the relaying of such signals and messages, for any defects in the installation, operation or maintenance of any alarm system, or for any failure to respond to an alarm pursuant to this section. 
(Ord. No. O99-84, § 1, 10-12-99) 
Secs. 17-142-17-155. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE COMPANIES[6] 
Footnotes:

DIVISION 1. - FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE TAX[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- The provisions of Art. V, §§ 17-156-17-164, were redesignated as Div. 1 by § 1 of Ord. No. O90-136, adopted Nov. 20, 1990. 

Sec. 17-156. - Penalty. 
    Any person who violates the provisions of this article shall be punished as provided in section 11-10-3 of the Illinois Municipal Code [65 ILCS 5/11-10-3]. 
(Code 1969, § 17-119) 
Sec. 17-157. - Exception for marine insurance. 
    This article shall not be applicable to receipts from contracts of marine insurance, even though they include insurance against fire, where the premium for the fire insurance is not separately specified. 
(Code 1969, § 17-118) 
Sec. 17-158. - Fee-Required. 
    Every corporation, company and association which is not incorporated under the laws of this state and which is engaged in effecting fire insurance in the city shall pay to the treasurer of the city for the maintenance, use and benefit of the fire department thereof, two (2) percent of the gross receipts received from fire insurance upon property situated within the city. 
(Code 1969, § 17-111) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/11-10-1. 
Sec. 17-159. - Same-Basis for. 
    Each designated corporation, company and association shall pay at the rate so prescribed, upon the amount of all premiums which have been received during the year ending on every July 1 for all fire insurance effected or agreed to be effected on property situated within the city or the fire protection district, by that corporation, company or association respectively. 
(Code 1969, § 17-112) 
Sec. 17-160. - Reports. 
    Every person who acts in the city as agent or otherwise on behalf of a designated corporation, company or association, shall render to the city, on or before July 15 of each year, a full and true account, verified by his oath, or all of the premiums which, during the year ending on the first day of July preceding the report, were received by him, or by any other person for him on behalf of that corporation, company or association. He shall specify in this a full and true account, verified by his oath, or all of the premiums which, during the year ending on the first day of July preceding the report, were received by him, or by any other person for him on behalf of that corporation, company or association. He shall specify in this report the amounts received for fire insurance, and he shall pay to the treasurer of the city, at the time of rendering this report, the amount for which his corporation, company or association is accountable under this article. 
(Code 1969, § 17-113) 
Sec. 17-161. - Defaulters may not conduct business. 
    If the account required by section 17-160 is not rendered on or before July 15 of each year, or if the sum due remains unpaid after that day, it shall be unlawful for any corporation, company or association so in default to transact any business in the city until the sum due has been fully paid. This provision shall not relieve any corporation, company or association from the payment of any loss upon any risk that may be taken in violation of this requirement. 
(Code 1969, § 17-114) 
Sec. 17-162. - Recovery of amount due. 
    The amount of the tax or license set out in this article may be recovered from the corporation, company or association that owes it, or from its agent, by an action in the name and for the use of the city for money had and received. 
(Code 1969, § 17-115) 
Sec. 17-163. - Right to examine books. 
    The city treasurer may examine the books, records and other papers and documents of a designated agent, corporation, company or association for the purpose of verifying the correctness of the report of the amounts received for fire insurance. 
(Code 1969, § 17-116) 
Sec. 17-164. - Use of proceeds. 
    The city treasurer shall pay over and set apart all such sums of money collected by him pursuant to this article to the fire protection fund of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 17-117) 
Sec. 17-165. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE TAX ADMINISTRATION BOARD[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Section 4 of Ord. No. O90-136, from which this division denotes, provides that the ordinance shall be automatically repealed without further council action should PA 86-0935 (Ill. Rev. Stat. 1989, Ch. 24, ¶ 11-10-2) be declared unconstitutional or otherwise abrogated. 

Sec. 17-166. - Established. 
    There is hereby established a foreign fire insurance tax administration board for the city. In accordance with the requirements of Illinois Revised Statutes, 1989, Chapter 24, paragraphs 11-10-1 and 11-10-2, each year, beginning in 1990, all monies collected and received by the city under the provisions of the foregoing state statute shall immediately be forwarded by the city treasurer to the duly elected treasurer of the foreign fire insurance tax administration board for disbursement by the duly elected officers of the board. Such monies shall only be expended for the maintenance, use and benefit of the city fire department. 
(Ord. No. O90-136, § 2, 11-20-90) 
Sec. 17-167. - Election of board members. 
(a)  The board shall include a treasurer who shall be a member of the fire department and who shall be elected at-large by a vote of all members of the department. The board shall also include one (1) member from each fire company within the department elected by the members of such fire company as well as one (1) member elected by all members of the department not assigned to a company. Additionally, the fire chief or his designee shall be an ex-officio member of the board and shall have a vote and voice in all proceedings of the board. 
(b)  In order to maintain a smooth transition of board leadership, terms of office will be staggered. The board elections for odd-numbered fire companies shall be held before January 13, 1993 for a one-year term and held every two (2) years thereafter. Board elections for even-numbered fire companies and one (1) member of the department not assigned to a company will be held before January 13, 1993 and every two (2) years thereafter. With the exception of the 1993 election for the odd-numbered companies, all elected board members shall serve a two-year term of office and shall be limited to a maximum of two (2) consecutive terms. At the second meeting of each odd-numbered year, beginning in 1993, a chairman and a secretary shall be elected from among the board's members. 
(c)  The board shall appoint an election committee consisting of one (1) member from each rank within the department. The election committee shall be responsible for conducting and supervising the election according to the procedures established by the board. All such election procedures shall be consistent with this division. No member of the election committee shall be a candidate for any office to be voted upon at the same election which he supervises. 
(d)  All board elections shall be conducted by secret mail ballot. All such ballots shall list each eligible candidate in alphabetical order. All ballots shall be mailed to members of the department no less than ten (10) days prior to the final return date established by the election committee. 
(e)  Vacancies shall be filled by a special election from among the relevant constituency. Such vacancies shall be for the balance of the unexpired term of office. 
(Ord. No. O90-136, § 2, 11-20-90; Ord. No. O92-77, § 1, 9-15-92) 
Sec. 17-168. - Bond. 
    The chairman and treasurer of the board shall be required to post a bond, not to exceed one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00), so as to ensure the faithful performance of their duties. 
(Ord. No. O90-136, § 2, 11-20-90) 
Sec. 17-169. - Disbursement of funds; audit. 
    The board shall comply with all state and local bidding and purchasing laws. All monies disbursed by the board shall be approved by a majority vote of the members of the board and all checks or other disbursements shall be signed by the chairman and treasurer of the board. Additionally, all disbursements for fire suppression equipment or duty-related equipment or supplies must be approved by the fire department safety committee prior to board approval. 
    No less than once each month, the board treasurer shall make a report to the city treasurer detailing the receipts and expenditures made during the prior month. Furthermore, at least once each fiscal year, the board shall employ an accounting firm, which is acceptable to the city, to perform an audit of the board's receipts and expenditures. 
(Ord. No. O90-136, § 2, 11-20-90) 
Sec. 17-170. - Title to equipment. 
    Title to all equipment purchased by the board shall be in the name of the City of Aurora. 
(Ord. No. O90-136, § 2, 11-20-90) 
Sec. 17-171. - Rules and regulations. 
    The board may adopt all needful rules and regulations with respect to the management of the money which has been paid over to the board's treasurer. Such rules and regulations shall not be contrary to this division. 
(Ord. No. O90-136, § 2, 11-20-90)

ARTICLE IV. - DRAINAGE PROJECT FEE 

Sec. 18-120. - User fee. 
    A fee is hereby imposed upon all consumers to whom water service is provided by the city for the purpose of funding various projects related to drainage improvements, flood relief and stormwater management in the city. 
(Ord. No. O98-04, § 1, 1-13-98) 
Sec. 18-121. - Amount of fee. 
(a)  Fees contained in this section shall be based upon a two-month billing period or any portion thereof. 
(b)  The drainage project user fee shall be as follows: 
(1)  Commercial water accounts ..... $6.90 
(2)  Industrial water accounts ..... 6.90 
(3)  School/church water accounts ..... 6.90 
(4)  Residential water accounts ..... 6.90 
(c)  For apartment buildings or other multifamily dwellings served by one (1) water meter, a drainage project user fee shall be charged for each apartment unit or family unit served by the water meter whether occupied or not. The amount of the charge per unit shall be the amount set forth in subsection (b) above for residential water accounts. 
(Ord. No. O98-04, § 1, 1-13-98; Ord. No. O04-04, § 1, 1-1-04) 
Sec. 18-122. - Revenues to be deposited in drainage projects fund. 
    All payments of fees, interest and penalties received by the city treasurer, pursuant to this article, shall be deposited by him in an account designated as the city drainage project fund. Monies held in such fund shall be budgeted by the city council solely for expenditures or projects related to drainage improvements, flood relief or stormwater management. For purposes of this section, such expenditures or projects may include land acquisition, engineering, design, construction or reconstruction, and debt retirement in relation thereto. 
(Ord. No. O98-04, § 1, 1-13-98; Ord. No. O99-96, § 3, 11-9-99) 
Secs. 18-123-18-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - STORMWATER MANAGEMENT 

Sec. 18-201. - Kane County Stormwater Ordinance. 
(a)  The Kane County Stormwater Ordinance as now or hereafter amended is adopted by reference as if set forth in this chapter. 
(b)  The city engineer is hereby designated the administrator for said ordinance. 
(c)  The plan commission is hereby designated the oversight committee for said ordinance. 
(d)  The city council is hereby designated the decision making authority for said ordinance. 
(Ord. No. O01-67, § 3, 6-26-01) 
Sec. 18-202. - Same-Additions, insertions, deletions and changes. 
    The following sections of the Kane County Stormwater Ordinance adopted in section 18-201 are hereby revised as follows: 
    Sec. 200 General Information. 
 * * * 
(b)  Developments shall comply with Sec. 203 if: 
(1)  two or more one or two-family residences are to be constructed on a site three or more acres in size; 
(2)  a single-family or duplex residential development is to be constructed on a site more than one acre in size; 
(3)  any non-residential land use is to be constructed on a site more than one (1) acre in size. 
(4)  development after the effective date of this ordinance on a site one (1) acre or more in size devoted to an existing multifamily or nonresidential land use exceeds in the aggregate twenty-five thousand (25,000) square feet. 
 * * * 
    Sec. 202 Site runoff requirements. 
 * * * 
(f)  Any design runoff rate calculation method shall use Bulletin 70 Aurora Point Frequency rainfall statistics and shall calculate flow from all tributary areas upstream of the point of design. Peak discharges for conveyance design purposes shall be based on the critical duration considering the appropriate rainfall distribution. 
 * * * 
    Sec. 203 Site runoff storage requirements (detention). 
 * * * 
(c)  Event hydrograph routing methods such as HEC-1, HEC-HMS, TR-20 or TR-55 tabular method using SCS curve number methodology shall be used, in addition to the city's modified rational method, to calculate design runoff volumes. The controlling methodology shall be the one that calculates the greatest design runoff volume. Event methods shall incorporate the following assumptions: 
(1)  antecedent moisture condition equals two; 
(2)  appropriate Huff rainfall distribution except that SCS Type II distribution is acceptable with TR-55 tabular method only; and 
(3)  24-hour duration storm of 8.4 inches of rain with a 1% probability (100-year) of occurrence in any one year as specified by Bulletin 70 Aurora specific sectional rainfall statistics. 
 * * * 
(n)  Within the Indian Creek and Blackberry Creek watersheds, the required stormwater storage volume to be provided shall be one hundred ten (110) percent of the volume required by the foregoing provisions of this section. 
 * * * 
    Sec. 1301. Procedures; use of funds (fee-in-lieu of site runoff storage) 
 * * * 
(a)  An applicant's request for approval of the payment of a fee-in-lieu of site runoff storage shall be submitted to the Administrator with a copy to the public works director. If the applicable fee is less than $6,000.00, the city council's buildings, grounds and infrastructure committee shall grant or deny the request within 45 days, unless the applicant agrees to an extension. If said fee is $6,000.00 or more, the city council shall, upon referral by the buildings, grounds and infrastructure committee, grant or deny the request within 45 days, unless the applicant agrees to an extension. 
(Ord. No. O01-67, § 3, 6-26-01; Ord. No. O02-61, § 1, 5-28-02; Ord. No. O02-73, § 1, 6-25-02; Ord. No. O03-43, § 2, 4-22-03; Ord. No. O04-35, § 1, 3-23-04) 
Sec. 18-203. - Offenses and penalties. 
(a)  Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects, refuses to comply with or resists the enforcement of any provision of this article (i.e. ordinance violation) or any requirement or condition in any permit issued pursuant to this article (i.e. permit violation) and, in case of a permit violation, fails to correct such violation, omission or neglect, or cease such disobedience, refusal or resistance after notice and reinspection as provided below, shall be guilty of an offense under this article. 
(b)  Whenever the administrator determines that a permit violation exists, he shall serve notice of the violation in the manner prescribed in section 1006 to the permittee. Such notice shall state the nature of the violation and fix a date not less than ten days after the date of the notice when the site will be reinspected. 
(c)  Any person found guilty of an offense under this article shall pay a civil fine in an amount not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) and not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each calendar day during which such violation continues to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(d)  In addition to any fine imposed under this section, the administrator may revoke any stormwater management permit issued to such person. 
(e)  In addition to any fine imposed or permit revocation undertaken pursuant to this section, the administrator may issue an order requiring the suspension of any further work on the site. Such stop-work order shall be in writing, shall indicate the reason for its issuance, and shall specify the action, if any, required to be taken in order to resume work. One copy of the stop-work order shall be posted on the site in a conspicuous place and one copy shall be served in the manner prescribed in section 1006 upon the permittee, if any, or if none, upon the person in whose name the site was last assessed for taxes as disclosed by the records of the supervisor of assessments. 
(f)  In the enforcement of this article, the administrator may bring any action, legal or equitable, including an action for injunctive relief, as he deems necessary. 
(Ord. No. O01-67, § 3, 6-26-01) 
Sec. 18-204. - Fees. 
(a)  If the administrator determines it is in the best interests of the city to contract with a consultant to perform permit or plan reviews, including reviews related to erosion control and wetland issues, the permit applicant shall reimburse the city for all consultant costs related to said reviews prior to the issuance of any permit required by this article. 
(b)  A fee of ninety thousand dollars ($90,000.00) per acre-foot of storage or pro rata part thereof is established for the fee-in-lieu of onsite runoff storage. 
(Ord. No. O01-67, § 3, 6-26-01; Ord. No. O02-20, § 1, 3-12-02) 
Secs. 18-205-18-299. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - EPA-MANDATED LONG-TERM CONTROL PLAN FEE 

Sec. 18-300. - Fee. 
    A fee is hereby imposed upon all consumers to whom water service is provided by the city for the purpose of funding various projects associated with the city's Long-Term Control Plan (LTCP) so as to comply with mandatory standards promulgated by the United States Environmental Protection Agency for the management of discharges from the city's combined sewers. 
(Ord. No. O11-031, § 1, 6-28-11; Ord. No. O13-44, § 1, 8-27-13; Ord. No. O16-011, § 1, 3-8-16) 
Sec. 18-301. - Amount of fee. 
(a)  The fee contained in this section shall be based upon a two-month billing period. 
(b)  The fee shall be as follows: 
(1)  Commercial water accounts ..... $5.85 
(2)  Industrial water accounts ..... $5.85 
(3)  School/church water accounts ..... $5.85 
(4)  Residential water accounts ..... $5.85 
(c)  For apartment buildings or other multi-family dwellings served by one (1) water meter, the fee shall be charged for each apartment unit or family unit served by the water meter whether occupied or not. The amount of the charge per unit shall be the amount set forth in subsection (b) above for residential water accounts. 
(d)  The penalty for failure to pay this fee shall be as provided in Chapter 48, Article II, Division 3 entitled "Rates, Charges and Collection Procedures." Water bill payments made shall be applied in the following order: 
(1)  Environmental refuse disposal fee. 
(2)  EPA-mandated LTCP fee. 
(3)  Drainage project fee. 
(4)  Fees related to water and sewer services. 
(Ord. No. O11-031, § 1, 6-28-11; Ord. No. O13-044, § 1, 8-27-13; Ord. No. O16-011, § 1, 3-8-16) 
Sec. 18-302. - Revenues to be deposited in the long-term control plan fee fund. 
    All payments of fees, interest, and penalties received by the city treasurer pursuant to this article, shall be deposited by him in a fund designated as the long-term control plan fund. Monies held in such fund shall be budgeted by the city council solely for expenditures or projects related to the implementation of the city's long-term control plan. 
(Ord. No. O11-031, § 1, 6-28-11) 
Chapter 19 - TELECOMMUNICATIONS AND CABLE TELEVISION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 25; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 42; taxation, Ch. 44; utilities, Ch. 48. 

ARTICLE I. - SIMPLIFIED TELECOMMUNICATIONS TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O09-30, §§ 1, 3, adopted May 12, 2009, repealed Art. I, §§ 19-1-19-6 and enacted new Art. I, §§ 19-1-19-6 to read as herein set out. Former Art. I, §§ 19-1-19-6, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. O08-116, §§ 1, 3, 12-9-08. 

Sec. 19-1. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
    Amount paid: The amount charged to the taxpayer's service address in such municipality regardless of where such amount is billed or paid. 
    Department: The Illinois Department of Revenue. 
    Gross charge: The amount paid for the act or privilege of originating or receiving telecommunications in the city and for all services and equipment provided in connection therewith by a retailer, valued in money whether paid in money or otherwise, including cash, credits, services and property of every kind or nature, and shall be determined without any deduction on account of the cost of such telecommunications, the cost of the materials used, labor or service costs or any other expense whatsoever. In case credit is extended, the amount thereof shall be included only as and when paid. Gross charges for private line service shall include charges imposed at each channel termination point within a municipality that has imposed a tax under this article and, charges for the portion of the inter-office channels provided within that municipality. Charges for that portion of the inter-office channel connecting two (2) or more channel termination points, one or more of which is located within the jurisdictional boundary of such municipality, shall be determined by the retailer by multiplying an amount equal to the total charge for the inter-office channel by a fraction, the numerator of which is the number of channel termination points that are located within the jurisdictional boundary of the municipality and the denominator of which is the total number of channel termination points connected by the inter-office channel. However, "gross charge" shall not include any of the following: 
(1)  Any amounts added to a purchaser's bill because of a charge made pursuant to: (i) the tax imposed by this article, (ii) the tax imposed by the Telecommunications Excise Tax Act, (iii) the tax imposed by section 4251 of the Internal Revenue Code, (iv) 911 surcharges, or (v) charges added to customers' bills pursuant to the provisions of section 9-221 or 9-222 of the Public Utilities Act, as amended, or any similar charges added to customers' bills by retailers who are not subject to rate regulation by the Illinois Commerce Commission for the purpose of recovering any of the tax liabilities or other amounts specified in those provisions of the Public Utilities Act. 
(2)  Charges for a sent collect telecommunication received outside of such municipality. 
(3)  Charges for leased time on equipment or charges for the storage of data or information for subsequent retrieval or the processing of data or information intended to change its form or content. Such equipment includes, but is not limited to, the use of calculators, computers, data processing equipment, tabulating equipment or accounting equipment and also includes the usage of computers under a time sharing agreement. 
(4)  Charges for customer equipment, including such equipment that is leased or rented by the customer from any source, wherein such charges are disaggregated and separately identified from other charges. 
(5)  Charges to business enterprises certified as exempt under section 9-222.1 of the Public Utilities Act to the extent of such exemption and during the period of time specified by the department of commerce and economic opportunity. 
(6)  Charges for telecommunications and all services and equipment provided in connection therewith between a parent corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries or between wholly owned subsidiaries when the tax imposed under this act has already been paid to a retailer and only to the extent that the charges between the parent corporation and wholly owned subsidiaries or between wholly owned subsidiaries represent expense allocation between the corporations and not the generation of profit for the corporation rendering such service. 
(7)  Bad debts (defined as any portion of a debt that is related to a sale at retail for which gross charges are not otherwise deductible or excludable that has become worthless or uncollectible, as determined under applicable federal income tax standards; if the portion of the debt deemed to be bad is subsequently paid, the retailer shall report and pay the tax on that portion during the reporting period in which the payment is made). 
(8)  Charges paid by inserting coins in coin operated telecommunication devices. 
(9)  Amounts paid by telecommunications retailers under the Telecommunications Infrastructure Maintenance Fee Act. 
(10)  Charges for nontaxable services or telecommunications if (i) those charges are aggregated with other charges for telecommunications that are taxable, (ii) those charges are not separately stated on the customer bill or invoice, and (iii) the retailer can reasonable identify the nontaxable charges on the retailer's books and records kept in the regular course of business. If the nontaxable charges cannot reasonably be identified, the gross charge from the sale of both taxable and nontaxable services or telecommunications billed on a combined basis shall be attributed to the taxable services or telecommunications. The burden or proving nontaxable charges shall be on the retailer of the telecommunications. 
    Interstate telecommunications: All telecommunications that either originate or terminate outside this state. 
    Intrastate telecommunications: All telecommunications that originate and terminate within this state. 
    Person: Any natural individual, firm, trust, estate, partnership, association, joint stock company, joint venture, corporation, limited liability company, or a receiver, trustee, guardian, or other representative appointed by order of any court, the federal and state governments, including state universities created by statute, or any city, town, county, or other political subdivision of this state. 
    Purchase at retail: The acquisition, consumption or use of telecommunications through a sale at retail. 
    Retailer: Includes every person engaged in the business of making sales at retail as defined in this section. The department may, in its discretion, upon application, authorize the collection of the tax hereby imposed by any retailer not maintaining a place of business within this state, who, to the satisfaction of the department, furnishes adequate security to ensure collection and payment of the tax. Such retailer shall be issued, without charge, a permit to collect such tax. When so authorized, it shall be the duty of such retailer to collect the tax upon all of the gross charges for telecommunications in this state in the same manner and subject to the same requirements as a retailer maintaining a place of business within this state. The permit may be revoked by the department at its discretion. 
    Retailer maintaining a place of business in this state: Includes any retailer having or maintaining within this state, directly or by a subsidiary, an office, distribution facilities, transmission facilities, sales office, warehouse or other place of business, or any agent or other representative operating within this state under the authority of the retailer or its subsidiary, irrespective of whether such place of business or agent or other representative is located here permanently or temporarily, or whether such retailer or subsidiary is licensed to do business in this state. 
    Sale at retail: The transmitting, supplying or furnishing of telecommunications and all services and equipment provided in connection therewith for a consideration, to persons other than the federal and state governments, and state universities created by statute and other than between a parent corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries or between wholly owned subsidiaries for their use or consumption and not for resale. 
    Service address: The location of telecommunications equipment from which telecommunications services are originated or at which telecommunications services are received by a taxpayer. In the event this may not be a defined location, as in the case of mobile phones, paging systems, and maritime systems, service address means the customer's place of primary use as defined in the Mobile Telecommunications Sourcing Conformity Act. For air to ground systems and the like, service address shall be the location of a taxpayer's primary use of the telecommunications equipment as defined by telephone number, authorization code, or location in Illinois where bills are sent. 
    Taxpayer: A person who individually or through his or her agents, employees, or permittees engages in the act or privilege of originating or receiving telecommunications in a municipality and who incurs a tax liability as authorized by this chapter. 
    Telecommunications: In addition to the meaning ordinarily and popularly ascribed to it, includes, without limitation, messages or information transmitted through use of local, toll, and wide area telephone service, digital telecommunication networks, private line services, channel services, telegraph services, teletypewriter, computer exchange services, cellular mobile telecommunications service, specialized mobile radio, stationary two-way radio, paging service, or any other form of mobile and portable one-way or two-way communications, or any other transmission of messages or information by electronic or similar means, between or among points by wire, cable, fiber optics, laser, microwave, radio, satellite, or similar facilities. As used in this article, "private line" means a dedicated nontraffic sensitive service for a single customer, that entitles the customer to exclusive or priority use of a communications channel or group of channels, from one or more specified locations to one or more other specified locations. The definition of "telecommunications" shall not include value added services in which computer processing applications are used to act on the form, content, code, and protocol of the information for purposes other than transmission. "Telecommunications" shall not include purchases of telecommunications by a telecommunications service provider for use as a component part of the service provided by such provider to the ultimate retail consumer who originates or terminates the taxable end-to-end communications. Carrier access charges, right of access charges, charges for use of inter-company facilities, and all telecommunications resold in the subsequent provision of, used as a component of, or integrated into, end-to-end telecommunications service shall be non-taxable as sales for resale. Prepaid telephone calling arrangements shall not be considered "telecommunications" subject to the tax imposed under this article. For purposes of this section, "prepaid telephone calling arrangements" means that term as defined in section 2-27 of the Retailers' Occupation Tax Act. 
(Ord. No. O09-30, §§ 1, 3, 5-12-09) 
Sec. 19-2. - Simplified municipal tax imposed. 
    A tax is hereby imposed upon any and all the following acts or privileges: 
(1)  The act or privilege of originating in the municipality or receiving in the municipality intrastate telecommunications by a person at a rate of six (6) percent of the gross charge for such telecommunications purchased at retail from a retailer. To prevent actual multi-municipal taxation of the act or privilege that is subject to taxation under this subsection, any taxpayer, upon proof that the taxpayer has paid a tax in another municipality on that event, shall be allowed a credit against any tax enacted pursuant to or authorized by this section to the extent of the amount of the tax properly due and paid in the municipality that was not previously allowed as a credit against any other municipal tax. 
(2)  The act or privilege of originating in the municipality or receiving in the municipality interstate telecommunications by a person at a rate of six (6) percent of the gross charge for such telecommunications purchased at retail from a retailer. To prevent actual multi-state or multi-municipal taxation of the act or privilege that is subject to taxation under this subsection, any taxpayer, upon proof that the taxpayer has paid a tax in another state or municipality in this state on such event, shall be allowed a credit against any tax enacted pursuant to or authorized by this section to the extent of the amount of such tax properly due and paid in such other state or such tax properly due and paid in a municipality in this state which was not previously allowed as a credit against any other state or local tax in this state. 
(3)  The tax imposed by this chapter is not imposed on such act or privilege to the extent such act or privilege may not, under the constitution and statutes of the United States, be made the subject of taxation by the municipality. 
(Ord. No. O09-30, §§ 1, 3, 5-12-09) 
Sec. 19-3. - Collection of tax by retailers. 
(a)  The tax authorized by this chapter shall be collected from the taxpayer by a retailer maintaining a place of business in this state and shall be remitted by such retailer to the department. Any tax required to be collected pursuant to or as authorized by this chapter and any such tax collected by such retailer and required to be remitted to the department shall constitute a debt owed by the retailer to the state. Retailers shall collect the tax from the taxpayer by adding the tax to the gross charge for the act or privilege of originating or receiving telecommunications when sold for use, in the manner prescribed by the department. The tax authorized by this chapter shall constitute a debt of the taxpayer to the retailer until paid, and, if unpaid, is recoverable at law in the same manner as the original charge for such sale at retail. If the retailer fails to collect the tax from the taxpayer, then the taxpayer shall be required to pay the tax directly to the department in the manner provided by the department. 
(b)  Whenever possible, the tax authorized by this chapter shall, when collected, be stated as a distinct item separate and apart from the gross charge for telecommunications. 
(Ord. No. O09-30, §§ 1, 3, 5-12-09) 
Sec. 19-4. - Returns to department. 
    Commencing on passage of this article, the tax imposed under this chapter on telecommunication retailers shall be returned with appropriate forms and information as required by the department pursuant to the Illinois Simplified Municipal Telecommunications Tax Act, 35 Illinois Compiled Statutes 636/1 et seq., as amended, and any accompanying rules and regulations created by the department to implement this act. 
(Ord. No. O09-30, §§ 1, 3, 5-12-09) 
Sec. 19-5. - Resellers. 
(a)  If a person who originates or receives telecommunications claims to be a reseller of such telecommunications, such person shall apply to the department for a resale number. Such applicant shall state facts which will show the department why such applicant is not liable for the tax authorized by this chapter on any of such purchases and shall furnish such additional information as the department may reasonably require. 
(b)  Upon approval of the application, the department shall assign a resale number to the applicant and shall certify such number to the applicant. The department may cancel any number which is obtained through misrepresentation, or which is used to send or receive such telecommunication tax free when such actions in fact are not for resale, or which no longer applies because of the person having discontinued the making of resales. 
(c)  Except as provided in this section, the act or privilege of originating or receiving telecommunications in this state shall not be made tax free on the grounds of being a sale for resale unless the person has an active resale number from the department and furnishes that number to the retailer in connection with certifying to the retailer that any sale to such person is nontaxable because of being a sale for resale. 
(Ord. No. O09-30, §§ 1, 3, 5-12-09) 
Sec. 19-6. - Maintaining books and records. 
    Every retailer maintaining a place of business in this state, every retailer authorized or required to collect the tax imposed by this article and every taxpayer shall keep accurate books and records of its business or activity, including original source documents and books of entry denoting the transactions that gave rise, or may have given rise, to any tax liability or exemption. All such books and records shall be kept in the English language and, at all times during business hours of the day, shall be subject to and available for inspection by the city. 
(Ord. No. O09-30, §§ 1, 3, 5-12-09) 
Secs. 19-7-19-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COMMUNITY ANTENNA TELEVISION SYSTEMS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, adopted Nov. 27, 2007, deleted Art. II in its entirety and enacted a new Art. II to read as set out herein. Former Art. II pertained to cable communications systems and derived from Ord. No. O89-37, §§ 1-45, adopted May 2, 1989. 

Sec. 19-16. - Intent. 
    The city finds that the provision of cable and video services has great benefit and impact upon the residents and businesses of Aurora.
