Because of the complex and rapidly changing technology associated with cable television and substantially similar video services, the city finds that the public health, safety and general welfare can best be served by establishing certain regulatory powers in the city as this article shall designate. It is the intent of this article to provide for the means to attain the best possible service and developmental results in the public interest and for such public purposes in these matters; and any franchise granted pursuant to this article shall be deemed to include these findings as an integral part thereof. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-17. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Aurora Cable and Video Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-18. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular number, words in the singular number include the plural number, and the use of any gender shall be applicable to all genders whenever the sense requires. The words "shall" and "will" are mandatory and the word "may" is permissive. Words not defined shall be given their common and ordinary meaning. 
    Act means the Communications Act of 1934, the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, as amended by the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992 (47 U.S.C. 521 et. seq.) (hereinafter "Cable Act") and the Telecommunications Act of 1996 as now or hereinafter amended. 
    Administrator or cable/video administrator means that individual who has been appointed by the mayor to oversee and administer the cable/video ordinance and any franchise agreement. 
    Applicant means any cable operator or video provider that applies for a franchise for a CATV system in the city, its agents, employees, or subsidiaries. 
    Cable communications system, cable system, or system shall mean a facility, consisting of a set of closed transmission paths and associated signal generation, reception, and control equipment that is designed to provide cable service which includes video programming and which is provided to multiple subscribers within a community, but such term does not include (A) a facility that serves only to retransmit the television signals of one or more television broadcast stations; (B) a facility that serves subscribers without using any public right-of-way; (C) a facility of a common carrier which is subject, in whole or in part, to the provisions of Title II of this Act, except that such facility shall be considered a cable system (other than for purposes of Section 621 (c)) to the extent such facility is used in the transmission of video programming directly to subscribers, unless the extent of such use is solely to provide interactive on-demand services; (D) an open video system that complies with Section 653 of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 (P.L. 104-104); or (E) any facilities of any electric utility used solely for operating its electric utility systems. 
    Cable operator means any person who provides cable services through means of a cable system that has facilities located in a public right-of-way, or any person who manages, controls, coordinates, or directs the operations of a cable system or as defined in 47 U.S.C. 522(5). 
    Cable service means one-way transmission to subscribers of (i) video programming or (ii) other programming service, and subscriber interaction, if any, which is required for the selection or use of such video programming or other programming service as provided in 47 U.S.C. 522(6), as amended from time to time, and which is provided through wireline facilities located at least in part in the public rights-of-way. 
    CATV provider means a cable operator and/or video provider providing cable services and/or video services to subscribers through the authority of a franchise agreement. 
    CATV service means the provision of cable service and/or video service through the means of a CATV system. 
    CATV system means a cable system or video system franchised in the city pursuance to a franchise agreement pursuant to the Community Antenna Television Act (65 ILCS 5/11-42-11 et seq.) as currently provided or hereafter amended. 
    Channel means a portion of the electromagnetic frequency spectrum which is used in a cable or similar video system that is used or capable of use to deliver a television channel (as television channel is defined by the commission) to subscribers. 
    City means the City of Aurora, State of Illinois, and all the territory within its present and future boundaries and including any other area over which the city exercises jurisdiction. 
    Complaint means any written or verbal communication from any person, individual, business, unit of government, or institution, however communicated, to the franchising authority regarding a matter or matters pertaining to the service or other function of the cable system or franchise. 
    Converter means an electronic device provided by a grantee to subscribers for the purpose of decoding digital and analog signals or changing the frequency of mid-band, super-band, or hyper-band signals to a suitable channel or channels which the television receiver is able to deliver at designated dial locations. 
    Corporate authorities means the mayor and the members of the city council of the City of Aurora. 
    Developed parcel area means any area of the city where there are at least twenty (20) occupied dwelling units per cable mile. 
    Dwelling unit means any single-family or multiple-family residential place of occupancy including one (1) or more rooms in a residential structure designed for occupancy by one (1) family, for living and sleeping purposes. 
    Educational access channel means a non-commercial educational access channel or channels set aside and so designated for the use of schools. 
    FCC means the Federal Communications Commission and any legally appointed, designated, or elected agent or successor. 
    Footprint means the geographic area in the city designated by a holder of state-issued authorization as the geographic area in which the holder will offer cable service or video service during the period of state-issued authorization. 
    Franchise means an initial or renewed nonexclusive right granted through the authority of a franchise agreement between the city and a grantee hereunder which allows the grantee to provide cable service or video service to subscribers in the city. 
    Franchise agreement means a contractual agreement entered into between the city and a grantee by which the grantee is given the right by the city to operate a CATV system and to provide CATV service to subscribers in the city. 
    Franchise fee means a tax, fee, or assessment paid to the city in exchange for the right to operate a CATV system and to provide CATV service to subscribers in the city. The term "franchise fee" does not include: 
(1)  Any tax, fee, or assessment of general applicability that is imposed on some basis other than the fact that a person is a CATV provider and, that is not discriminatory against CATV providers, including, but not limited to, permit fees, bonds and other fees and obligations related to the use of public right-of-ways; 
(2)  Payments that are required by a franchise agreement to be made by the a grantee during the term of a franchise for, or in support of the use of, public, educational, or governmental access facilities; and 
(3)  Capital costs that are required by a franchise agreement to be paid by a grantee for public, educational, or governmental access facilities; or 
(4)  Any fee imposed under Title 17, United States Code. 
    Franchising authority means the City of Aurora, Illinois. 
    Government access channel means a non-commercial channel or channels set aside and so designated for the use of units of local government as provided for in Sections 602(1) and 611 of the Cable Act (47 U.S.C. 522, 47 U.S.C. 531) 
    Grantee means any cable operator or video provider granted a franchise for a CATV system in the city, its agents, employees, or subsidiaries. 
    Grantor means the city in its capacity as a party to a franchise agreement. 
    Gross revenues means and includes all monetary and non-monetary compensation, including all cash, credits, property of any kind or nature or other consideration, received directly or indirectly by a grantee, its subsidiaries, or any other person in which the grantee has a financial interest or which has a financial interest in the grantee, arising from, attributable to or in connection with the operation of the grantee's cable system and provision of cable service within the city, including but not limited to: Basic tier cable service; any tier of video programming service other than basic service; any optional, premium, per-channel or per program service, regardless of the method of transmission; any installation, disconnection, re-connection, change-in-service or other customer service; late or administrative fees; rentals of converters, remotes or other customer premises equipment; provision of data services such as Internet service, carried over the cable system (to the extent that they may be included as gross revenues by law); commercial leased channels or channel access; advertising compensation (including infomercials); per subscriber share of revenues for grantee's subscribers within the city, compensation from home shopping channels; the sales of programming guides; revenue from all charges for the insertion of commercial advertisements upon the system; revenue from the sale or use of the system's subscriber list; compensation from all charges for leased access or use of studio and such other compensation sources from the provision of cable service as may now exist or hereafter develop, provided that such compensation, fees, receipts or charges may lawfully be included in the gross revenue base on which the city may calculate and collect franchise fees. Cable services as defined by the Act that are enabled by the grantee and delivered to subscribers by means of Internet Protocol (IP) shall be subject to this definition of gross revenues. 
Gross revenues shall not include any amounts refunded to subscribers, any unpaid subscriber or advertiser accounts and any sales tax, telecommunications tax, utility message tax or other taxes imposed directly upon any subscriber or user by the city, the state or other governmental unit and collected by the grantee on behalf of and for remittance to the city, the state, Kane County, or other governmental unit. As used herein, annual gross revenues shall mean gross revenues attributable to a twelve-month accounting period, or portion thereof. This definition of gross revenues shall be the basis for computing the franchise fees imposed pursuant to [Section 44] hereof. 
    Incumbent means a person that provided cable service or video service in the city under a franchise agreement with the city on January 1, 2007. 
    Installation means the connection of a cable, video or CATV system from a subscriber drop to a subscriber's terminals. 
    Leased access means the use of the system by any business enterprise or other entity (whether profit, nonprofit or governmental) to render services to the citizens of the city, and shall include without limitation all use pursuant to Section 532 of the Act. 
    Mayor means the mayor of the City of Aurora, Illinois, or his or her authorized designee. 
    Ordinance means the Aurora Cable Ordinance, as may be amended from time to time. 
    Person means any individual, firm, corporation, limited liability company, partnership of any kind, association, joint venture or organization of any kind and the lawful trustee, successor, assignee, transferee or personal representative thereof. 
    Public access channel means a channel or channels specifically designated as a channel or channels available to the public for the production of non-commercial programming as subject to applicable law. 
    Public rights-of-way means the property described in article X, chapter 42, section 42-301 of the Aurora Municipal Code. 
    School means any public or private elementary school, secondary school, junior college, college or university which conducts classes or provides instructional services and which has been granted a certificate of recognition by the State of Illinois. 
    Street or public street shall mean the surface, the air space above the surface, and the area below the surface of any public street, road, highway, lane, path, alley, sidewalk, boulevard, drive, or bridge, now or hereafter held by the city. No reference herein, or in any franchise, to the public street shall be deemed to be a representation or a guarantee by the city that its title or interest to any property is sufficient to permit its use for such purpose, and a grantee shall, by the use of such terms, be deemed to gain only such rights to use property in the city as the city may have the undisputed right and power to give. 
    Subscriber means any person who has accepted the grantee's offer to provide CATV service by means of a cable, video or CATV system within the city. 
    Subscriber drop means a wire, cable, fiber or other conduit that connects the tap of a feeder cable to a ground block at a subscriber's premises. 
    PEG user means a party utilizing a cable system channel for purposes of production or transmission of material to subscribers, as contrasted with receipt thereof in a subscriber capacity. 
    Video programming means programming provided by, or generally considered comparable to programming provided by, a television broadcast station as defined in 47 U.S.C. 522 (20). 
    Video provider means a person providing video service to subscribers in the city. 
    Video service means video programming and subscriber interaction, if any, that is required for the selection or use of such video programming services, and which is provided through wireline facilities located at least in part in the public rights-of-way without regard to delivery technology, including Internet protocol technology. This definition does not include any video programming provided by a commercial mobile service provider defined in 47 U.S.C. 332(d) or any video programming provided solely as part of, and via, service that enables users to access content, information, electronic mail, or other services offered over the public internet. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-19. - Police powers. 
    Nothing in this article or in any franchise agreement shall be construed as an abrogation of any of the city's police powers. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-20. - Grant of franchise. 
(a)  No person, including cable operators and video providers, shall construct, install, maintain, or operate within the city or on public streets or public rights-of-way unless a franchise has first been granted by the city pursuant to the provisions of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/11-42-11 et seq.) and this article, or unless a state-issued authorization is in full force and effect. Such franchise shall not take the place of any other license or permit which may be legally required of the grantee in order to conduct such a business. The granting of any franchise by the city shall create a non-exclusive right in the grantee to provide CATV service to subscribers in the city and shall not preclude the city from granting any other franchise to a qualified applicant. 
(b)  The city may grant a franchise for all or any defined portion of the city. The franchise area shall be the entire area defined in the franchise agreement. No franchise may be granted without a franchise agreement approved by a majority of the corporate authorities then holding office. 
(c)  In the event that city grants a franchise to construct, operate, maintain, and reconstruct a CATV system in the city, said franchise shall constitute both a right and an obligation to provide the CATV service as required by the provisions of this article. 
(d)  Any franchise granted under the provisions of this article shall be consistent with federal and state laws and regulations to the extent constitutionally required, and local ordinances and regulations, as from time to time amended. In the event of conflict between the terms and conditions of a franchise agreement and the statutory standards on which the city has the authority to grant a franchise, the statutory requirements shall, without exception, control. Interpretation, amplification and clarification of statutory requirements found in the franchise agreement shall not be considered a conflict unless they cannot be interpreted, amplified or clarified in harmony with applicable statutory provisions. 
(e)  The term of any franchise shall be as established in the franchise agreement between the grantee and the city, unless terminated sooner as provided in this article. 
(f)  The requirements for franchise established by this article may be modified from time to time to reflect changing conditions and as necessary to protect the public health, safety and welfare in the exercise of the city's police powers. Such requirements shall be retroactive to franchises then in effect to the extent relating to the reasonable exercise of police powers or as permitted by the franchise agreement, but in any case shall become applicable when the franchise is renewed. 
(g)  The term of any new franchise and all rights, privileges, obligations, and restrictions pertaining thereto shall be as established in the franchise agreement, unless terminated sooner as hereinafter provided. 
(h)  Provisions relating to a grant of franchise under this section shall apply to and include renewals of franchise under this article. 
(i)  All franchises granted shall be granted consistent with the requirements and authority prescribed in Section 621 of the Cable Act (47 U.S.C. 541) and the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/11-42-11 et seq. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-21. - Franchise renewals. 
(a)  Cable franchise renewals shall be processed in accordance with the procedures provided in 47 U.S.C. 546 as modified or amended from time to time. 
(b)  A grantee shall file a renewal application with the city not later than thirty-six (36) months prior to the date on which the franchise will expire and shall cooperate with the city in following the notice, public participation and performance review requirements established in the Cable Act (47 U.S.C. 546 (a)-(h)) as modified or amended from time to time. 
(c)  Video franchise renewals shall be processed in substantially similar fashion as cable franchises. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-22. - Franchise amendments. 
    The city may entertain modifications of a cable franchise consistent with the terms and conditions set forth in Cable Act (47 U.S.C. 545), as now or hereafter amended. Requests for modification shall be made by the grantee by application. Modifications shall be processed, negotiated and approved by mutual consent of the grantee and city consistent with applicable law. Modifications of video franchises shall be processed in substantially similar fashion as cable franchises. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-23. - Contents of franchise applications. 
    The city shall require the submission of applications for a franchise under this article. 
(a)  Initial applications for a franchise under this article shall include at a minimum: 
(1)  A clear description of the identity of the applicant, including but not limited to the name of the applicant, the address of the applicant, the nature of the business entity, a statement of those persons who hold ownership of more than five (5) percent of the stock of the business entity of the applicant, or more than five (5) percent of partnership or membership holdings if the entity is a partnership or limited liability company (LLC), and evidence of the compliance of the business entity with all federal, state and local laws applicable thereto. 
(2)  Plans and specifications relating to all aspects of the applicant's proposed cable system as are applicable to the building and zoning laws of the city or as may be required by the City of Aurora City Engineer or director of public works. 
(3)  A map or maps of a scale of not less than one (1) inch equaling one thousand (1,000) feet showing the precise geographic area for which applicant seeks a franchise ("franchise area"). 
(4)  Projected financial pro forma for estimated CATV system revenue expenditures, debt servicing, and operation for a period of no less than ten (10) years, and evidence of financial responsibility in the form of a letter from an officer of a financial institution that has a financial relationship with the applicant as a lender, significant shareholder, or partner, and that has substantial knowledge of the applicant's financial condition. 
(5)  Audited financial statements by a nationally recognized accounting firm acceptable to the city, annual corporate reports and balance sheets, profit and loss statements for no less than the previous two (2) years. 
(6)  Written documentation of any financial support from a financial institution for issuance of any loans, bonds, notes, or other related instruments to the applicant for the purpose of defraying the costs of the proposed CATV system construction or operation. 
(7)  Applicants shall pay a nonrefundable application fee in an amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), which amount shall be used by the city to offset direct expenses in preparing the application documents, and for time and assistance incurred by city staff, legal counsel and technical consultant assistance. An applicant to whom the city council grants a non-exclusive franchise shall, in addition to the nonrefundable fee specified hereinabove, pay to the city at the time of acceptance of the franchise, an amount to be determined by the city council based upon the costs to the city for the granting of the franchise to be used to reimburse all direct, reasonable expenses actually incurred by the city in granting the franchise which are not fully defrayed by the nonrefundable fee as required hereinabove. 
(8)  Detailed plans and specifications for the proposed CATV system which is proposed by the applicant, including layout of proposed construction and routing of trunk and feeder cables, and node locations reflected upon the map(s) provided pursuant to subsection (3), and a tentative construction progression schedule. 
(9)  A statement of applicant's technical service and repair capabilities within the city and customer service policies and operations for the community. 
(10)  A statement by the applicant indicating whether a franchise held by the applicant, applicant's business entity, or any person or persons required to be identified in subsection (a)(1) has been revoked or denied renewal. Such statement shall also include representations that the owners, partners, operating officers, principals, or principal stockholders or members owning more than five (5) percent of the applicant's business entity have not been convicted of a crime or been placed under investigation or indictment for alleged illegal or improper activities by any state investigative agency, or federal investigative or regulatory agency, including but not limited to the U.S. Department of Justice, Federal Communications Commission, Securities and Exchange Commission, or the Federal Trade Commission. 
(11)  Any other information requested by the franchising authority that is not included in the above subsections that is pertinent and appropriate to the evaluation and awarding of a CATV franchise. 
(b)  Applications for renewal of a cable franchise shall be processed pursuant to the provisions of the Cable Act and this article, shall include all of the information set forth in subsection (a) above, and shall also include and shall be subject to the following additions and modifications: 
(1)  Any communication and/or documentation required for renewals under Section 626 of the Cable Act (47 U.S.C. 546); 
(2)  Any updated or current information necessary to supplement documentation required under paragraphs 1-6 and 8-11 of subsection (a); and 
(3)  Specific documentation of grantee's prior performance and operation during the existing franchise, including but not necessarily limited to the history of revenue flows and subscriber statistics, and such other historical documentation as the city may reasonably request. 
(c)  Applications for renewal of a video franchise shall be processed in substantially similar fashion to cable franchises. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-24. - Review of franchise applications. 
(a)  The city shall review all franchise applications consistent with Section 621 of the Cable Act (47 U.S.C. 541), the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/11-42-11 et seq.), and any other applicable law, and the city shall: 
(1)  Review the application and all information submitted therewith, as to both completeness and competency thereof; 
(2)  Request and evaluate any supplemental documentation that may be required as a function of the thorough review of the application and plans and specifications submitted therewith; 
(3)  Request and review all documentation necessary for verification of the applicant's compliance with all appropriate federal and state laws and municipal codes and regulations; 
(4)  Seek such public comment as may be necessary to determine the appropriateness of the application; 
(5)  Require any supporting documentation or studies that relate to the applicant's proposal and applicant's capability for administration of a CATV system, particularly demonstrating but not limited to: technical capabilities, applications of new technologies, system performance, financial responsibility of applicant, programming and services offered, and applicable company policies, as each may be available; and 
(6)  Collect from applicant all incidental expenses of city's evaluation and processing of the application and its content under this subsection and any attorneys' and consultants' fees incurred by the city in the review process. 
(b)  For application for franchise renewal, the city shall follow the terms, conditions and proceedings established by Section 626 of the Cable Act (47 U.S.C. 546) now in effect or hereafter amended. 
(c)  After city staff review of the application and all further materials under this section, the application shall be referred by the city staff with a recommendation thereon to the mayor, who shall refer it to the city council for action in accordance with appropriate city ordinances. Within sixty (60) days of approval of a renewed franchise, a grantee shall pay to the city a fee in the amount of any staff, legal, consulting and other costs incurred by the city in the process of renewal of the franchise. 
(d)  All applications when filed shall be available for public inspection at places designated by the city. A decision shall be made by the city after the filing of the application based upon the evaluation thereof. 
(e)  The city may grant one (1) or more franchises, or may decline to grant any franchise. All franchises granted shall be non-exclusive and revocable as provided by law, and no competitive franchise shall be unreasonably refused. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-25. - Revocation of franchise. 
(a)  The franchise granted to the grantee pursuant to a franchise agreement is subject to revocation in the event of any breach of a franchise agreement or violation of this article. The following events, acts or omissions on the part of the grantee may be considered cause for revocation of the franchise and termination of a franchise agreement: 
(1)  Failure to complete initial construction or upgrade of CATV system as specified in a franchise agreement. 
(2)  Failure, after notice and an opportunity to cure, to comply with the material provisions of this article. 
(3)  Failure, after notice and an opportunity to cure, to comply with the material terms of a franchise agreement. 
(4)  Fraud or misrepresentation in an application of information provided in order to obtain the franchise. 
(5)  Failure to pay taxes, franchise fees, costs or penalties when and as due the city. 
(6)  Insolvency or bankruptcy of the grantee, subject to the U.S. Bankruptcy Court, or other court of competent jurisdiction. 
(7)  Transfer of the franchise without city approval pursuant to section 35 [16-45]. 
(8)  Abandonment of the franchise. The grantee shall be deemed to have abandoned its franchise if it willfully refuses or is unable to operate the CATV system as granted by a franchise agreement pursuant to this article, when there is no event beyond the grantee's control that prevents the operation of the CATV system, and where operation would not endanger the health or safety of the public or property. 
(b)  In the event of a breach of a franchise agreement or violation of this article, the city shall give written notice to the grantee setting forth: 
(1)  The nature of the breach or violation by the grantee; 
(2)  A written demand that the grantee correct the breach or violation; 
(3)  Notice that any failure to correct the breach or violation within thirty (30) days, or as the parties may agree in a franchise agreement, may be cause for revocation of the franchise. 
(c)  The grantee shall respond within thirty (30) days in writing to the city after receipt of a notice of breach or violation and shall provide any and all information and documentation in support of its response. The grantee's response may include a statement: 
(1)  That it contests the city's notice of breach or violation and requests an opportunity to be heard as provided herein. 
(2)  That corrective action has been implemented by the grantee and the breach or violation has been cured. 
(3)  That corrective action has been implemented by the grantee and is being actively and diligently pursued, accompanied with a written corrective action plan that includes the estimated time period in which the breach or violation will be cured. 
(d)  If requested by the grantee, or if the city is not satisfied that sufficient corrective action is being actively and diligently pursued by the grantee to remedy the breach or violation, the city shall schedule a public hearing to hear and determine the issues and to consider whether sufficient cause exists to revoke the franchise. The city shall give the grantee not less than fourteen (14) days' written notice specifying the city's intent to consider the revocation of the grantee's franchise, and the date, time and place of the public hearing to be held before the city council or a hearing officer appointed by the city council. 
The hearing may be held by the council or by a hearing officer appointed by the council. If a hearing officer has been designated, the hearing officer shall hear the relevant evidence, preserve a record and submit written findings and a recommendation to the city council for the council to make the appropriate determination. 
(e)  If the hearing is conducted by a hearing officer, the grantee shall be entitled an opportunity to present to the city council a summary, orally or in writing, of its position in response to the hearing officer's findings and recommendations, but the grantee shall not have further opportunity to present facts or evidence in support of its position. The city council shall receive and consider the record and the hearing officer's findings and recommendations, shall consider the grantee's summary of its position, and shall determine whether or not a breach or violation by the grantee has occurred, whether it has been cured or a satisfactory corrective action plan has been submitted and is being actively and diligently pursued and whether cause exists to initiate revocation of the franchise or to impose some lesser sanction. The city council may continue the hearing in order to allow the grantee to comply with any lesser penalty imposed by the city council in order to correct any breaches or violations. In the event that the city council determines that cause exists to revoke the franchise, it shall send notice of revocation within a reasonable time after said determination. 
(f)  If the city council determines that cause exists to revoke the franchise, it may, by ordinance, declare a grantee's franchise to be terminated and revoked consistent with applicable law, provided that the city may grant a grantee an additional period of time to remedy the substantial breach or violation before such ordinance is becomes effective or grant a time period in which the grantee may reinstate the revoked franchise. 
(g)  No provision of this section shall be deemed to bar or otherwise limit the right of the franchising authority to seek or obtain judicial relief to enforce the provisions of this article or a franchise agreement. 
(h)  In the event that a franchise has been revoked by the city and the city acquires ownership of the CATV system, or affects a transfer of ownership of a grantee's CATV system to another person, any such acquisition or transfer shall be governed under Section 627 of the Cable Act (47 U.S.C. 547) or its successor provision. 
Failure by a grantee to comply with a timetable for corrective action as required by the city council pursuant to the requirements of this section shall be considered to be a breach of this article and may result in a cause for revocation of the franchise. 
(i)  The city council may, upon good cause shown, and upon its own motion, impose any lesser sanction permitted by this article, a franchise agreement, or as such lesser sanction is permitted at law or in equity. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-26. - Continuity of operations. 
    In the event of revocation of the franchise, expiration of the franchise, or transfer of the franchise between the existing grantee and a successor grantee, the existing grantee (prior to the revocation, transfer or expiration) shall continue to provide CATV service to its subscribers until a successor CATV provider operates the CATV system in the same manner and with the same types of programming, customer service, and repair capabilities and under the same terms and conditions as provided by a franchise agreement and this article prior to the change in status of the franchise. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-27. - Cable system construction/reconstruction scheduling. 
(a)  Franchise applications for an initial franchise shall include a schedule for construction of the initial build out of the CATV system. In the case of a franchise that is being considered for renewal, the renewed franchise agreement shall include a schedule for upgrade, if no upgrade has been undertaken during the then existing franchise, or if an upgrade is deemed by the city to be necessary to meet market conditions during the term of the renewed franchise, and shall include a timetable for commencement or enhancement of CATV services to subscribers. 
(b)  Within three (3) months after acceptance of a new initial franchise or renewed franchise, grantee shall furnish the franchising authority with a copy of preliminary engineering drawings and an operating construction schedule setting forth target dates by area for construction activity. If substantial changes become necessary, grantee shall modify such drawings and schedule to reflect any substantial changes. No permit for such construction or reconstruction shall be granted without the provision of the aforementioned drawings and schedule; provided, however, that the grantee may identify such drawings as being confidential in accordance with the Illinois Freedom of Information Act. 
(c)  Grantee shall furnish the franchising authority progress reports on construction or upgrade of the CATV system at such time and in such manner as reasonably determined by the city engineer or cable/video administrator. 
(d)  Grantee shall provide as built maps, which are capable of being reproduced and in an electronic format that can be utilized by the city's geographic information system (GIS), of the cable system to the city within ninety (90) days after the initial construction or upgrade of the cable system is substantially completed. If a grantee desires, it may provide a set of as built drawings that shall be public records, and a separate set of detailed maps containing proprietary information that the city would agree to protect from public disclosure as can be protected under the Illinois Freedom of Information Act laws. 
(e)  If a grantee is delayed in completing the initial construction or reconstruction upon renewal of a franchise of a CATV system and such delay is beyond the physical or administrative control of the grantee, grantee shall notify the franchising authority of said delay and shall indicate the cause or causes for the delay. Upon receipt of notification by the grantee of such delay, the franchising authority and the grantee shall determine a revised schedule for the recommencement and completion of the work. In the event that the delay continues beyond the control of grantee, and extends beyond the agreed-upon date, the franchising authority and the grantee revise the schedule in like fashion. Delays in construction or service that extend beyond any final dates agreed upon by grantee and the franchising authority in a franchise agreement or otherwise shall constitute a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-28. - Use of public rights-of-way and easements. 
(a)  For the purpose of providing CATV service pursuant to a franchise to subscribers in the city, a grantee may use public rights-of-way in the city to construct, maintain and operate a CATV system, subject to the following: 
(1)  A grantee may only use the public rights-of-way that have been dedicated for compatible uses that are within a grantee's franchise area; 
(2)  A grantee shall comply with all generally applicable codes, regulations and ordinances pertaining to the construction of facilities in public rights-of-way, including the Aurora Right-of-Way Ordinance. 
(b)  For the purpose of providing CATV service pursuant to a franchise in the city, a grantee may use private easements in the city to construct, maintain and operate a CATV system, subject to the following: 
(1)  The safety, functioning and appearance of the property and the convenience and the safety of other persons shall not be adversely affected by the installation or construction of the facilities necessary for a CATV; 
(2)  The cost of the installation, construction, operation, or removal of such facilities shall be borne by the CATV provider or subscribers or both; and 
(3)  The owner of the property shall be justly compensated by the CATV, for any damages caused by the installation, construction, operation, or removal of such facilities by the CATV. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-29. - Completion. 
(a)  For an initial franchise, a final order of completion of the CATV system shall be issued by the city engineer when, all of the following have been completed to the satisfaction of the city engineer: 
(1)  Construction of the CATV system has been completed within the entirety of each franchise area in compliance with construction standards, National Electrical Code and National Electrical Safety Code requirements and right-of-way standards adopted by the city, the design and other requirements of this article, and all other applicable codes and ordinances of the city; 
(2)  CATV services have been made available to one hundred (100) percent of the dwelling units within the franchise area; 
(3)  Any and all studio facilities, equipment, channels and other services, resources or benefits required for public, educational, and governmental access purposes have been completed and made available (with the exception of items to be completed at a future date); 
(4)  Complete and accurate "as built" plans pursuant to section [19-27] have been filed or made available by the grantee to the city; and 
(5)  A notice of completion has been filed by the grantee as hereinafter provided. 
(b)  For reconstruction or upgrade under a renewed franchise, a final order of completion shall be issued by the city engineer when all of the following have been completed to the satisfaction of the city engineer: 
(1)  Reconstruction or upgrade of the system has been completed within the entirety of the franchise area in compliance with construction standards, National Electrical Code and National Electrical Safety Code requirements and right-of-way standards adopted by the city, the design and other requirements of this article, and all other applicable codes and ordinances of the city; 
(2)  The agrees changes to the CATV services resulting from the upgrade have been made available to one hundred (100) percent of the dwelling units within the franchise area; 
(3)  Complete and accurate "as built" plans have been filed or made available by the grantee to the city; and 
(4)  A notice of completion has been filed by the grantee as hereinafter provided. 
(c)  For purposes of this article, CATV service shall be deemed to be made available when it is offered on a non-discriminatory basis for immediate usage to the owner or occupant of each dwelling unit upon the exercise of the option to accept that offer within the customary time for connection of new CATV service users. 
(d)  For the purpose of determining compliance with the provisions of this article and of determining completion under this section, the total number of dwelling units within each developed parcel shall be deemed to be the actual number of units available for occupancy as of a date forty-five (45) calendar days in advance of the date of filing by the grantee of the notice of completion; provided that the grantee files the notice of completion with a good faith belief that it has in fact achieved completions of the date of filing. 
(e)  A grantee who asserts completion shall file a written notice of completion with the city clerk. The notice of completion shall state the total number of dwelling units available for occupancy within each developed parcel forty-five (45) calendar days in advance of the filing of the notice, the total number of dwelling units to which CATV service has been made available within each developed parcel as of the date of filing, and shall otherwise certify completion as defined by subsection (a) or (b). Neither the notice of completion nor the statements, assertions or certifications contained therein shall be deemed to be binding upon the city. 
(f)  Within the sixty-day period following the filing of the notice of completion, all elements and components thereof, and all equipment and studio facilities required by the franchise documents shall be subject to inspection by city employees or authorized agents or representatives thereof, for the purpose of determining whether the CATV system and related facilities comply with the franchise and the provisions of this article. The grantee shall cooperate with such inspection and provide such information and cooperation as is required in order to permit an adequate investigation to determine the existence or nonexistence of such compliance. 
(g)  The grantee shall offer to install, make operational, and render CATV service to all developed parcel areas within the franchise area in accordance with this article and the franchise agreement, within the time period specified in the franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-30. - Universal service. 
    Each grantee under this article shall offer CATV service of equal quality and uniform type of services available, subject only to a reasonable construction schedule established by the grantee pursuant to section [19-27] to all dwelling units within each developed parcel area. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-31. - The franchise area. 
    The franchise agreement shall describe a franchise area of which contour, so far as is possible, shall follow streets. Within the perimeter of the contour, no developed parcel area shall be excluded from the offer of CATV services provided in the franchise area so described. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-32. - Extension of lines and franchise area. 
(a)  If the franchise area is the entire jurisdictional area of the city, the grantee shall be required to extend its CATV system and make CATV service available to every developed parcel area that is annexed to the city simultaneously with the installation of utility lines to the extent practical. For property included in the initial franchise area that is not part of a developed parcel area the grantee shall extend its CATV system and make CATV service available to every dwelling unit when that portion of the franchise area that becomes a developed parcel area within a reasonable time after a developed parcel area is established. 
(b)  In areas of the franchise territory not included in the initial franchise service area, the grantee shall be required to extend and make its cable system and cable service available to every dwelling unit in all unserved, developing areas having at least twenty (20) occupied dwelling units per cable mile, as measured from the existing cable system simultaneously with the installation of utility lines to the extent practical. 
(c)  The grantee shall extend and make CATV service available to any dwelling unit that is not in a developed parcel area of the franchise area or that is not in the franchise area to a person that requests connection at the standard connection charge, if the connection to the isolated resident would require no more than a standard one hundred twenty-five-foot drop line. 
(d)  Upon request for service to any dwelling unit that is not in a developed parcel area of the franchise area, the grantee shall provide an estimate of the grantee's costs required to extend service to the subscriber. The grantee shall then extend service upon request of the potential subscriber upon payment or assurance of payment satisfactory to the grantee. In the event any such payments are made within thirty-six (36) months of the area in which such a dwelling unit is located becomes a developed parcel area, the grantee shall refund the payment for extending the CATV service to that dwelling unit. 
(e)  In areas of new construction or property development where utilities are to be placed underground, the city shall require the developer or property owner to give the grantee reasonable notice of such construction or development, and of the particular date on which open trenching will be available for the grantee's installation of conduit, pedestals, and/or vaults and laterals to be provided at the grantee's expense. The grantee shall provide specifications as needed for trenching. Costs of trenching and easements required to bring service to the development shall be borne by the developer or property owner; except that if the grantee fails to install its conduit, pedestals and/or vaults and laterals within ten (10) working days of the date the trenches are available, as designated in the notice given by the property owner or developer to the grantee, then the cost shall be borne by the grantee if the trenches are closed after the ten-day period. 
(f)  Nothing herein shall be construed to prevent the grantee from serving geographical areas within the franchise area that are not developed parcel areas or geographical areas located outside of the jurisdictional boundaries of the city that are not required to be covered by this article or a franchise agreement. 
(g)  Geographical areas that are annexed to the city shall become a part of the franchise area and shall be subject to the provisions and requirements of this article and the applicable franchise agreement. Grantee shall make CATV service available to newly annexed developed parcel areas of the city within a reasonable time after annexation. 
(h)  The city and the grantee shall, in the term of the franchise agreement, develop procedures and criteria for the extension of CATV system plant, including fiber optic cabling, to existing and planned industrial and business parks. 
(i)  The grantee, in its initial, renewal or modification application, may propose or agree to a line extension policy that will result in serving more residents of the city than required above, in which case, the grantee's policy will be incorporated into the franchise agreement and will be binding on the grantee. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-33. - General capability. 
    Each grantee shall, at a minimum: 
(a)  Develop and operate a CATV system with the technological capabilities specified in the applicable franchise agreement, similar standards being adhered to therein for similar technical applications, and the community needs and interests ascertained under the Act being addressed where possible; 
(b)  Agree to modify the capabilities referred to in subsection (a), in accordance with industry-accepted changes in cable or video technology, as may be specified in the applicable franchise agreement; and 
(c)  Agree to add such CATV system capability provisions to the franchise agreement as may, from time to time, be permitted by law and agreed to by both parties. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-34. - Standby power. 
    Each CATV system shall include the equipment capable of providing standby and back up powering that is to be specified in the franchise agreement. The CATV system shall incorporate safeguards necessary to prevent injury to linemen resulting from a standby generator powering a "dead" utility line. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-35. - Override capability. 
(a)  Each CATV system shall include an emergency alert capability that will permit the city to override, by remote control, touch-tone telephone, cellular or PCS telephones, or otherwise, the audio and/or video of all channels simultaneously, under the conditions and in the manner specified in the franchise agreement, and including those capabilities for alternate broadcasts so specified therein, in the event of a declared public emergency. 
(b)  Upon requirement by the FCC to participate in the emergency alert system, grantee shall provide the following: 
(1)  A channel alert system that provides subscribers with appropriate audio and/or visual emergency warnings on all channels operated by the grantee at any given time. 
(2)  An emergency alert system (EAS) or its successor, in accordance with all requirements of the FCC, including, but without limitation, the requirement currently set forth in FCC regulations that cable television systems transmit a visual EAS message on at least one channel and that cable television systems also provide video interruption and audio EAS message on all channels with the video further stating which channel is carrying the visual message. In establishing its EAS system, the grantee shall cooperate with the city on the use and operation by the city of the EAS. 
(3)  In the event of emergencies that are not subject to the provisions of the EAS regulations established by the FCC (47 U.S.C. 11.53, 11.55) upon notification of said emergency by the mayor or his/her designee, the grantee shall transmit a visual message on at least one (1) channel and provide video interruption and an audio message on all channels with the video further stating which channel is carrying the visual message. 
(4)  A grantee and the city shall jointly develop an emergency notification plan that shall be integrated into the city's disaster and emergency operations plan, and which plan shall be coordinated with the DuPage County Emergency Communications (DuComm), the Will County Office of Emergency Management, the Kendall County Emergency Services and Disaster Agency (ESDA) and the Kane County Office of Emergency Management, and such other similar agencies as are part of the local, state and federal emergency services systems. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-36. - Technical standards. 
    To the extent permitted by law: 
(a)  Each grantee shall construct, install and maintain its CATV system in a manner consistent and in compliance with all applicable laws, ordinances, construction standards, governmental requirements, and technical standards established by the FCC or otherwise as applicable, including the FCC technical standards contained in Part 76, Subpart K of the commissions rules and regulations, as updated and amended from time to time (47 CFR. 76, Subpart K). 
(b)  Each grantee shall at all times comply with the current National Electrical Safety Code (National Bureau of Standards), National Electrical Code (National Bureau of Fire Underwriters), applicable FCC and other federal, state and local regulations, and codes and other ordinances of the city as amended from time to time. In particular, all towers, antennas, satellite receiving stations, and other exposed equipment including subscriber drops and power supplies of grantee used in the provision of CATV service shall be properly grounded in accordance with the National Electrical Code and the National Electrical Safety Code adopted by the city, and all applicable city codes. 
(c)  In any event, the CATV system shall not endanger or interfere with the safety of persons or property within the city or other areas in which the grantee may have equipment located. 
(d)  Construction, installation and maintenance of the CATV system shall be performed in an orderly and workmanlike manner and in close coordination with public and private utilities serving the city following accepted construction procedures and practices and working through existing committees and organizations. 
(e)  All cable and wires shall be installed, where possible, parallel with electric, and telephone lines, and multiple cable configurations shall be arranged in parallel and bundled in compliance with acceptable and safe engineering practices. 
(f)  Any antenna structure used in the CATV system shall comply with construction, marking and lighting of antennae structures, required by the United States Department of Transportation. 
(g)  RF leakage shall be checked at reception locations for emergency radio services so as to prove that no interference signal combinations are possible. Radiation shall be measured adjacent to any proposed aeronautical navigation or communication radio sites to prove that no interference to air navigational reception is possible. 
(h)  Each CATV system, including currently existing CATV systems upon completion of an upgrade, shall provide: (1) a minimum of one hundred (100) video channels without regard to method of delivery or capacity; (2) stereo sound reproduction capacity, where a stereo signal is provided by the programmer; and (3) platform expansion capability, without regard to technological format, that enables a grantee to respond to marketplace conditions for enhanced CATV services. 
(i)  Each CATV system shall have the capacity to identify system faults through electronic status monitoring equipment installed at locations consistent with a grantee's engineering practices. 
(j)  Each CATV system shall have the capability to provide upstream channel and downstream channel capacity. 
(k)  Each CATV system shall be designed and capable of twenty-four (24) hour, continuous operation of all services offered through the CATV system. 
(l)  Each CATV system shall be designed and capable of providing a parental control mechanism or device that permits the subscriber to lock out audible and visual reception of programming of the subscriber's choice upon request. For purposes of this article, a converter box that contains a micro-processing chip that enables blocking or scrambling of cablecast signals shall meet the requirements of this section. 
(m)  Each CATV system shall be designed and operated so that it does not interfere with television reception of subscribers or persons not served by the grantee, nor shall any franchised CATV system interfere with, obstruct or hinder in any manner the operation of the various utilities serving the residents within the confines of the franchise area. 
(n)  Grantee shall comply with the provisions of 47 U.S.C. 76.802 et seq. of the U.S. Code of Federal Regulations in the disposition of cable home wiring. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-37. - Testing and compliance with FCC/state standards. 
(a)  Each grantee shall perform all tests necessary to determine and confirm compliance with the FCC technical standards. Tests shall include, at minimum, proof-of-performance tests required by FCC Rule Section 76.601 (47 U.S.C. 76.601) and such additional or repeat tests involving specified subscriber terminals as may be required to determine compliance with the FCC technical standards. 
(b)  Written records of test results shall be maintained at each grantee's local office, and each grantee shall provide to the city, upon request, written reports of the grantee's annual proof of performance tests conducted pursuant to FCC standards and requirements and state standards and requirements as codified by the city at []. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-38. - CATV programming. 
(a)  A grantee shall provide on the CATV system all over-the-air broadcast stations required to be carried by federal law or FCC regulations as currently in force or hereafter amended. grantee shall provide a wide range and diversity of programming for subscribers residing within the franchise area. Unless otherwise provided by a franchise agreement, categories of programming comparable in quality, mix, and level to be provided by grantee to subscribers shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Local, regional, national, and international news programs. 
(2)  Local, regional, and national sports and sporting events. 
(3)  Local, regional, and national weather. 
(4)  Educational programming. 
(5)  Children's programming. 
(6)  Music programming (including audio music services). 
(7)  Public affairs programming. 
(8)  General entertainment programming, including movies. 
(9)  Cultural programming. 
(10)  Pay-per-view programming. 
(11)  Financial and business-related programming. 
(12)  Foreign language programming (including Spanish language programming). 
(13)  Broadcast stations. 
(b)  When a broadcaster providing over-the-air broadcast service to the grantee has not reached an agreement with the grantee for carriage of the broadcaster's signal by the deadline established by the FCC for consent to transmit said broadcaster's signal ("retransmission consent"), the grantee shall not be obligated pursuant to this article to carry said signal until such agreement has been finalized. 
(c)  Grantee shall comply with all applicable laws concerning the provisions of obscene programming. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-39. - Public, educational and government access. 
    Every CATV system franchised pursuant to the provisions of this article shall provide for public, educational and governmental access pursuant to the Act, section [19-49] hereof, and the applicable franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-40. - Support for use of access. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to limit the ability of the grantee to make payments in support of the use of public, educational and/or governmental access additional to any payments otherwise required under this article or the franchise agreement. However, such additional payments are expressly not a requirement of any franchise granted hereunder and shall in no event be considered in the calculation of franchise fees pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-41. - Availability of access facilities. 
(a)  Use of facilities for public, educational and governmental access upon any CATV system, cable system and video system shall be made available as provided by law, under the conditions and in the manner provided and required hereinbelow, in connection with the production of that public, educational and governmental access programming cablecast upon the system. Where a grantee controls and operates an access channel or channels, the grantee shall establish reasonable rules and procedures designed to promote the utilization of the access programming channel that it controls and operates. Where the city or a school controls and operates an access channel or channels, the city or school shall establish reasonable rules and procedures designed to promote the utilization of the access programming and channel or channels. Subject to the approval of the city, which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld, the grantee shall accept and cablecast such public, educational and governmental access programming upon the system as shall be provided to the grantee by all PEG users and entities. The grantee shall allow all PEG users and entities desiring to cablecast public, educational and/or governmental access programming to produce such programming upon and electronically interface directly with the cable system of grantee so as to effectively cablecast the public, educational or governmental access programming. 
(b)  Unless otherwise provided in a franchise agreement, grantee shall dedicate an amount of channel space on its system at a minimum level of one (1) channel for public access programming, one (1) channel for educational access programming, and one (1) channel for governmental access. Grantee shall, where possible, cluster access programming channels together. 
In no event shall the grantee place any access programming channel on any expanded basic service, satellite service, or digital service tier of programming without the express written consent of the city. In the event that any of the access channels have the capability to transmit programming in stereo and/or in HDTV, the grantee shall enable the channel or channels to be transmitted in stereo and/or in HDTV. 
(1)  The public access channel shall be made available to residents of the city on a first-come, first-served, non-discriminatory basis. Where a grantee operates a public access channel, the grantee shall adopt operating rules for the public access channel, designed to prohibit the presentation of any advertising material that promotes the sale of commercial products or services, including lottery information, and any programming in violation of any federal, state, or local law. A grantee shall keep a complete record of the names and addresses of all persons, groups, or PEG users utilizing access time. A grantee shall provide said record to the franchising authority upon request. 
(2)  The educational access channel shall be made available for the use of all schools and public libraries free of charge. Consistent with Section 612 of the Cable Act (47 U.S.C. 532), an educational access channel shall not carry paid advertising to the extent that it would be considered a channel for commercial use. 
(3)  The governmental access channel shall be made available for the use of units of local governments serving the franchise area free of charge. This channel may be shared between units of local government including the city, and Kane, Kendall, Will, and DuPage Counties. 
(c)  In the event that there is more than one (1) CATV provider providing services to the franchise area, the city shall not be precluded from providing, or causing to be provided, programming produced for its public access, government access or educational access channels to any CATV provider if such person provides a separate, direct link to the point of origination. Where a grantee controls and supervises a public, educational or governmental access channel, grantee shall be exempt from the requirements of this subsection. 
(d)  The content of programs on educational and governmental access channels shall not be controlled by a grantee. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-42. - Transfers. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in a franchise agreement, a CATV system shall not be sold, assigned, leased, subject, sold or leased back hypothecated or mortgaged, either in whole or in part, disposed of, transferred in trust, pledged in whole or in part, by voluntary sale, merger, sale and leaseback consolidation or otherwise, or by forced or involuntary sale, nor shall title thereto, either legal or equitable, or any right or interest therein, pass to or vest in any party without the prior written consent of the city expressed by ordinance and then on such conditions as therein may be prescribed. Any sale, transfer, or assignment not made according to the procedures set forth in this article shall render the franchise agreement void. The sale, transfer, or assignment in bulk of the major part of the tangible assets of a grantee shall be considered an assignment and shall be subject to the provisions of this section. 
(b)  In the absence of extraordinary circumstances, the city will not approve any such transfer of control or ownership prior to substantial completion of construction or reconstruction of the CATV system. Notwithstanding the foregoing a grantee may transfer ownership or control of the franchise or the CATV system, after notice to the city, to an entity controlling, controlled by, or under common control with grantee, where such transfer does not result in a change in the management, operator or ultimate controlling entity of the franchise or the system without any release of the liability of the grantee. The recipient of a transferred franchise for said CATV system shall not be subject to the requirements for new franchises, nor shall the recipient be considered a new franchise for any other purpose provided by law, provided that the transferee agrees in writing to abide by all of the terms and conditions of the franchise agreement with the transferor. In no event shall a transfer of ownership or control be approved without the successor(s) in interest to the franchise agreement agreeing in writing to comply with the terms, obligations, and conditions of the franchise agreement for the remainder of the franchise term. The grantee, as transferor, shall promptly cure any present or ongoing franchise violations or defaults prior to the city's granting of consent for the transfer of control or ownership of the franchise. 
(c)  Whenever any transfer subject to city approval under subsection (a) hereof is proposed, a grantee and any proposed assignee or transferee of the franchise shall submit an FCC Form 394, or its successor, containing or accompanied by such information as is required in accordance with applicable law and FCC regulations. In addition, the grantee and/or the transferee shall provide any and all information and documentation of the legal, financial, technical, and character qualifications of the prospective transferee or controlling party to operate and maintain the CATV system. Such information may include that required by subsection 19-23(a)(1) hereinabove. The grantee and the prospective transferee or controlling party shall provide all other reasonable information as allowed under applicable law requested by the city in connection with such inquiry within the timeframes established by the FCC, and that addresses the effect of the proposed transfer or assignment upon the public. 
(d)  Prior approval of the city shall be required where ownership or control of more than twenty-five (25) percent of the right of control of a grantee acquired, is transferred or during the term of the franchise in any transaction or series of transactions by a person or group of persons acting individually or collectively, on the effective date of the franchise agreement. The word control as used herein is not limited to major stockholders but also includes actual working control in whatever manner exercised. By its acceptance of the franchise agreement, a grantee specifically acknowledges and agrees that any such acquisition occurring without a prior approval of the city shall render the franchise void. 
(e)  Subject to any limitations set forth in the franchise agreement, any transfer of the grantee's CATV system, or any part thereof, subject to the city's right of approval pursuant to subsection (a) hereof shall also be subject to the city's right to elect to acquire the grantee's CATV system, or the part thereof proposed to be transferred, for the consideration specified in a bona fide purchase offer based upon valuations from a qualified firm specializing in CATV system appraisals acceptable to the grantee. The city shall exercise this right by written notice to a grantee within thirty (30) days following its receipt of the notice required in subsection (c) hereof. Except for the consideration, the city shall be obligated in exercising this right to accept all other terms of the proposed transfer. The city's rights hereunder shall in no way affect its independent rights under any other provision of this article or under the franchise agreement. 
(f)  Whenever any transfer subject to city approval under subsection (a) hereof is proposed, the grantee shall file an FCC Form 394 at least one hundred twenty (120) days prior to the proposed date of transfer. The grantee shall provide the city with any additional information requested pursuant to subsection (b) above within thirty (30) days of the written request of the city. 
(g)  As prescribed by the Cable Act (47 U.S.C. 537), the city shall be deemed to have consented to a proposed transfer if the city fails to render a final decision on the request for approval of the proposed transfer within one hundred twenty (120) days following the city's receipt of the written application together with all technical, legal, and financial information and all other reasonable information requested by the city as to the effect of the proposed transfer or assignment upon the public, unless the city and the applicant agree in writing to extend the time for the city to review the application and to grant or deny its consent. The consent of the city shall not be unreasonably withheld. 
(h)  Any transfer approved by the city shall be made by a bill of sale or similar document evidencing closing of the transaction, an executed copy of which shall be filed with the city within sixty (60) days after any such transfer. No such transfer shall be approved unless the proposed transferee shall have agreed in writing to comply with all the provisions of this article now in effect or as amended, as well as the applicable franchise agreement and is found by the city to be, in all respects, legally, technically and financially qualified and possess the operating experience reasonably deemed necessary by the city in order to hold a CATV system franchise. Furthermore, no such approval shall be granted until all defaults are cured or a plan to cure has been approved by the city, and unless all monies accruing to the city as of the date of transfer, whether by way of fees, penalties, damages or otherwise, have first been paid in full or is guaranteed to be paid out of the consideration received by the transferor for such transfer. 
(i)  Any sale, transfer, assignment, mortgage, pledge, lease, sublease or other encumbrance of whatever kind or nature made in violation of the provisions of this section shall be void. 
(j)  The transferee shall reimburse city for any incidental administrative expenses, including reasonable attorney's fees, and fees for consulting or other assistance provided on behalf of city that has been expended under this section. 
(k)  The consent or approval of the city to any transfer of the grantee, franchise, or other control thereof, shall not constitute a waiver or release of the rights of the city in and to the use of public streets and public rights-of-way, and any transfer shall, by its terms, be expressly subordinate to the terms and conditions of the franchise being transferred. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-43. - Procedure-remedying material franchise violations. 
(a)  In the event that city determines that grantee has violated any material provision of the franchise, city may make a written demand on grantee to remedy such violation. If the violation is not remedied, or in the process of being remedied to the satisfaction of city, within thirty (30) days following any such demand, city shall determine whether or not such violation by grantee was excusable or inexcusable as follows: 
(1)  The city shall conduct an administrative hearing to review the alleged violation, and grantee shall be provided with an opportunity to be heard upon thirty (30) days' written notice to grantee of the time and the place of the hearing; the allegations of franchise violations; and the remedy sought by the city. 
(2)  If, after notice is given and a hearing is held, city determines that such violation by grantee was excusable, city shall direct grantee to correct or remedy the same within such additional time, in such manner and upon such terms and conditions as city may reasonably direct. If city determines that such violation was inexcusable under a like analysis, then it may impose a fine, penalty or other sanction in accordance with this article or take any other action allowed in law or equity to a municipality for addressing a violation of municipal ordinances. 
(3)  A hearing reviewing the administrative findings may be conducted by a hearing office appointed by the city council on the appeal of either the city or the grantee. Such hearing officer shall be an attorney licensed to practice under the laws of the State of Illinois. 
(4)  The cost of either hearing, if any, shall be borne by the ultimate non-prevailing party. The costs incurred by the parties for attorney's fees, expert witness fees and other expenses shall be borne solely by the party incurring the costs. 
(5)  In any hearing conducted by a hearing officer, the officer shall, upon conclusion of the hearing, prepare a recommended decision which includes findings of fact and conclusions. The recommended decision shall be filed with the city clerk and mailed to the parties not later than thirty (30) calendar days after the conclusion of the hearing. Upon receipt of such a recommended decision, the city council may, without holding a further hearing, either: 
a.  Adopt the recommended decision, including findings of fact and conclusion submitted by the hearing officer; 
b.  Adopt the findings of fact and conclusions contained in the recommended decision, modify the decision, and adopt the recommended decision as so revised; 
c.  Based upon the record of, the hearing, modify the findings of fact, conclusions or decisions, and adopt the recommended decision as so revised; or 
d.  Reject the recommended decision and order that a new hearing be held. 
(6)  If the city council determines there are grounds for termination of the franchise and that the franchise should be terminated, the city council may adopt a resolution which terminates the franchise and includes the decision. The effective date of termination shall be such date as is prescribed by the city council, within its sole discretion, in the resolution. 
(7)  In the event that the city council determines that a remedy other than termination is warranted, the city may impose a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per day per occurrence from the date upon which the violation or violations were to have been cured. 
All fines levied are to be paid within thirty (30) days and if not, such non-payment after thirty (30) days could constitute an additional breach or cause for revocation of the franchise. 
(8)  If the city council adopts a resolution under this section which terminates the franchise, grantee shall have all further legal remedies available to it by law. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-44. - Alternative remedies. 
    No provision of this article shall be deemed to bar the right of the city to seek or obtain judicial relief from a violation of any provision of the franchise or any rule, regulation, requirement or directive promulgated thereunder as allowed by. Neither the existence of other remedies identified in this article nor the exercise thereof shall be deemed to bar or otherwise limit the right of the city to recover, monetary damages (except where liquidated damages are otherwise prescribed) for such violation by the grantee, or judicial enforcement of the grantee's obligations by means of specific performance, injunction relief or mandate, or any other judicial remedy available at law or in equity. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-45. - Non-enforcement. 
    Subject to the provisions of the Act, a grantee shall not be relieved of any obligation to comply with any of the provisions of the franchise or any rule, regulation, requirement or directive promulgated thereunder by reason of any failure of the city or its officers, agents or employees to enforce prompt compliance nor shall such be considered a waiver thereof. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-46. - Communications with regulatory agencies. 
    Copies of all petitions, applications, communications, and reports submitted by a grantee to the FCC or any other federal or state regulatory commission or agency having jurisdiction in respect to any matters directly affecting construction or operation of the cable system serving the franchise area or services provided through the cable system serving the franchise area, shall be submitted to the city within one (1) week of filing. Grantee shall make a good-faith effort to assure that all such filings made by a grantee's parent or affiliates are similarly submitted to the city. Copies of responses or any other communications from the regulatory agencies to a grantee likewise shall be filed, upon receipt, with the city. Any filing specifically requested by the city shall be submitted to the city as soon as practicable. 
(Ord. No. O07-134, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 19-47. - Franchise fee. 
(a)  Payment of franchise fee: A grantee shall pay to the city on a quarterly basis, an amount equal to five (5) percent per year of grantee's annual gross revenue as permitted by law. Gross revenue shall be defined as stated in subsection 19-18(v) hereinabove. Should the law permit an increase in the percentage of gross revenues to be collected by the franchising authority as franchise fees, the franchising authority may impose and collect franchise fees up to maximum amount authorized by law as the franchising authority determines is reasonable and necessary. Payment of franchise fees shall be made by the grantee by the sixtieth day following the close of the fiscal quarter for which the payment is being made. Such dates shall be not later than, May 31, August 31, November 30, and February 28/29.
