(c)  When required for a special event, the number of police officers, emergency medical providers, and fire department employees required for a special event must be based on guidelines established by each separate department. 
(d)  At least thirty (30) days prior to the start of a tier 1 or tier 2 special event, an event organizer shall provide the special events coordinator a written description of all non-city public safety resources that will be used at the special event. 
(Ord. No. O19-002, § Exh. E, 1-22-19) 
Sec. 41.5-161. - Personal security and property security. 
(a)  An event organizer may hire private security, for personal safety or property security during a special event to supplement the services provided by the Aurora Police Department. 
(b)  Private security employed pursuant to subsection (a) must: 
1.  Be in uniform; 
2.  Be able to contact city police, fire, or emergency medical services if necessary; 
3.  Remain on-site during the special event, including while the special event is completed and through the take-down process. 
4.  Be licensed by the State of Illinois; 
5.  Provide necessary documents to show they have been insured and bonded; and 
6.  Not consume any alcoholic beverages or participate in the special event. 
7.  Meet with the Aurora Police Department prior to the event to establish guidelines. 
(c)  The supervising police officer at a special event may, at his or her discretion, reduce the number of peace officers posted at a special event. 
(d)  Unless a peace officer has been authorized by the police chief, or is otherwise on duty and acting in an official capacity of their agency, only peace officers or police cadets commissioned by the City of Aurora shall be used for traffic control on City streets or in City right-of-way for special events, as defined by this chapter. In making a determination for authorization, the police chief shall consider the officer's familiarity with local ordinances and rules of the city, and the proximity of the officer's primary jurisdiction to the city. Exemption: The police chief can make the determination, based on safety and security of the event, for certain tier 3 and tier 4 events to allow volunteers trained by the police department, for traffic control. 
(e)  Volunteers under the supervision of the office of emergency management for the City of Aurora may work under the supervision of the Aurora Police Department to assist at special events. 
(Ord. No. O19-002, § Exh. E, 1-22-19) 
Sec. 41.5-162. - Fire safety. 
(a)  An event organizer shall comply with all applicable International Fire Code requirements as adopted and amended in chapter 17 of this Code (Fire Protection and Prevention), as well as requirements under chapter 12 (Buildings and Building Regulations) under this Code including but not limited to: 
1.  Fire lanes and public safety access; 
2.  Tents and temporary membrane structures; 
3.  Fireworks, pyrotechnics, open flames; 
4.  Theatrical flame or laser performances; 
5.  Occupant loads, exiting, and egress; 
6.  Use of decorative materials and finishes; 
7.  Use, location, storage of propane or other fuel type equipment; and 
8.  Crowd management. 
(b)  An event organizer shall comply with all applicable City of Aurora Fire Department guidelines related to street closures. 
(Ord. No. O19-002, § Exh. E, 1-22-19) 
Sec. 41.5-163. - Medical service. 
(a)  An event organizer may hire medical providers, including licensed medical providers that are not employed by the City of Aurora, for medical support for a special event to supplement the services provided by the Aurora Fire Department. 
(b)  Unless otherwise directed by the fire chief, only medical service responders employed by the City of Aurora may respond to 911 requests within a special event or provide medical transport from a special event. 
(Ord. No. O19-002, § Exh. E, 1-22-19) 
Secs. 41.5-164-41.5-169. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SPECIAL EVENT ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 41.5-170. - Offense and penalty. 
(a)  A person who violates a provision of this chapter or a requirement or condition of a special permit is guilty of a separate offense for each day or part of a day during which the violation is committed or continued. 
(b)  For offense punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00), a culpable mental state is not required for the commission of an offense under this chapter. 
(c)  Each offense is punishable by a fine not to exceed: 
1.  Two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) fine plus cost recovery for a violation of a provision of this chapter or a requirement or condition of a special event permit governing fire safety, zoning, or public health and sanitation, including dumping of refuse, site restoration; or 
2.  Any event organizer/person or organization who holds a special event, regardless of tier, without a proper permit is subject to fines not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and not more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) per day of the unpermitted special event. 
3.  Five hundred dollars ($500.00) fine for all other violations of this chapter or requirement or condition of a special event permit. 
4.  Any other offenses listed in this Code. 
(Ord. No. O19-002, § Exh. E, 1-22-19) 
Secs. 41.5-171-41.5-179. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - REVOCATION OF SPECIAL EVENT PERMIT 

Sec. 41.5-180. - Revocation of special event permit. 
(a)  The special events coordinator may revoke a special event permit if the special events coordinator determines: 
1.  The special events coordinator issued the special event permit in error; 
2.  The event organizer is conducting the event in a manner that does not comply with the special event permit; 
3.  The event organizer fails to maintain insurance as required in this chapter. 
4.  The event organizer or any person associated with the special event has failed to obtain any other permit required by the city; or 
5.  The event poses a threat to public health or safety. 
(b)  Except as provided in subsection (c), the special events coordinator may revoke a special event permit after he or she issues a notice of intent to revoke. The notice of intent will be in writing; specifically set forth the reasons for revocation; specify the corrective measures required for compliance and to prevent revocation; and provide a time period for compliance. 
(c)  Verbal notification is sufficient if an emergency that poses a threat to public health or safety requires immediate revocation. The special events coordinator may provide a warning to the event organizer prior to an immediate revocation. 
(d)  If an event organizer fails to take the corrective measures identified in the notice of intent within the time period provided, the special event permit is revoked without further action by the special events coordinator. 
(e)  If the special events coordinator revokes a special event permit prior to the start of the event, the event organizer may request an appeal hearing in the same manner as set forth in section 41.5-135. 
(f)  A revocation described in subsection (c) that occurs during a special event is effective until the condition causing a threat to public health or safety is remedied and the special event no longer poses a threat to public health or safety. 
(Ord. No. O19-002, § Exh. E, 1-22-19) 
Chapter 42 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 42-1. - General duties of division of streets and electricity. 
    It shall be the duty of the division of streets and electricity to: 
(1)  See that the provisions of all ordinances in regard to streets, alleys, sidewalks and approaches thereto and public drains are obeyed and enforced. 
(2)  Cause all streets and alleys of the city to be thoroughly cleaned. 
(3)  Make a careful and general inspection of the streets, street crossings and bridges in the city, noting the defects therein and take appropriate action to correct such defects. 
(4)  Take timely and proper precautions to prevent damages from insufficient structure of sluices or drains, or stoppage of the same from snow, ice or any other obstruction and to take proper precaution to prevent any damages from defective streets, bridges, crossings and sidewalks. 
(Code 1969, § 42-4(a)-(d); Ord. No. O90-142, § 1, 12-18-90) 
Sec. 42-2. - Preparation, service of citations. 
    Employees of the division of streets and electricity are deemed peace officers, and shall prepare and serve citations personally or by certified mail for violations of sections 20-4, 20-23 and 20-25 and 42-11 of this Code. 
(Code 1969, § 42-4(h)) 
Sec. 42-3. - Street names; signs. 
(a)  The several streets in the city shall be known and designated by the names applied thereto respectively on the maps and records of the city and as designated by the several ordinances in force fixing the names of such streets. 
(b)  The division of streets and electricity may erect signs designating the names of the streets and avenues and other public highways, except alleys, in the city, at all street and avenue intersections. 
(Code 1969, §§ 42-17, 42-18) 
Sec. 42-4. - Surveys generally. 
    The city engineer shall make all surveys within and for the city when called upon by the city council. 
(Code 1969, § 42-8) 
Sec. 42-5. - Determination of grade. 
    The city engineer shall determine the grades of all streets and alleys in the city. 
(Code 1969, § 42-7) 
Sec. 42-6. - Removal of obstructions and encroachments on public property. 
(a)  Whenever the owner or person in possession or control of any obstruction or encroachment in or upon any street, sidewalk or public ground in the city shall refuse or neglect to remove the same within ten (10) days after notice, or without notice if the owner cannot readily be found for the purpose of such notice or if the city determines that the obstruction poses an urgent threat to the public health and safety, the same shall be deemed a nuisance, and it shall be the duty of the police department or the division of streets and electricity to summarily remove or take down the same or cause the same to be removed or taken down, and the expense thereof shall be recoverable of such owner. Every person who opposes or resists the execution of the orders of the division of streets and electricity and the police department in so doing shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
Cross reference- Issuance of citations by public works director or designee, § 2-288. 
(b)  No person shall, without the consent of the division of engineering, in writing, or without the consent of the person superintending any paving, displace or remove any lawful obstruction. 
(Code 1969, §§ 42-20, 42-31) 
Cross reference- Fine schedule for certain violations, § 1-11. 
Sec. 42-7. - Notice to fire department of obstructions. 
    Whenever any public street or alley in the city is obstructed or rendered impassable for vehicles, the person so obstructing or occupying such street or alley shall immediately notify the fire department of the location of such obstruction, and of any change therein from day to day, during the progress of the work causing such obstruction. 
(Code 1969, § 42-25) 
Sec. 42-8. - Obstructions, encroachments generally. 
(a)  The streets and alleys in the city shall be kept free and clear of all obstructions, encumbrances and encroachments, for the use of the public, and shall not be used or occupied in any other way than as herein provided; except as authorized by final determination of the government operations committee of the city council, for street closings related to block parties and other special events. 
(b)  It shall be lawful for any person employed to pave or repave any street in the city, to place proper obstructions across such street for the purpose of preserving the pavement then newly made or to be made, until the same is fit for use. 
(Code 1969, §§ 42-19, 42-30) 
Sec. 42-9. - Openings in or near streets. 
    It shall be unlawful to keep or leave open or allow or suffer to be kept or left open, except when in actual use, any cellar door, trapdoor, coal hole or the grating or cap of any vault, or to allow the same to remain insecure or unsafe, in or upon any sidewalk, street, thoroughfare or passageway, or immediately contiguous thereto. 
(Code 1969, § 42-9) 
Sec. 42-10. - Playing on public ways. 
    No person shall play at ball or engage in any game, sport or amusement or fly any kite upon any public street or way in the city. 
(Code 1969, § 42-10) 
Sec. 42-11. - Depositing snow or sweeping on public ways. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit any snow, leaves, grass clippings or sweepings from any sidewalk, driveway, property or parking lot or other premises onto any street or alley. It shall also be unlawful for any person to sweep or deposit any snow, leaves, grass clippings or sweepings from any sidewalk or building onto any public parkway. 
(b)  Subsection (a) shall not apply, for purposes of snow removal only, to any premises or areas of the city that the city council has determined lack sufficient open space, excluding areas set aside for off-street parking, upon which to accumulate snow. Schedules setting forth these premises or areas shall be on file in the city clerk's office and may be adopted and amended by the city council from time to time by resolution. 
(c)  Persons owning, occupying or controlling any property fronting or abutting on paved sidewalks within the area hereunder shall remove snow, ice or any other obstructions from said sidewalks pursuant to this section. If snow and ice are too hard for removal, those persons shall cover the sidewalks with abrasive material within forty-eight (48) hours after a snowfall or freezing precipitation. The provisions of this subsection shall apply to the area bounded by and including both sides of the following: that portion of Lincoln Avenue from Spring Street to Benton Street; that portion of Benton Street from Lincoln Avenue to Lake Street; that portion of Lake Street from Benton Street to Spruce Street; that portion of Spruce Street from Lake Street to River Street; that portion of River Street from Spruce Street to Pinney Street; that portion of Pinney Street from River Street to the Fox River; that portion of the Fox River from Pinney Street to the east bank of the Fox River at Spring Street extended and that portion of Spring Street extended from the Fox River to Lincoln Avenue. 
(d)  Any person violating any provisions of this section shall upon conviction thereof be punished as provided in section 1-10 or as otherwise specified in section 1-11. 
(Code 1969, §§ 42-13, 42-60; Ord. No. O86-5480, § 1, 3-18-86; Ord. No. O10-02, § 1, 1-12-10) 
Cross reference- Fine schedule for certain violations, § 1-11; issuance of citations by employees of department of streets and electricity, § 42-2. 
Sec. 42-12. - Depositing dirt, mud, gravel on streets. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person at any time and for any purpose including, but not limited to, construction, excavation and hauling of various materials such as dirt, gravel and the like, to deposit upon the public streets of this city dirt, earth, gravel or such other materials. This section is intended to cover the disposition of such materials on public streets whether it be deposited by the wheels of trucks or other vehicles, by dragging of such materials by trucks or other vehicles, by scattering of such materials from trucks or other vehicles, or by or in any other manner. 
(b)  In addition to both the operator and owner of an offending vehicle, if any, the owner of the property from which the offending vehicle or other source of deposit has proceeded shall be considered responsible for the violation. Muddy tire tracks or other deposit trails leading from a parcel of property shall be considered prima facie evidence of violation of this section by the owner of the property. 
(Code 1969, § 42-15) 
Sec. 42-13. - Removal of construction debris. 
    All material of every kind and character that may be deposited upon any public street or thoroughfare in the city, under the conditions of section 42-12 or otherwise, in connection with the construction of sidewalks, curbing, driveways, crossings or any other construction on a street or upon private property in the city, shall be removed and cleaned up by the party performing the work in a manner satisfactory to the superintendent of streets immediately after the completion of the work, or before the completion of the work if, in the opinion of the superintendent of streets, it shall be deemed necessary. If any person shall fail or refuse to remove any material which has been deposited upon the street by him, or through his agents or servants, in connection with construction, when the work is completed, the city may remove the material. The expense of the work shall be paid to the city by the person within fifteen (15) days after a bill for the same is rendered therefor. After such period the city shall take the necessary measures to compel such payment. 
(Code 1969, § 42-35) 
Sec. 42-14. - Interfering with barricades. 
    No person shall remove any barricade erected in front of or about any defective sidewalk or street within the city or in any way interfere with, change or destroy such barricade. 
(Code 1969, § 42-11) 
Sec. 42-15. - Cleanliness of private alleys. 
    The cleanliness or neatness of any private alley is the direct responsibility of the owners or tenants who occupy the buildings along the alley. Any neglect on the part of the tenant or owner of property along such an alley as far as disposition of garbage, rubbish, combustible material or windblown material is unlawful. 
(Code 1969, § 42-14) 
Sec. 42-16. - Damaging surface; interfering with repairs. 
    No person shall injure or tear up any pavement, sidewalk or crosswalk or any part thereof, dig any hole, trench, ditch or drain in, or dig or remove any sod, stone, curb, earth, sand or gravel from, any street, alley or public ground in the city, without first having obtained written permission given in accordance with this Code. No person shall hinder or obstruct the making or repairing of any public improvement or work ordered by the city council, or being done under lawful authority for the city. 
(Code 1969, § 42-22) 
Sec. 42-17. - Liability of permittee occupying street. 
    Any person occupying any portion of any street or alley under any permit shall save and keep the city free, clear and harmless from any and all loss or liability on account of any accident or damages resulting from such occupation, and shall fully remove all material, dirt and rubbish from the space so occupied, and restore such street or alley to its original condition immediately upon the expiration of the period named in the permit. 
(Code 1969, § 42-23) 
Sec. 42-18. - Liability for damages due to street work. 
    In all cases where any person performs any street or sidewalk work, either under contract with the city or by virtue of permission obtained from the city, such person shall be answerable for any and every damage which may be occasioned by persons, animals or property by reason of or connected with the work. 
(Code 1969, § 42-24) 
Sec. 42-19. - Mixing cement, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to mix upon the surface of any street or sidewalk within the city any dry or wet concrete, cement or plaster of any kind or description without the use of a suitable mixing platform or box for the protection of the street or sidewalk. 
(Code 1969, § 42-32) 
Sec. 42-20. - Standards, specifications for streets. 
(a)  Variances from the provisions of this section may be granted in accordance with the procedures and standards in section 43-10. 
(b)  All streets shall be considered in their relation to existing and planned streets, to topographical conditions, to public convenience and safety, and in their relation to the proposed uses of the land to be served by such streets. 
(c)  Where such is not shown on the general development plan, the arrangement of streets in a subdivision shall either: 
(1)  Provide for the continuation or appropriate projection of existing principal streets in surrounding areas; or 
(2)  Conform to a plan for the area of neighborhood approved or adopted by the city council to meet a particular situation where topographical or other conditions make continuance or conformance to existing streets impracticable. 
(d)  Minor streets shall be so laid out that their use by through traffic will not be encouraged. 
(e)  Where a subdivision abuts or contains an existing or proposed major street, as shown on the general comprehensive plan, the city council may require marginal access streets; reverse frontage with screen planting contained in a nonaccess reservation, at least ten (10) feet wide, along the rear property line; deep lots with rear service alleys, or such other treatment as may be necessary for adequate protection of residential properties and to afford separation of through and local traffic. 
(f)  Where a subdivision borders on or contains a railroad or highway, the city council may require a street approximately parallel to and on each side of such railroad or highway, at a distance suitable for the appropriate use of the intervening land, as for park purposes in residential districts, or for commercial or industrial purposes in appropriate districts. Such distances shall also be determined with due regard for the requirements of approach grades and future grade separations. 
(g)  Reserve strips controlling access to public utilities, streets or alleys shall be prohibited. 
(h)  All street intersections and confluences should encourage safe traffic flow. 
(i)  Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than one hundred twenty-five (125) feet for local streets at local streets, and two hundred (200) feet for local streets at minor collector streets should be avoided. 
(j)  Tangents shall be introduced between reverse curves on all streets (see table of minimum standards). 
(k)  When connecting street lines deflect from each other at any one point by more than ten (10) degrees, they shall be connected by a curve with a radius adequate to ensure clear sight distances (see table of minimum standards). 
(l)  Streets shall be laid out so as to intersect as nearly as possible at right angles and, where practical, no street shall intersect any other street at less than eighty (80) degrees. 
(m)  Property lines at street intersections shall be rounded with a sufficient radius to allow for the installation of utilities and adequate approach sidewalks at the crosswalks. The planning commission may recommend comparable cutoffs or chords in place of rounded corners. 
(n)  Street right-of-way widths shall be as specified in the table of minimum standards. 
(o)  Half-streets shall be prohibited except where essential to the reasonable developments of the subdivision in conformity with the other requirements of these regulations and where the planning commission finds it will be practicable to require the dedication of the other half when the adjoining property is subdivided. Wherever an existing half-street is adjacent to a tract for which subdivision is sought, the other half of the street shall be platted within the proposed subdivision. The initial half-street dedication shall be one-half of the required right-of-way in width, with a ten-foot parallel Utility easement, and shall be of sufficient length to provide proper transitions with a minimum pavement width of twenty-two and five-tenths (22.5) feet to the back of curb and of sufficient length to provide proper transitions. 
(p)  Dead-end streets (culs-de-sac) designed to be permanent shall be provided at the closed end with a paved turnaround having an outside pavement radius of at least forty (40) feet and a street property line radius of at least sixty (60) feet and shall not be longer than five hundred (500) feet from the centerline of the intersecting street to the radius point. 
(q)  Dead-end streets that are intended to be temporary shall be also provided with a paved turnaround at the end if the dead-end section of roadway contains any drive openings. Such dead-end stubs will be required to the subdivision unit perimeter to serve adjacent units and to provide traffic circulation. The paved turnaround will not be required if, prior to final acceptance of the subdivision unit, an adjacent subdivision or unit thereof has securities on file with the city clerk for the public improvements of the adjacent subdivision or unit thereof, including the completion or continuation of streets leading to the subdivision. 
(r)  Streets shall conform to the following table of minimum standards:

    All major streets shall have curb openings and/or intersecting streets no closer to each other than one thousand two hundred (1,200) feet where possible, and unless a limited egress and/or ingress can be effectively constructed. 
    Curb openings on local streets shall be at least sixty (60) feet from an intersection, the sixty (60) feet measured from the closest right-of-way line to the center of the drive. 
(s)  Street gradients and vertical curves shall be as specified in the table of minimum standards. 
(t)  Street grades shall provide proper relation between the street and the first floor elevation of the houses or buildings and permit convenient and economical access to and drainage of the lots. 
(u)  No street names shall be used which will duplicate or be confused with the names of existing streets. Existing street names shall be projected wherever possible. Street names shall be subject to the approval of the planning commission. Furthermore, the first name of any street designation shall be unique within the 911 emergency call boundary as determined by the planning council. 
(v)  The following street designation system shall be utilized to differentiate different kinds of public streets: 
(1)  Any new public street running in a generally north-south direction shall be named ___________ Street or ___________ Drive. 
(2)  Any new public street running in a generally east-west direction shall be named ___________ Avenue or ___________ Road. 
(3)  Major streets running in any direction which are designated with special characteristics such as planted medians shall be named ___________ Boulevard. 
(4)  Eyebrow culs-de-sac shall retain the numbering system of the public way that they front on and shall not have a separate name. 
(5)  Culs-de-sac shall be named ___________ Court. 
(6)  Any public street that comes back upon itself shall be called ___________ Circle. 
(7)  Any public street that lacks true directional quality shall be named ___________ Lane. 
(Code 1969, § 42-37; Ord. No. O04-36, § 1, 3-23-04) 
Sec. 42-21. - Vacation of alleys. 
(a)  A petition shall be filed with the city clerk to vacate an alley within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  Whenever a petitioner, whether a private citizen or the city acting in the public interest, files a petition to vacate an alley the burden shall be upon the petitioner to give notice to all property owners whose land abuts the alley, by certified mail, that a petition to vacate is being sought. 
(c)  Such notice shall contain the date of the planning commission meeting at which the petition to vacate will be considered; and the notice shall be given at least fourteen (14) days prior to the planning commission meeting. This notice shall be given entirely at the expense of the petitioner and proof of mailing the notice shall be filed with the city clerk prior to the planning commission meeting thereon. The notice requirements are to be construed as directory, and the validity of any vacation shall be unaffected by noncompliance with this requirement. 
(d)  The planning commission shall review the petition and hear any proponents and opponents as may be convenient after which the planning commission shall submit its recommendation as to the granting of the petition to vacate, to the planning and development committee of the city council. 
(e)  Upon receipt of the recommendation of the planning commission, the planning and development committee shall consider the petition for vacation and process same in accordance with applicable state law. 
(Code 1969, § 42-39) 
Sec. 42-22. - Mailboxes. 
(a)  For purposes of this section, boxes used for receipt of United States mail and placed outside of residences and establishments for such purpose shall be referred to herein as mailboxes. 
(b)  Personnel of the public works department and its divisions shall notify any property owner upon whose or adjacent to whose property is found a mailbox which: 
(1)  Fails to meet the published standards of the United States Postal Service for installation instructions (P.S. Form 4056) as well as Illinois Department of Transportation standards along state highways; or 
(2)  Is located so that the front edge of the mailbox when closed extends closer than nine (9) inches from the backside of the curb, or where no curbing exists, extends closer than eighteen (18) inches from the near edge of the public street pavement. 
(c)  Failure of such notified owner to relocate the mailbox as provided in this section shall render such owner ineligible to receive any appropriate reparations under subsection (d) hereof. 
(d)  In the event of municipal snowplowing along the streets of the city which snowplowing results in direct contact damage to a mailbox thereupon, reparation in an amount of said damage, but not to exceed fifty dollars ($50.00) per separately standing mailbox shall be provided to the applicable property owner, except as provided in subsection (c) hereof. 
(e)  Property owners desiring that the parkway or other off-street or street fringe area immediately in front of and accessing any mailbox be kept free and clear of snow or diminished thereof shall be authorized to clear such area under their own responsibility, and the city shall not be responsible therefor. 
(f)  Nothing in this section shall be deemed to supersede the provisions of section 42-8 of this article. 
(Ord. No. O90-116, § 1, 10-2-90) 
Secs. 42-23-42-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SIDEWALKS 

Sec. 42-36. - Supervision generally. 
    The system of sidewalks laid or to be laid in the public streets, alleys, parks or places in the city (except the cleaning thereof) shall be under the control of the city engineer subject to the direction and authority of the public works director, the city council and the ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 42-47) 
Sec. 42-37. - Construction specifications. 
    No sidewalk shall be laid or constructed in any public street, alley, park or place in the city, unless otherwise provided for by ordinance, except in compliance with the standard specifications for improvements adopted by the city, a copy of which is on file in the office of the city engineer and will be furnished to any person applying therefor. 
(Code 1969, § 42-48) 
Sec. 42-38. - Alignment and grade. 
    Every person constructing sidewalks in the city, unless otherwise provided by ordinance, shall so construct the walks as to conform to the lines and grades furnished by the city engineer. In case any walk is not in conformity with the grade and lines furnished by the city engineer, the person constructing the walk shall, after due notice is given by the city engineer, make such changes in the walk as are necessary to make the walk conform to the lines and grades furnished by the city engineer. If any person shall fail or neglect to change the walk so as to conform to the lines and grades as described aforesaid, within thirty (30) days after due notice has been served upon the person, then the city may make or cause to be made such changes as are necessary to have the walk conform to the requirements aforesaid, and the cost of performing such changes shall be paid by the person constructing the walk. If the person fails and refuses to repay the city such expense as was incurred in changing or constructing the walk, the law department shall file a lien on the adjacent property to compel payment. 
(Code 1969, § 42-49) 
Sec. 42-39. - Sidewalks to be stamped. 
    The contractor shall cause all concrete sidewalks constructed in any public street, alley, park or place in the city to be stamped in plain characters showing the date of construction, the name of the builder thereof and the number of squares constructed. The stamping tool shall be shown the city clerk prior to bonding for sidewalk excavation. 
(Code 1969, § 42-50) 
Sec. 42-40. - Permit required for work. 
    Any person desiring to construct, repair, rebuild or move any sidewalk on any public street, alley or place in the city shall, before beginning such work, obtain an excavation permit to lay the same from the city engineer. 
(Code 1969, § 42-51) 
Sec. 42-41. - Maintenance bond. 
    Before the city engineer shall issue an excavation permit to any person for the construction of a sidewalk along or on any public street, alley or other public place, the applicant for such a permit shall have on file with the city clerk a performance and maintenance bond pursuant to section 42-105. This bond shall be conditioned to keep and maintain in good repair all sidewalks constructed for a period of one (1) year from the date of construction thereof. This in no way reduces the requirements of the provisions of section 42-42. 
(Code 1969, § 42-52) 
Cross reference- Alternatives to bond, § 2-318. 
Sec. 42-42. - Permittee to maintain sidewalk. 
    Every person to whom a permit shall have been issued under this article shall maintain and keep in repair all sidewalks constructed by him for a period of five (5) years from the date of completion thereof, but no such requirement shall be made except as to repairs necessitated by faulty or improper materials, poor workmanship, or failure to properly protect the sidewalk from damage by the elements. 
(Code 1969, § 42-53) 
Sec. 42-43. - Failure to comply with construction requirements. 
    If any person shall build, renew, lay or relay, or attempt to build, renew, lay or relay, or knowingly assist in so doing, any public sidewalk or portion thereof ordered by the city council to be constructed or renewed, without first obtaining a grade therefor from the city engineer or upon a grade contrary to that established therefor by the division of streets and electricity, or in a manner contrary to any of the provisions of the general ordinances of the city or the particular ordinance relating to such sidewalk, the city engineer may stop any further work on such sidewalk, and cause such portion thereof as shall have been so constructed to be reconstructed in accordance with the provisions of such ordinances. Such person so offending shall be guilty of a misdemeanor for every day he shall fail, neglect or refuse to relay, renew or construct such sidewalk, or portion thereof, in conformity with such provisions. 
(Code 1969, § 42-54) 
Sec. 42-44. - Private use prohibited. 
    No part of any sidewalk constructed on or along any street, alley or public place shall be taken for private use by lowering or cutting down the same next to the building, or railing off the same, or shutting off the public from passing along and over the same. Sidewalks shall not be raised up next to the building by constructing a platform or steps on the same, of any material or substance, but the sidewalks shall be built flush up to the building on a uniform grade as herein provided in all such places where the sidewalk extends to the building. 
(Code 1969, § 42-55) 
Sec. 42-45. - Permit required for areaways. 
    No person shall build, occupy or use, or suffer or permit to be built, occupied or used in whole or in part any space in any street under any sidewalk in the city unless permitted to do so by the city council authorizing the city engineer to issue a permit therefor. Such permit shall specify the purpose for which the space is to be used, the extent thereof, and the materials and manner of construction, and shall be issued only on condition that the party receiving the same and his assignee shall, as compensation for the privilege granted, build, maintain and keep in repair the walls of such space and the sidewalk extending over the same in such manner so as at all times to conform with the ordinances of the city and the requirements of the division of streets and electricity. 
(Code 1969, § 42-56) 
Sec. 42-46. - Conditions of areaway permit; revocation; bond. 
    Every person receiving any permit under section 42-45 and building or constructing any space thereunder shall take such permit subject to the conditions that he hold such space as tenant at will of the city, and that the same may be revoked at any time upon giving thirty (30) days' notice to the owner or person in possession of the premises abutting thereon or lying opposite the same, and that such space and the walls and sidewalk thereover shall at all times be the property of the city without expense to it or reimbursement by it before or after revocation. If the owner or such persons cannot be found in the city, then the posting of such notice thirty (30) days before the date of such revocation, upon the premises, shall be a sufficient notice hereunder, and thereafter all rights and privileges in the space shall cease and the city shall continue as the sole owner thereof and be deemed to be in possession as such owner. An areaway permit shall further be subject to the condition that the permittee shall execute and deliver to the city a continuous bond in the penal sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), with sureties to be approved by the law department, conditioned to indemnify, save and keep harmless the city from any loss, expense, damage or liability of any kind whatsoever which the city may suffer or may be put to or may have recovered from it, by reason of the issuance of such permit, or by reason of any act or thing done or neglected to be done under or by virtue of the authority given in such permit, or by or on account of any loss, expense, damage or liability to which the city may suffer or be put to on account of the construction or occupation of such coal-hole, areaway, vault or sidewalk. The bond shall be further conditioned to maintain and keep in repair, in accordance with the directions and requirements of the division of streets and electricity, any coal-hole, areaway, vault or sidewalk built or constructed in accordance with such permit. 
(Code 1969, § 42-57) 
Cross reference- Alternative to bonds, § 2-318. 
Sec. 42-47. - Inspection of areaways; correcting dangerous conditions. 
    The city engineer shall, as often as necessary, thoroughly inspect all sidewalks, coal-holes, areaways, vaults or coverings over the same. In case the walk or covering or the areaway, vault or coal-hole is dangerous or unsafe or will not bear the load required in this article, he shall give to the person or corporation occupying or using such space a five (5) days' notice in writing to repair in accordance with the specifications of the city engineer, such sidewalk, coal-hole, areaway, vault or covering for the same. In case such person or corporation neglects to so repair the coal-hole, areaway, vault or sidewalk, the division of streets and electricity shall repair or cause to be repaired the coal-hole, vault, areaway or sidewalk, in a proper manner at the expense of the person and shall further have the authority and power to abolish and remove such areaway, vault or coal-hole underneath such sidewalk. In case such coal-hole, areaway, vault, sidewalk or any portion thereof shall, in the judgment of the division of streets and electricity, become out of repair or unsafe or dangerous, it may erect or build, or cause to be erected or built around such sidewalk, areaway, or coal-hole such barricades or railings as it may deem proper to prevent any damage arising therefrom. 
(Code 1969, § 42-58) 
Sec. 42-48. - Right of entry to inspect areaways. 
    For the purpose of carrying out the requirement of this chapter, the division of streets and electricity and the city engineer and his designees shall be permitted at all times to enter any building or property, adjacent to or abutting upon any sidewalk beneath which there is maintained any vault, coal-hole or areaway, if he shall deem it necessary, in order to make a thorough examination and investigation of such sidewalk, areaway, coal-hole or vault. Any person who shall hinder or interfere with such inspection shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1969, § 42-59) 
Sec. 42-49. - Use for storage or signs. 
    No public sidewalk shall be used for the storage of goods, wares or merchandise, or sign of any kind or description whatever, and if any person shall place or cause to be placed in or upon any sidewalk any barrel, box, hogshead, crate, package or any other matter or thing whatever and suffer the same to remain thereon more than one (1) hour, he shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and the division of streets and electricity and the police department may cause the same to be removed at the expense of the party placing the same thereon. 
(Code 1969, § 42-61) 
Sec. 42-50. - Opening in or near sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful to keep or maintain an uncovered opening in any sidewalk or passageway, or immediately contiguous thereto. 
(Code 1969, § 42-64) 
Sec. 42-51. - Improvements. 
    Whenever the owner or occupant of any lot in the city is notified by the city engineer or the director of the division of inspections or his designee to raise, lower, repair or install any sidewalk, coalhole, areaway, vault or coverings over the same, or drive approach, in front of, adjacent to or upon any premises owned or occupied by him, it shall be the duty of such owner or occupant to cause the improvement to be made in the manner and within the time prescribed by said officials. Such notice to the owner or occupant shall set forth all city sidewalk participation programs currently available, for the information of said owner or occupant. If the owner or occupant shall fail, neglect or refuse to so raise, lower, repair or install the sidewalk, coalhole, areaway, vault or coverings over the same, in drive approach in accordance with such direction, the department of public works shall immediately raise, lower, repair or install the sidewalk, coalhole, areaway, vault or coverings over the same or drive approach, and the owner or occupant shall be liable for and pay to the city the cost thereof. If any such owner or occupant fails or refuses to repay the city such expense as was incurred in raising, lowering, repairing or installing the sidewalk, coalhole, areaway, vault or coverings over the same, or drive approach, the law department may file a lien on the adjacent property to recover payment of such expense plus administrative costs. 
(Code 1969, § 42-65; Ord. No. O88-121, § 1, 10-4-88; Ord. No. O89-51, § 1, 6-6-89; Ord. No. O92-78, § 1, 9-15-92; Ord. No. O96-36, §§ 1, 2, 4-23-96) 
Editor's note- At the request of the city, the language of section 42-51 has been clarified with the addition of the words "coalhole, areaway, vault or coverings over the same" following the word "sidewalk" generally throughout said section, as applicable. 
Cross reference- Fine schedule for certain violations, § 1-11; issuance of citations by public works director or designee, § 2-288. 
Sec. 42-52. - Plants overhanging, obstructing sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, suffer or permit the branches or parts of any tree, or any shrub or part thereof, hanging or being over any such sidewalk to be nearer thereto than ten (10) feet above the same, or to suffer or permit any vines, shrubbery or plants to grow or be on any such sidewalk or obstruct the free use thereof. 
(Code 1969, § 42-67) 
Sec. 42-53. - Accessibility of curbs and gutters. 
    For all new curbs and gutters which are provided for in the city and all existing curbs and gutters which are a part of any reconstruction, in order to enable persons using wheelchairs to travel freely and without assistance, at each crosswalk a ramp with nonslip surface shall be built into the curb so that the sidewalk and street blend to a common level. Such ramp shall be not less than thirty-two (32) inches wide and shall not have a slope greater than one (1) inch rise per twelve (12) inches length. Where because of surrounding buildings or other restrictions it is impossible to conform the slope with this requirement, the ramp shall contain a slope with as shallow a rise as possible under the circumstances. In all ramps, there shall be a gradual rounding at the bottom of the slope. 
(Ord. No. O88-70, § 1, 6-21-88) 
Secs. 42-54-42-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EXCAVATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 42-76. - Applicability to franchised utilities. 
    Every public Utility which has the right by virtue of a franchise from the city to install, operate and maintain facilities within public streets shall obtain the permit required hereunder without cost, and shall repair streets cut by them at their own expense, subject to inspection and approval by the city engineer, and otherwise are subject to the terms of this article. 
(Code 1969, § 42-78) 
Sec. 42-77. - Enforcement. 
    It is made the duty of the superintendent of streets and all employees of the division of streets and electricity, the city engineer and all division of engineering employees, the superintendent of water and sewer maintenance and all division of water and sewer maintenance employees, and all of the police officers of the city to take notice of any excavations being made in any of the streets, alleys or public places of the city and report them to the division of engineering. It shall be the duty of the police chief and all of the police officers of the city to arrest any person engaged in making, directing or superintending such excavations, unless he shall, upon demand, exhibit a written permit for the making of the same, duly issued in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1969, § 42-94) 
Sec. 42-78. - Refilling and surfacing procedures. 
    When an excavation is refilled it shall be done in horizontal layers not to exceed six (6) inches in thickness and each layer shall be thoroughly tamped and every third layer shall be thoroughly flushed with water, all in accordance with the city standard specifications for improvements. All excavated material shall be hauled off the site by the permittee. All bituminous concrete paving, as required by the city standard specifications for improvements, will be done by a paving contractor fully bonded under the terms of this article for maintenance and performance. The paving contractor must be shown on the original excavating permit, if applicable. 
(Code 1969, § 42-83) 
Sec. 42-79. - Barricades required; liability for injuries. 
    During the period the work is being done under this article by the applicant he shall maintain lighted flashing barricades to the satisfaction of the city engineer on both sides of the opening, and shall assume all liability for injury to persons or property occasioned by such work. 
(Code 1969, § 42-84) 
Sec. 42-80. - Notice required of excavations by city. 
    Every department of the city, before making any excavation or opening in or under any street, alley, sidewalk or public place in the city, shall so notify the city engineer in writing, giving the location and extent of such excavations, the date of the commencement and approximate date of the completion thereof. Water service connection permits and sanitary service connection permits shall not be given until an executed excavation permit is shown and a copy attached thereto. 
(Code 1969, § 42-85) 
Sec. 42-81. - Notice to fire department and police department. 
    It shall be the duty of the city engineer to notify the fire department and police department of the city of the making of any opening or excavation in any street, alley or avenue in the city which would render such street, alley or avenue impassable or obstruct the use thereof. All such traffic obstructions must meet the approval of the city engineer including the barricading and signing thereof. 
(Code 1969, § 42-86) 
Sec. 42-82. - Compliance with ordinances; inspections. 
    Whenever any excavation is made in or under any street, alley, sidewalk or public place in the city, such excavation shall be made in strict compliance with the terms prescribed in the standard specifications for improvements and by the ordinances of the city, and shall be under the inspection of the city engineer. Failure to obtain the city engineer's inspection will result in extensive testing or complete removal and replacement at the direction of the city engineer. All costs for this remedial work will be borne entirely by the contractor and secured by the performance bond provided for in section 42-105. 
(Code 1969, § 42-88) 
Sec. 42-83. - Damaging public property; dangerous installations. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall authorize or permit the destruction, injury to or marring in whole or in part of any street, alley, public ground or place, or gutter, curb, treebank, sidewalk, trees, shrubbery, plants, or other work or property therein, nor shall any poles, wires, mains, pipes, conduits, work or equipment be placed or maintained in such manner as to injure or be dangerous to persons or property. It shall be unlawful to place or maintain any wire, conduit, conductor or other apparatus in any such street, alley, public ground or place containing or carrying electricity, electric current or power, or any inflammable or explosive gas, liquid, fluid or vapor without safe insulation and protection, and so that the same will not injure or be dangerous to persons or property, and the same shall be kept at all times at such a standard of safety. 
(Code 1969, § 42-89) 
Sec. 42-84. - Maps of facilities required. 
    Every person who has laid or shall lay down or construct any mains, pipes, conduits or other work in any street or alley shall make and keep on file at the office of the city engineer an accurate map showing the exact location of every line or main, conduit, pipe and connection laid by them. Such map shall also show the depth of all mains, pipes, conduits or other work with reference to the city datum and shall at all times be accessible for public inspection. 
(Code 1969, § 42-90) 
Sec. 42-85. - House connections and service pipes. 
    Whenever any person shall receive a permit and proceed to lay mains or pipes in any of the public streets, avenues or alleys of the city, such person or corporation shall lay down and construct in and along such street, avenue or alley, or part thereof, a sufficient number of house connections and service pipes so that there shall be at least one (1) such house connection and service pipe for each dwelling house or other building fronting upon such street, avenue or alley or part thereof, and in addition thereto at least one (1) such house connection and service pipe for each and every vacant lot (according to the subdivisions of the land then existing), or for every fifty-foot frontage of unsubdivided property abutting upon such street, avenue or alley. He shall also lay down and construct sufficient mains or feeders to supply the service pipes whenever the use of the same may be required. The house connection and service pipes shall be laid from the street mains to a point at least one (1) foot farther from the center of the street, avenue or alley than the curblines of the same, as provided herein or by any other ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 42-91) 
Sec. 42-86. - Removal of facilities on notice. 
    A permittee under this article shall, upon notice from the city engineer, and at its own expense, remove or change any main, pipe, conduit, lamppost, service pipe or feeder which interferes with the construction or erection of any viaduct, public building or other public structure, sewer or other public improvement. 
(Code 1969, § 42-92) 
Sec. 42-87. - Work confined to necessary scope. 
    No permittee under this article shall open or encumber more of any street, avenue, alley or public place at any one time than may be necessary to enable it to proceed with advantage in the laying of any such main pipes, feeder or service pipes, nor shall such company permit any such street, avenue or public place to remain open or encumbered for a longer period than shall be necessary to execute the work for which the same shall have been opened. 
(Code 1969, § 42-93) 
Secs. 42-88-42-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 42-101. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, without receiving the permit provided for in this division, to make any excavation or opening in or under any sidewalk, street, alley or public place in the city. Failure to obtain a permit prior to working within the public right-of-way will be grounds to deny such a contractor further privileges to work within the public right-of-way. The city engineer shall order extensive testing to ensure that the work was done according to the city standard specifications for improvements, and all such costs of testing and remedial work will be borne by the offending contractor's performance bond. If there is no such bond on file with the city clerk then the law department will file a lien against the adjacent property to compel such cost payment. 
(Code 1969, § 42-79) 
Cross reference- Fine schedule for violations, § 1-11; issuance of citation by public works director or designee, § 2-288. 
Sec. 42-102. - Application; issuance. 
(a)  Any person desiring to make any excavation or opening in or under any street, alley, sidewalk or public place in the city shall make application therefor to the city engineer upon a form to be provided for such purpose. Such application shall state therein the purpose for which such excavation or opening is to be made, approximate date and time of the commencement and completion thereof. 
(b)  Upon the approval of the city engineer of the application he shall, upon proof of payment by the applicant to the city treasurer of the fees provided for in this division and proof of current bonding on file with the city clerk, issue a street excavating permit authorizing the applicant to make the excavation or opening in the street, sidewalk, alley or public place, subject to restoration as hereinafter provided. 
(Code 1969, § 42-80) 
Sec. 42-103. - Fees. 
    The fees payable to the city treasurer for every street excavating permit shall be as established by ordinance or resolution. 
(Code 1969, § 42-81) 
Sec. 42-104. - Permittee to refill, temporarily pave surface. 
    Excavation permits shall be issued upon condition that the applicant shall remove all materials resulting from the excavation from the site of the work, and shall refill the ditch with sand, and shall cover the upper fourteen (14) inches of the refill excavated area with twelve (12) inches of CA-6 crushed limestone and a temporary two-inch asphaltic concrete surface at the applicant's expense, and shall maintain the temporary surface at the applicant's own expense at which time a permanent surface will be installed by a city bonded contractor at the applicant's own expense. 
(Code 1969, § 42-82) 
Sec. 42-105. - Bond; insurance. 
(a)  Certificate of insurance. No permit for any work within the public right-of-way shall be issued by the city engineer to any person under this article until the applicant for such permit shall file with the city clerk a certificate of general public liability insurance, including trucks and automobiles, in a minimum amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for the death or bodily injury of more than one (1) person in any one (1) accident, five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for the death or bodily injury of any one (1) person in any one (1) accident, and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for the damage to property of any persons or entities in any one (1) accident, conditioned to indemnify, save and keep harmless the city from any and all loss, cost, expense, including reasonable attorney's or solicitor's fees, or liability of any kind whatsoever, which may be recovered from it by reason of the issuance of such permit, or by reason of any act or thing done or neglected to be done under and by virtue of the authority given in such a permit. Further, such a certificate of insurance must include a thirty-day cancellation notice to the city in the case of termination. The person must also have on file with the city clerk a certificate of workman's compensation insurance prior to any issuance of any permit to work on the public properties. 
(b)  Bonds. No permit for any work within the public right-of-way shall be issued by the city engineer to any person under this article until the applicant for such permit shall file with the city clerk, in a form to be prepared and furnished by the city and approved by the law department thereof, a performance and one-year maintenance bond in the penal sum of twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) for the appropriate class of excavation requested, namely: 
(1)  General excavation (other than (2) and (3) below); 
(2)  Sidewalk excavation; 
(3)  Paving excavation. 
An applicant may file for any combination, but must submit a separate bond for each class of excavation and must show a previous competent record for each class of excavation. The performance and one-year maintenance bond must provide the following: 
(1)  Insure completion within the time specified within the permit; 
(2)  Insure adherence to all provisions of this section and to the city standard specifications for improvements on file with the city engineer and any special notes on the permit; 
(3)  Insure payment to the city for any and all corrective measures necessitated by the work of the permittee as deemed necessary by the city engineer for failure to conform to the provisions of this article. This section shall apply to the full one-year maintenance period after the city's written conditional acceptance of the work; 
(4)  Insure the one-year maintenance bond coverage for all work performed under the period of the bond even after cancellation; 
(5)  Insure any and all provisions of this ordinance, including penalties for work done on public right-of-way without the necessary permits as described herein. The work done without a permit shall be reason for the city to not allow work by such person on public right-of-way for a minimum period of one (1) year. 
(Code 1969, § 42-87; Ord. No. O00-138, § 1, 10-24-00) 
Cross reference- Alternative to bonds, § 2-318. 
Secs. 42-106-42-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BENCHES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 42-121. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to assist the public in the use of the streets by providing, subject to the regulation of the inspections and permits director, benches for the use of the public. Nothing contained in this article shall be construed as permitting the placing of advertising upon any device in the public streets other than the benches as permitted by this article. 
(Code 1969, § 42-105; Ord. No. O86-5565, § 1, 10-7-86) 
Sec. 42-122. - Administration and enforcement. 
    The administration and enforcement of this article is vested in the inspections and permits director. He may make reasonable rules and regulations for the carrying out of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1969, § 42-106; Ord. No. O86-5565, § 1, 10-7-86) 
Sec. 42-123. - Variations. 
    The city council may waive or modify any section of this article, or portion thereof, for the individual case of any particular applicant hereunder. 
(Code 1969, § 42-126; Ord. No. O86-5565, § 1, 10-7-86) 
Sec. 42-124. - Permitted at bus stops. 
    Benches for the convenience and accommodation of pedestrians, persons awaiting bus transportation and others may be installed and maintained on the public property of the city at bus stops only, subject to the provisions of this article. No more than one (1) bench shall be permitted at such location. 
(Code 1969, § 42-107; Ord. No. O86-5565, § 1, 10-7-86) 
Sec. 42-125. - Advertising. 
    Benches installed or maintained under the provisions of this article may be used for advertising purposes. 
(Code 1969, § 42-108; Ord. No. O86-5565, § 1, 10-7-86) 
Sec. 42-126. - Notice of claims. 
    The city shall immediately notify the permittee of any claim filed against it which is alleged to arise from the installation or maintenance of any bench of the permittee. 
(Code 1969, § 42-119; Ord. No. O86-5565, § 1, 10-7-86) 
Sec. 42-127. - List of locations. 
    Each permittee under this article shall maintain in the office of the inspections and permits director a list of all locations where the permittee maintains benches. Such list shall be verified on the oath of the permittee and shall at all times be current to within thirty (30) days. 
(Code 1969, § 42-120; Ord. No. O86-5565, § 1, 10-7-86) 
Sec. 42-128. - Specifications for construction. 
    All benches installed under the provisions of this article shall strictly conform to the following specifications: 
(1)  The bench shall be six (6) feet in length, forty-two (42) inches in height and thirty (30) inches in width, and crushed stone or concrete must be placed in front of benches for solid footing. Such crushed stone or concrete must be at least six (6) feet in length and four and one-half (41/2) feet in width and must provide at least two (2) feet in front of the bench which must be maintained for footing. 
(2)  The benches must be of heavy construction and must weigh not less than four hundred (400) pounds. 
(3)  The end pieces and legs of the bench shall be constructed of concrete. The back rests shall be constructed of hardwood not less than three-fourths inch in thickness, and the seats shall be constructed of hardwood not less than one and three-fourths (13/4) inches in thickness. 
(4)  The several parts of the bench shall be joined by bolts of not less than one-half inch in diameter, and the entire bench must be assembled and installed in a workmanlike manner and reasonably safe for the purpose of which it is intended. 
(5)  The permit number of each bench must be printed on the back of such bench with two-inch lettering. 
(Code 1969, § 42-121; Ord. No. O86-5565, § 1, 10-7-86) 
Sec. 42-129. - Requirements for advertising. 
    Copy, layout and content of all advertising to be placed on benches shall be submitted to the inspections and permits director. No advertising shall be displayed or placed on any bench until written approval has been given by the director. To avoid confusion with traffic-control signs, the colors of red, yellow and orange may not be used. Advertising copy on benches shall not exceed thirty-three (33) percent of the bench facade. No advertising placed on any such bench shall contain animations, figures or faces, but shall contain only lettering. No bench shall carry any immoral picture or profane, vulgar or obscene words. No sign or words which might confuse or distract traffic shall be placed on any bench. No political, or liquor, wine or beer advertisements shall be placed on any bench. 
(Code 1969, § 42-122; Ord. No. O86-5565, § 1, 10-7-86) 
Sec. 42-130. - Maintenance. 
    All wooden surfaces of the benches shall be kept free of splinters and shall be maintained in a smooth, safe, clean, sightly and well-painted condition. The permittee must keep the ground free of paper and debris and cut weeds and grass under and around the bench. 
(Code 1969, § 42-123; Ord. No. O86-5565, § 1, 10-7-86) 
Sec. 42-131. - Inspections. 
    In addition to approval passing upon all permit applications the inspections and permits director shall inspect all benches at least once in each year in order to determine whether the permittee has complied with all the terms and conditions of this article. 
(Code 1969, § 42-124; Ord. No. O86-5565, § 1, 10-7-86) 
Sec. 42-132. - Removal. 
    Upon the revocation of any permit issued under this article or upon the expiration of any permit under this article where the same shall not be renewed, the inspections and permits director shall direct the permittee in writing to remove the bench or benches within five (5) days. Upon failure of the permittee to remove the bench or benches the director shall cause such bench or benches to be removed and charge to the permittee the cost of removal and storage. Upon failure of the permittee to pay such cost within ten (10) days after billing therefor, the director may dispose of such bench or benches as he deems fit. 
(Code 1969, § 42-125; Ord. No. O86-5565, § 1, 10-7-86) 
Secs. 42-133-42-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 42-151. - Required. 
    A permit to install or maintain a bench on public property in the city is required; no person shall install or maintain any bench on public property in the city until such person has obtained a permit. 
(Code 1969, § 42-109; Ord. No. O86-5565, § 1, 10-7-86) 
Sec. 42-152. - Consent of property owners. 
    Before any person shall submit an application for a permit to install or maintain a bench under the provisions of this article, such person must first secure the consent, in writing, of the owners of record of all the property within a radius of one hundred (100) feet from the proposed location of such bench. An affidavit by the applicant shall be attached to such consent stating that the owners of record of all of the property within a radius of one hundred (100) feet of the proposed location of such bench, consent to such bench and such affidavit shall be prima facia evidence of consent. 
(Code 1969, § 42-110; Ord. No. O86-5565, § 1, 10-7-86) 
Sec. 42-153. - Objection by property owners after installation. 
    If at any time after the installation of any bench under the provisions of this article, the owner or owners of record of fifty (50) percent or more of the property within a radius of one hundred (100) feet of such bench shall object to the inspections and permits director in writing to the continued existence of such bench, the director shall forthwith cancel any permit which may have been issued and direct the permittee to remove such bench within five (5) days. 
(Code 1969, § 42-111; Ord. No. O86-5565, § 1, 10-7-86) 
Sec. 42-154. - Application; approval; issuance. 
    Any person desiring a permit under this division shall submit to the inspections and permits director an application in writing upon a form to be provided by the director setting forth the dimensions, construction and intended location of the bench for the installation or maintenance whereof a permit is sought. Such application shall be accompanied by the consent in writing of the owners of record of all of the property within a radius of one hundred (100) feet of the proposed location of such bench, and the affidavit of the applicant. Once the information required in the application process is received by the director, he shall forward it to the city engineer and the superintendent of transportation for review. Once a determination has been made by the above-cited parties as to the application, the application shall be returned to the inspections and permits director for further action. If the inspections and permits director approves the application he shall place his signature thereon and shall issue the permit for the installation of the bench. 
(Code 1969, § 42-112; Ord. No. O86-5565, § 1, 10-7-86) 
Sec. 42-155. - Fee; expiration. 
    Each application for a permit under this division shall be accompanied by a fee in the amount established by ordinance or resolution for each bench. Permits expire annually on June 30 of each year and renewal of applications must be accompanied by a fee in the amount established by ordinance or resolution. 
(Code 1969, § 42-113; Ord. No. O86-5565, § 1, 10-7-86) 
Sec. 42-156. - Renewal. 
    Once a permit for the installation or maintenance of any bench under the provisions of this article has been granted, the permittee may renew his permit at the expiration thereof upon payment of the annual permit and inspection fee to the inspections and permits director before June 30 of each year provided that such permittee and the location and condition of the bench comply with all the terms and conditions of this article. As long as the permittee pays the annual permit fee before June 30 of each year no permit shall be granted to any other person for the same location provided that such permittee and the location and condition of the bench complies with all the terms and conditions of this article. No permit shall be renewed if the bench does not comply with any requirements of this article. 
(Code 1969, § 42-114; Ord. No. O86-5565, § 1, 10-7-86) 
Sec. 42-157. - Bond; insurance. 
    No application for a permit under this division shall be approved by the inspections and permits director unless the applicant shall have filed with the application a surety bond in the penal sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) conditioned upon the applicant agreeing in writing to hold the city harmless from any damage or suit for damages alleged to arise from the installation or maintenance of any bench covered by the application. The applicant shall also file with the application a certificate of public liability insurance showing coverage to the extent of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for death or injury of one (1) person, five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for death or injury to more than one (1) person and twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) for property damage arising from the installation or maintenance of the applicant's bench. Such bond and certificate shall be in a form acceptable to the corporation counsel. 
(Code 1969, § 42-117; Ord. No. O86-5565, § 1, 10-7-86) 
Cross reference- Alternative to bonds, § 2-318. 
Sec. 42-158. - Denial. 
    The inspections and permits director shall not approve an application for a permit to install or maintain any bench and no permit shall be issued for the installation or maintenance of any bench under the provisions of this article under any of the following circumstances: 
(1)  If the application for a permit is not accompanied by the consent in writing of all of the owners of record of the property within a radius of one hundred (100) feet from the proposed location of such bench and/or the affidavit of the applicant. 
(2)  If the application for a permit for the installation or maintenance of any bench is for a proposed location other than a bus stop as determined by the superintendent of transportation. 
(3)  If the installation or maintenance of a bench at the proposed location would tend to obstruct traffic along a public way or to create a hazard to persons or property as determined by the city engineer. 
(4)  If the installation or maintenance of such benches at the proposed location would not promote the convenience of the traveling public as determined by the city engineer. 
(5)  If the distance from the face of the curb to the property line at the proposed location of the bench is less than eight (8) feet. 
(Code 1969, § 42-115; Ord. No. O86-5565, § 1, 10-7-86) 
Sec. 42-159. - Revocation. 
    If after the issuance of a permit the inspections and permits director finds that the continued maintenance of the bench would tend to obstruct passage along a public way, or to create a hazard to persons or property, or if the owners of record of fifty (50) percent or more of the property within a radius of one hundred (100) feet of the location of such bench object to the continued maintenance of such bench, or if the director finds that the bench is not being maintained in a reasonably safe condition, or that the permittee is violating any of the provisions of this article, the director shall in writing revoke the permit for such bench and order the permittee to remove the same within five (5) days. 
(Code 1969, § 42-116; Ord. No. O86-5565, § 1, 10-7-86) 
Sec. 42-160. - Failure to install bench. 
    If a permittee fails to install a bench for the use of the public at any location within forty-five (45) days of the issuance of a permit therefor, the inspections and permits director shall revoke the permit. 
(Code 1969, § 42-118; Ord. No. O86-5565, § 1, 10-7-86) 
Secs. 42-161-42-175. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - AWNINGS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 12. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 42-176. - Compliance with building code. 
    The construction, erection and placing of awnings or other like structures shall be governed by and conform to the regulations incorporated in the building code of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 42-143) 
Cross reference- Building code, § 12-16 et seq. 
Secs. 42-177-42-190. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 42-191. - Required. 
    No person shall use any public street, alley, sidewalk or thoroughfare within the city for the purpose of erecting, repairing or adjusting any awning or other like structure overhanging or to overhang any sidewalk, street, alley or public thoroughfare without first obtaining a license therefor. 
(Code 1969, § 42-136) 
Sec. 42-192. - Application; fee; issuance. 
    The awning license fee shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per annum. Application for such license shall be made to the city treasurer who shall, upon performance of all conditions prerequisite to the issuance of the license, issue the same. The license shall be attested by the city treasurer under the seal of the city. Written application forms for such license shall be furnished by the city treasurer upon request, and shall contain the following: 
(1)  The date of the application; 
(2)  The name of the applicant, and if a corporation, the name of the president, secretary and treasurer thereof; 
(3)  The residence address of the applicant or applicants, if a person or partnership; 
(4)  The business address of the applicant. 
(Code 1969, § 42-137) 
Sec. 42-193. - Transfer; revocation; expiration. 
    An awning license shall not be transferable. The city treasurer shall have the power to revoke any such license granted for violation by the licensee or his agents, of any of the provisions of this article. A license shall be dated as of January 1 of the year of issuance and shall expire December 31 of that year. 
(Code 1969, § 42-138) 
Sec. 42-194. - Insurance required. 
    No awning license shall be issued to any person under this article until the applicant files with the city treasurer a certificate of general public liability insurance, in a minimum amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for death or bodily injury or injury to property. 
(Code 1969, § 42-139) 
Secs. 42-195-42-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - VENDING DEVICES 

Sec. 42-211. - Location, advertising, maintenance; removal. 
(a)  Location restrictions. No vending device shall be placed, installed, used or maintained: 
(1)  So close to the curbline of any street as to interfere with the opening of the doors of legally parked motor vehicles; 
(2)  Within fifteen (15) feet of any "no parking any time" zone immediately adjacent to any intersection; 
(3)  Within thirty (30) feet of any intersection where no-parking zones are not designated; 
(4)  Within fifteen (15) feet of any fire hydrant; 
(5)  Within five (5) feet of any fire or police call box or fire alarm; 
(6)  Within three (3) feet ahead or fifteen (15) feet to the rear of any designated bus stop or place marked for handicapped parking; 
(7)  At any location whereby the clearance space for the passage of pedestrians is reduced to six (6) feet or less. 
(b)  Devices to be secure. All devices shall be securely affixed so as to be immovable but no vending device shall be chained to any municipal fixture unless the chain is coated with plastic or rubber or a similar nonabrasive material. 
(c)  Advertising. No vending device shall be used to advertise or publicize anything other than the goods or products offered for sale in it. 
(d)  Maintenance. All vending devices shall be kept in good repair with all parts intact and in an operable condition. Good repair shall include, but is not limited to, absence of broken glass or cut plastic; bent metal protruding from the device, especially sharp-edged metal; large or multiple dents in the metal. 
(e)  Temporary removal upon city's request. Upon request by the city, any distributor must temporarily remove any of its vending devices when such is necessary for efficient repair or replacement operations on municipal property. 
(Code 1969, § 42-170) 
Sec. 42-212. - Violations; remedial action. 
(a)  The corporation counsel will determine whether a violation of this article exists. If the corporation counsel so determines, notice to the distributor of the goods or products disseminated by the device shall be given, both allowing ten (10) days after receipt of the notice to correct such violation and informing the distributor of the evidence against the distributor. 
(b)  Within that same ten-day period, the distributor may examine the evidence upon which the corporation counsel relied, show the corporation counsel why no violation exists, and may cross-examine any witnesses supplying evidence to the city and against the distributor. The corporation counsel shall then review all the evidence, notify the distributor of his decision, and, if that decision is against the distributor, afford an additional ten (10) days after receipt of the decision by the distributor to correct the violation. 
(c)  The distributor may appeal to a board of review consisting of the inspections and permits director, the superintendent of streets and the mayor. Notice of appeal must be transmitted to the corporation counsel within fourteen (14) days from receipt of notice of the decision appealed from. The hearing by the board shall be had within seven (7) days of receipt of the notice of appeal by the corporation counsel. A record of the proceedings shall be kept. 
(d)  At the hearing the distributor may offer evidence of its own, examine the city's evidence, and cross-examine any city witnesses. If the board finds for the distributor, no further action may be taken by the city. However, if the board affirms the decision of the corporation counsel, the distributor shall have three (3) days to correct the violation. 
(e)  If the violation is not so corrected, the device may be removed and the city may assess the distributor storage costs of one dollar ($1.00) per day. After ninety (90) days the removed device shall be treated as abandoned property. 
(f)  All notices provided for in this section shall be registered or certified mail, return receipt requested. 
(Code 1969, § 42-171) 
Secs. 42-213-42-230. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - WATER STREET MALL 

Sec. 42-231. - Hours. 
    The Water Street Mall, as bounded by Galena Boulevard on the north and Downer Place on the south, shall be closed to the public from 10:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. daily. 
(Code 1969, § 42-180) 
Sec. 42-232. - Use of mall.
