Sec. 44-400. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the definitions found in the Illinois Food Handling Regulation Enforcement Act at 410 ILCS 625 et seq. are hereby adopted by reference as if fully set forth herein. 
(Ord. No.O17-001, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 44-401. - Home kitchen and cottage food operations. 
(a)  Subject to all applicable city ordinances, including, without limitation, land use and zoning regulations and privilege taxes, the statutory provisions contained within the Illinois Food Handling Regulation Enforcement Act regarding home kitchen and cottage food operations, as now or hereafter amended [410 ILCS 625 et seq.] are hereby adopted by reference as if fully set forth herein. 
(b)  In the event of a conflict between the provisions of this article, other applicable city ordinances and the statutory provisions in the Illinois Food Handling Regulation Enforcement Act, any and all applicable city ordinances shall control. 
(c)  The direct sale of baked goods as described in the Illinois Food Handling Regulation Enforcement Act is hereby authorized. 
(Ord. No.O17-001, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Chapter 45 - PUBLIC PASSENGER TRANSPORTATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. O93-06, adopted Jan. 5, 1993, repealed former Ch. 45 an enacted a new Ch. 45 in lieu thereof, as set out herein. The repealed provisions pertained to taxicabs and public passenger vehicles and derived from Code 1969, §§ 45-1-45-4, 45-15-45-25, 45-27, 45-28, 45-30, 45-33-45-39, 45-41-45-44, 45-55-45-62, 45-64-45-69, 45-80, 45-81, 45-87-45-89, 45-91-45-100, and Ord. No. O88-71, adopted June 21, 1988. 
Cross reference- Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 25; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 27; bus franchise required, § 29-112. 

ARTICLE I. - MOTORIZED PUBLIC PASSENGER VEHICLES 

Sec. 45-1. - Intent and purpose. 
    This chapter is adopted for the following purposes: 
(1)  To encourage the best possible public passenger vehicle service under a competitive system with regulation to the extent necessary to protect the safety and welfare of the citizens. 
(2)  To assure that any and all legitimate, locally based public passenger vehicle businesses are allowed to operate as many vehicles as are economically feasible by placing no limit on the number of vehicles operated by each business, until such time as the city deems necessary. 
(3)  To assure that public passenger vehicles licensed by the city are clean, comfortable and safe. 
(4)  To assure that public passenger vehicle operations are reputable, capable and safe. 
(5)  To assure that only bona fide public passenger vehicles licensed by the city are permitted to offer their services on the streets, at taxicab stands, at residences, and at places of business in the city. 
(Ord. No. O08-82, § 1, 8-26-08) 
Sec. 45-1.5. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article the following words and phrases shall have the meaning respectively ascribed to them by this section. 
    Inspection station. Official State of Illinois testing station, or other facility designated by the license administrator to conduct inspections required by this article. 
    License administrator. The license administrator for the city or his designee. 
    Licensee. Licensee shall mean any person who is the owner of one or more licenses issued pursuant to this article. 
    Livery vehicle. Any motor-propelled vehicle, not equipped with a taximeter, and transporting passengers for hire, as a result of individual contract, on a trip or hourly basis fixed in advance. 
    Operate. The use of a public passenger vehicle for hire. Such use can be pursuant to employment, contract, lease, rental or other agreements. 
    Person. Any natural person, corporation, partnership, unincorporated association or other legal entity. This includes, but is not limited to, contractors, subcontractors, lessees or other similar agents of any such entity. 
    Public passenger vehicles. Taxicabs and livery vehicles used for transportation of passengers for hire. 
    Public passenger vehicle chauffeur. Any person who drives a public passenger vehicle in use for the transportation of persons for compensation. 
    Public passenger vehicle company. Any person, partnership or corporation engaged in business as proprietor of one (1) or more public passenger vehicles for transportation of passengers for hire. 
    Public passenger vehicle owner. Any person owning or leasing from another a public passenger vehicle for hire. 
    Taxicab. Any motor-propelled vehicle equipped with a taximeter and operated for transportation of passengers for hire, available indiscriminately to all persons as may offer themselves for transportation. 
    Taxicab stand. Any places, public or private, where taxicabs are placed on display and presented for hire to prospective customers, accepting such persons as may offer themselves for transportation. Examples of locations for taxicabs stands are: railroad stations, hotels, motels, bowling alleys, theaters, race tracks, and any prominent gathering place. 
    Taximeter. Any mechanical or electronic device attached to a taxicab which records indicates a charge or fare in dollars and cents measured by distance and waiting time. 
    Waiting time. The time when the taxicab is not in motion at more than ten (10) miles per hour, beginning with the arrival at the place to which it has been called, or the time consumed while standing at the direction of the passenger, but no charge shall be made for the time lost on account of inefficiency of the taxicab, or its operator, or time consumed by a premature response to a call. 
(Ord. No. O93-06, § 1, 1-5-93; Ord. No. O94-30, § 1, 4-19-94; Ord. No. O96-16, § 1, 2-27-96; Ord. No. O08-82, § 1, 8-26-08) 
Sec. 45-2. - Business license. 
(a)  Required. No public passenger vehicle company shall maintain a place of business, including a dispatch office, in the city without first having obtained a business license. 
(b)  Application. The business license application, accompanied by a nonrefundable fee to be determined from time to time by separate ordinance or resolution of the city council shall be accompanied by a letter providing all of the following additional information for the business as well as for each driver associated with the business. 
(1)  The name, age and address of the applicant in the case of an individual; in the case of a partnership, the persons entitled to share in the profits thereof; and in the case of a corporation, for profit, or a club, the state and date of incorporation, the objects for which it was organized, names and addresses of the officers and directors, and shareholders, and the percentage of ownership of each. Corporations whose stock is traded publicly and listed on recognized stock exchanges shall be required to identify only a holder of a majority of the outstanding shares of the corporation. 
(2)  The citizenship of the applicant, if a natural person; the place of applicant's birth; and, if a naturalized citizen, the time and place of naturalization. 
(3)  Current occupation/employment, business address and telephone number. 
(4)  Employment history for the past ten (10) years immediately preceding application. 
(5)  Current financial status, including any unpaid judgments and pertinent information relative to any such judgments. 
(6)  Any previous convictions of felony and/or traffic violations, as well as an affidavit stating the applicant has not been convicted of any offense involving a battery, sex, narcotics, the use of a deadly weapon, and not, within the last five (5) years, been convicted of operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol or drugs. 
(7)  Previous residences for past five (5) years. 
(8)  The number of vehicles to be operated or controlled by the applicant and the location of proposed depots and terminals. 
(9)  The color scheme or insignia to be used to designate the vehicle or vehicles of the applicant, which color scheme and insignia shall be readily distinguishable from that of emergency vehicles and vehicles of previously licensed public passenger vehicle companies. 
(10)  Previous military history (if any) and type of discharge. 
(11)  Social Security number. 
(12)  An affidavit stating the applicant is in good physical condition and shall not have any nervous, organic, or functional condition or disease which is likely to interfere with the safe performance of his or her duties as a driver. 
(13)  Such additional information as may be required by the license administrator. 
(c)  Insurance. Applicants for a license or renewal of a license to operate a public passenger vehicle company in the municipality shall produce: 
(1)  A certificate from the Secretary of State showing compliance by the owner for each public passenger vehicle with the provisions of the statutes of the state relating to the bonding or insurance of motor vehicles used for carriage of passengers for hire; and 
(2)  A policy of insurance or certificate of insurance showing that there is in full force and effect a policy of insurance including coverage for personal injuries in the amount of not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) one (1) person, three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) one (1) accident and not less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for property damage, which shall provide that the coverage may not be cancelled or shall provide that the coverage may not be cancelled or materially changed without thirty (30) days' prior written notice to the license administrator. 
If any insurance is cancelled or permitted to lapse for any reason, the license administrator shall suspend the licenses for the vehicles affected for a period of not to exceed thirty (30) days, to permit other insurance to be supplied in compliance with the provisions of this section. If such other insurance is not supplied within the period of suspension of the license, the license administrator shall revoke the license for such vehicles. 
(d)  Issuance. If the license administrator finds that the applicant conforms to the provisions of this article, and the application and background investigation reveal nothing of a nature that might endanger the health, safety and welfare of the general public as a result of the applicant's possession of a license, then the license administrator shall issue a business license upon receipt of an amount to be determined, from time to time, by separate ordinance or resolution of the city council. No license shall be issued to any applicant who is indebted to the city in any amount for any reason, and/or who is not in compliance with all ordinances of the city, including those pertaining to traffic violations. 
(e)  Nontransferable. No business license may be sold, assigned, mortgaged, pledged, or otherwise transferred. 
(f)  Renewal. The business license may be renewed annually upon payment of an annual fee, to be determined from time to time by separate ordinance or resolution of the city council, as well as continued compliance with the requirements of this article. 
(g)  Suspension or revocation. The business license may be suspended or revoked by the license administrator and/or a fine imposed, if the licensee has: 
(1)  Failed to keep in force the insurance required by this section; 
(2)  Discontinued operations in the city for more than thirty (30) days; or 
(3)  Violated any ordinances of the city or the laws of the United States of America or the State of Illinois, related to the fitness of the licensee to offer public transportation. 
At least twenty (20) days prior to any suspension, revocation, and/or fine, the licensee shall be given written notice of the proposed action, and shall have an opportunity to be heard by the license administrator during such period. If a hearing is held before said official a verbatim transcript shall be made and a decision rendered within five (5) business days of such hearing. 
(h)  Change of stock ownership. 
(1)  A corporation holding a public passenger business license shall advise the license administrator thirty (30) days prior to any contemplated change of stock ownership involving five (5) percent or more of the stock of the corporation. 
(2)  Each individual seeking to acquire five (5) percent or more of the stock of a corporation holding a public passenger vehicle license shall comply with the provisions of this section as though he were applying for a license as an individual. 
(3)  The provisions of this subsection do not apply to corporations whose stock is traded publicly and listed on recognized stock exchanges. 
(Ord. No. O93-06, § 1, 1-5-93; Ord. No. O94-30, § 1, 4-19-94; Ord. No. O08-82, § 1, 8-26-08) 
Sec. 45-3. - Operation of business. 
(a)  Regular telephone service required. Every public passenger vehicle business licensee shall keep in service at all times while his license is in effect regular telephone service within the city, by means of which a person desiring to hire a public passenger vehicle may call the licensee. The licensee shall cause the telephone number to be listed in the local and regional telephone directories which are published for the municipality by the telephone company which furnishes local telephone service in the municipality. 
(b)  Public passenger service. Every public passenger vehicle business licensee shall operate every public passenger vehicle regularly in the city to the extent reasonably necessary to meet the public demands for passenger service. They shall maintain in the city a central place of business for the purpose of receiving calls and dispatching vehicles. They shall answer all calls received by them for service inside the corporate limits of the municipality as soon as they can do so and if the service cannot be rendered within a reasonable time they shall notify the prospective passengers how long it will be before the call can be answered and give the reason therefor. Any licensee who shall refuse to accept a call anywhere within the corporate limits of the municipality at any time when such licensee has available vehicles, or who shall fail or refuse to give overall service, shall be deemed in violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. O93-06, § 1, 1-5-93; Ord. No. O94-30, § 1, 4-19-94) 
Sec. 45-4. - Public passenger vehicle license. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful to operate a public passenger vehicle for hire within the corporate limits of the city unless the vehicle is licensed and operated in accordance with the provisions of this article or the vehicle holds a current license issued by a local licensing authority whose licensing standards are comparable to those contained herein. Comparability shall be determined by the license administrator. 
(b)  Applications. Applications for public passenger vehicle licenses shall be made by the owner upon forms furnished by the city. Such applications shall contain the full name and address of the owner of the vehicle, and in the case of a corporation or partnership, the names and addresses of the officers or partners; a complete description of the vehicle, including make and model, vehicle identification number, manufacturer's identification number, seating capacity (excluding driver's seat or any part thereof), state license number, color of vehicle, vehicle engine horsepower and such other data as the city may require to assure compliance with the requirements of this article, including all information required in subsection 45-2(b) above. 
(c)  Insurance. The application for a public passenger vehicle license shall be accompanied by evidence of the liability insurance required in subsection 45-2(c). 
(d)  Inspection. The vehicle for which a license application is made shall be inspected as provided in section 45-6. An inspection fee, to be determined, from time to time, by separate ordinance or resolution of the city council, per vehicle shall be paid at the time of inspection. 
(e)  Fee. The annual fee for a public passenger vehicle license shall be determined, from time to time, by separate ordinance or resolution of the city council, which fee shall be in addition to all other state and city vehicle fees. The initial license shall expire on December 31 following the date of issuance. 
(f)  Issuance. The license administrator shall issue a public passenger vehicle license has passed the inspection and the license fee has been paid. No license shall be issued to any applicant who is not first in compliance with all ordinances of the city, including those pertaining to traffic violations. 
(g)  Display required. The numbered vehicle license decal shall be affixed to the certified inspection plate, which shall be visibly displayed in the lower left hand corner of the rear window of the public passenger vehicle. 
(h)  Nontransferable. It shall be unlawful to transfer any public passenger vehicle license from one vehicle to another except when permanently replacing one vehicle for a newer vehicle within a taxicab company's fleet, and then only with the permission of the license administrator. Transferring any public passenger vehicle license shall be grounds for revocations of all licenses issued pursuant to this article (business license, vehicle licenses and chauffeur licenses) to both the owner of the license and the vehicle to which the license is transferred. 
(Ord. No. O93-06, § 1, 1-5-93; Ord. No. O94-30, § 1, 4-19-94; Ord. No. O08-82, § 1, 8-26-08) 
Sec. 45-5. - Register of licenses. 
    The license administrator shall keep a register of the names of persons to whom licenses are granted, the date issued, the number of the licenses and the description of the vehicles licensed. 
(Ord. No. O93-06, § 1, 1-5-93; Ord. No. O94-30, § 1, 4-19-94) 
Sec. 45-6. - Inspections. 
(a)  The license administrator will cause inspection of all licensed public passenger vehicles to be done no less than one (1) time a year, and upon complaint received by the license administrator, beginning annually June 1, 2008. 
(b)  After receiving notice from the license administrator, a public passenger vehicle company will be allowed seven (7) days to take their licensed public passenger vehicles to an inspection station for inspection. The license of all public passenger vehicles not inspected within that period will be suspended by direction of the license administrator. 
(c)  Such inspection will include, but need not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Vehicle, make, year and vehicle identification number. 
(2)  State license number and year. 
(3)  City vehicle license number and year. 
(4)  Vehicle color. 
(5)  Vehicle number. 
(6)  Company name. 
(7)  Service brakes (livery vehicle inspections to be made in accordance with applicable state law). 
(8)  Emergency brakes (livery vehicle inspections to be made in accordance with applicable state law). 
(9)  Horn (livery vehicle inspections to be made in accordance with applicable state law). 
(10)  Rear view mirror (livery vehicle inspections to be made in accordance with applicable state law). 
(11)  Windshield wipers and washers (livery vehicle inspections to be made in accordance with applicable state law). 
(12)  Headlights (livery vehicle inspections to be made in accordance with applicable state law). 
(13)  Tail lights (livery vehicle inspections to be made in accordance with applicable state law). 
(14)  Stop lights (livery vehicle inspections to be made in accordance with applicable state law). 
(15)  Turn signals (livery vehicle inspections to be made in accordance with applicable state law). 
(16)  Speedometer (livery vehicle inspections to be made in accordance with applicable state law). 
(17)  Rates displayed. 
(18)  Steering (livery vehicle inspections to be made in accordance with applicable state law). 
(19)  Interior condition. 
(20)  Exterior condition. 
(21)  Windows. 
(22)  Tires (livery vehicle inspections to be made in accordance with applicable state law). 
(23)  Current bond sticker. 
(d)  Any public passenger vehicle failing to pass the inspection will be given a period of five (5) working days to allow for repairs. The vehicle cannot be used as a public passenger vehicle for hire until repairs have been completed and it passes reinspection. If the public passenger vehicle does not pass reinspection within the five-working day period, the public passenger vehicle license will be suspended by direction of the license administrator. 
(e)  The license administrator shall prescribe reasonable standards which public passenger vehicles must satisfy to pass the inspections required prior to licensing and periodically thereafter, which standards shall be designed to assure that public passenger vehicles licensed by the city are mechanically dependable, safe, clean and satisfy the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. O93-06, § 1, 1-5-93; Ord. No. O94-30, § 1, 4-19-94; Ord. No. O08-82, § 1, 8-26-08) 
Sec. 45-7. - Inspection stations. 
(a)  The license administrator shall designate those facilities which may serve as inspection stations to conduct the vehicle inspections required by this article, which stations may be within or without the city. Such stations may include those which inspect livery vehicles pursuant to state law. He shall establish procedures for conducting the inspections and minimum standards in order that a vehicle be approved. He shall supply inspection stations with certified inspection forms, numbered certified vehicle inspection stickers and such other supplies as may be required to perform the duties required by this article and the regulations established hereunder. 
(b)  A list of authorized inspection stations shall be kept by the license administrator and shall be given to each public passenger vehicle owner together with the notice that vehicles must be inspected. An owner may use the authorized inspection station of his choice. 
(c)  Inspection stations shall charge the inspection fee authorized by the license administrator for all public passenger vehicle inspections. 
(d)  The license administrator shall cause unannounced spot checks of authorized inspection stations to assure compliance with the inspection procedures, standards and fees, and shall investigate all complaints of misconduct by inspection stations or their employees. Noncompliance with the requirements of this article or the regulations established hereunder by the license administrator shall be cause for suspension or revocation of the designation as an authorized inspection station. 
(Ord. No. O93-06, § 1, 1-5-93; Ord. No. O94-30, § 1, 4-19-94) 
Sec. 45-8. - Miscellaneous vehicle regulations. 
(a)  Every licensed taxicab shall bear on both sides of the vehicle, in lettering contrasting with the color of the vehicle and not less than two (2) inches in height, the name of the cab company and its telephone number. 
(b)  The identification number assigned to such vehicle by the taxicab company shall appear on both exterior sides of the vehicle in Arabic numerals a minimum of three (3) inches in height and in a conspicuous location within the passenger compartment, in numerals four (4) inches in height. 
(c)  No taxicab shall be painted or labeled so as to be so similar to the vehicles of any other person licensed and engaged in the business of operating taxicabs in the city so as to be an imitation thereof and calculated to deceive the patrons of taxicabs into believing that such vehicles are in reality the taxicabs of such other person. 
(d)  If after the inspection and approval of any public passenger vehicle, as provided for in this article, such public passenger vehicle shall from any cause become unsafe for the transportation of passengers or shall become unclean or unsightly in appearance, the license of such public passenger vehicle shall be suspended by the license administrator until the public passenger vehicle and all its accessories shall be put in fit condition for public use and have been approved and inspected as provided in this article. 
[(e)  Reserved.] 
(f)  Effective June 1, 2008, any vehicle that has more than one hundred fifty thousand (150,000) miles shall not be placed into service for first time use as a public passenger vehicle. 
(g)  Effective June 1, 2008, no public passenger vehicle shall be licensed or used if it is older than ten (10) years from the model year. Any public passenger vehicle not complying with the ten-year limitation imposed by this section on its effective date may be used for not more than two (2) more years, and on the two-year effective date of this section, any such nonconforming vehicle shall no longer be licensed or used. 
(Ord. No. O93-06, § 1, 1-5-93; Ord. No. O94-30, § 1, 4-19-94; Ord. No. O08-82, § 1, 8-26-08) 
Sec. 45-9. - Chauffeur license. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any public passenger vehicle for hire within the city without first having obtained a valid public passenger vehicle chauffeur's license or a sixty-day temporary license. 
(b)  Owner responsibility. It shall be unlawful for any person owning or controlling any public passenger vehicle to employ or permit any person to operate such vehicle for hire within the city unless such driver has a valid public passenger vehicle chauffeur's license issued by the city or a sixty-day temporary license. 
(c)  Application. The application for a license as a public passenger vehicle chauffeur shall contain the name of the applicant; his residence and employment history; number and current status of his Illinois driver's license; whether his state driver's license has ever been suspended or revoked and if so, when and for what cause; a list of all convictions, if any, for violation of federal, state or municipal laws including all information required in subsection 45-2(b) above; and two (2) personal references, each unrelated to the applicant. 
(d)  Qualifications. 
(1)  Every applicant for a public passenger vehicle chauffeur's license shall be no less than eighteen (18) years of age. 
(2)  The applicant must pass a physical examination by a licensed physician, at his own expense, subject to the examination conditions on the form provided by the city. Such certificate sets forth the opinion of the examining physician that the applicant is physically able to engage in the driving of public passenger vehicles without risk to the public. 
(3)  The applicant must be the holder of a valid State of Illinois driver's license. 
(4)  The applicant must not have been convicted of any felony or any other crime involving deception or bodily harm or operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of drugs or alcohol within the past five (5) years. 
(5)  The applicant must not have had his driver's license suspended or revoked in any state within the past three (3) years as a consequence of violations of law concerning his operation of a motor vehicle nor may the applicant have been convicted of more than two (2) moving violations within the twelve-month period immediately preceding application. 
(e)  Investigation. Upon filing of such application and applicant's payment of a fee, to be determined, from time to time, by separate ordinance or resolution of the city council, the chief of police shall make or cause to be made a careful and diligent investigation, including photographing and fingerprinting of the applicant. The report of such investigation and a copy of the traffic and police record of the applicant, if any, shall be considered in evaluating the application. Any applicant who fails to report to the city police department for processing within fourteen (14) days of the date of application shall be deemed to have withdrawn his application. 
(f)  Issuance. If the license administrator shall be satisfied that the applicant satisfies the requirements set forth in subsection (d) above, and is a fit person to be licensed, such application shall be approved and the license issued. During the investigation provided for by subsection (e) herein, a sixty-day temporary license may be issued to any applicant whose driver's license status and lack of any outstanding criminal violations (including traffic violations) has been verified by the city police department. No license shall be issued to any applicant who is not first in compliance with all ordinances of the city, including those pertaining to traffic violations. Any applicant who fails to pick up his license within thirty (30) days after notice of application approval shall be deemed to have withdrawn his application. An applicant whose license application has been denied may not reapply for a chauffeur's license for a period of twelve (12) months following the date of denial. 
(g)  Fees. The annual fee for a public passenger vehicle chauffeur's license shall be determined, from time to time, by separate ordinance or resolution of the city council. The initial license shall be issued without payment of a fee other than the application fee and shall expire on December 31 following the date of issuance. Licenses may be renewed for successive calendar years upon continuing satisfaction of standards for issuance. 
(h)  Display. The chauffeur's license shall be displayed at all times in the public passenger vehicle in plain view of the passenger. 
(i)  Nontransferable. It shall be unlawful to transfer any public passenger vehicle chauffeur's license from one person to another. Transference of such license shall be grounds for revocation. 
(j)  Suspension or revocation. The license administrator, in his discretion, may suspend a public passenger vehicle chauffeur's license for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days, for any failure or refusal to comply with the provisions of this article; for any violation of federal, state or municipal law; upon a determination that said license was obtained fraudulently, that the licensee has become physically, mentally or emotionally unfit to perform his duties as a public passenger vehicle operator, or that there has been any fraudulent use of the public passenger vehicle chauffeur's license by or with the consent of the licensee. 
(Ord. No. O93-06, § 1, 1-5-93; Ord. No. O94-30, § 1, 4-19-94; Ord. No. O96-16, § 1, 2-27-96; Ord. No. O08-82, § 1, 8-26-08) 
Sec. 45-10. - Public passenger vehicle operation. 
(a)  Number of passengers. No operator of a public passenger vehicle shall carry more than the rated passenger load per vehicle. 
(b)  Additional passengers after engagement. No additional passengers shall be transported after a public passenger vehicle has been hired by one (1) or more persons without the express permission of the person or persons first engaging the public passenger vehicle. An appropriate sign shall be posted indicating the restrictions on shared rides. 
(c)  Soliciting. No driver of a public passenger vehicle shall seek employment by repeatedly or persistently driving his vehicle to and fro in a short space before any theater, hotel, railway station or other public place or by otherwise interfering with the proper and orderly access to or egress from any such place. 
(d)  Right of operator to demand fare in advance; refusal to convey passengers. The operator or person in charge or control of any taxicab may demand, in advance, the payment of the estimated fare of the person desiring to be carried by such taxicab, and may refuse to convey any person who shall not comply with the demand; but no driver or operator of a taxicab shall otherwise refuse or neglect to convey any orderly person, upon request, anywhere in the city, unless previously engaged or unable to do so. 
(e)  Advertising. Advertising is restricted to that which may be displayed on a light mounted on the top of the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. O93-06, § 1, 1-5-93) 
Sec. 45-11. - Operation of livery vehicles. 
(a)  Livery vehicles shall not pick up or solicit passengers for hire from the streets. 
(b)  Livery vehicles shall not park in taxicab stands. 
(c)  Livery vehicles shall not indiscriminately accept passengers, but shall be limited in scope of operation to carrying passengers for hire on a contract basis at a price agreed upon prior to employment and by arrangement of the parties at the time of initial telephone contact by customer to the livery company. No livery shall be dispatched without a price having been established in advance. 
(d)  No livery vehicle shall be dispatched from a location using the same telephone number as that used for taxicab operations nor shall taxicab operations and livery operations advertise using a single phone number for combined operations. 
(Ord. No. O93-06, § 1, 1-5-93) 
Sec. 45-12. - Schedule of rates and charges. 
    The price or rates of fare to be asked or demanded by the operator or owner of any taxicab shall be determined from time to time, by separate ordinance or resolution of the city council. Flat rates to destinations outside the corporate limits of the city are permissible so long as the passenger agrees to the amount prior to the start of the trip and the operator follows section 45-13 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. O93-06, § 1, 1-5-93; Ord. No. O04-90, § 1, 9-28-04) 
Sec. 45-13. - Posting established rates. 
    There shall be affixed inside each taxicab in a place conspicuous to any person riding in such taxicab, in a frame covered by glass or other transparent material the following items: (1) a rate card issued by the city, upon which card shall be printed in plain, legible type the rates of fare as prescribed by this section and a statement that flat rates are permissible for trips outside the corporate limits of the city so long as the passenger agrees to the rate prior to the start of the trip, and (2) a sheet of paper upon which shall be printed in plain, legible type all flat rate charges for trips to Chicago-area airports. 
(Ord. No. O93-06, § 1, 1-5-93; Ord. No. O04-90, § 2, 9-28-04) 
Sec. 45-14. - Taximeters. 
(a)  Accuracy. No taxicab shall operate with passengers for hire unless the taximeter shall be accurately recording the fare to be charged, except for flat rates as set forth in sections 45-12 and 45-13 of this Code. 
(b)  Position. A taximeter shall be located so that its face can be seen by a passenger from the rear compartment of the vehicle. 
(c)  Illumination. Adequate lighting facilities shall be provided for illuminating the face of the taximeter so that it may be conveniently read by the passenger whenever the taximeter is in operation. 
(d)  Flags. Taximeters shall be equipped with a flag at least three (3) inches by two (2) inches in size, either painted red or bearing letters at least one inch in height, the word "Vacant" or the words "For Hire." The flag post of such flag shall be kept towards a vertical position when the taxicab is for hire and such flag post shall be immediately pulled down and kept in a horizontal position when such taxicab is engaged. 
(e)  Transfer. No person controlling or operating any taxicab shall transfer any taximeter to any other taxicab unless a new inspection and certification of such taximeter is made. 
(f)  Tampering. No person shall tamper with, break or mutilate any taximeter, cable or seal thereof. 
(Ord. No. O93-06, § 1, 1-5-93; Ord. No. O94-30, § 1, 4-19-94; Ord. No. O04-90, § 3, 9-28-04) 
ARTICLE II. - HORSE-DRAWN CARRIAGES 

Sec. 45-15. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Carriage license. An annual nontransferable license for one horse-drawn carriage to operate in the downtown. 
    Carriage driver permit. An annual nontransferable permit issued for one (1) driver to operate a horse-drawn carriage in the downtown. 
    Horse-drawn carriage. A four-wheeled passenger vehicle, horse-drawn, used for public passenger touring of a fixed route at a fixed fee, operated by a carriage driver with a valid permit, and used only for sightseeing and tour rides. 
    License administrator. The finance director for the City of Aurora or his designee. 
    Licensee. Licensee shall mean any person who is the owner of one (1) or more licenses or permits issued pursuant to this article. 
    Person. Any natural person, corporation, partnership, unincorporated association or other legal entity. 
    Special event license. A nontransferable license to operate a horse-drawn carriage in the city for a special event only. 
(Ord. No. O94-30, § 1, 4-19-94) 
Sec. 45-16. - License(s) required. 
    No horse-drawn carriage shall be operated within the city without the license(s) required in this article, as follows: 
(1)  Carriage license. It shall be unlawful to operate a horse-drawn carriage within the downtown unless the carriage is licensed and operated in accordance with the provisions of this article. Applications for horse-drawn carriage licenses shall be made by the owner upon forms furnished by the city. Such application must contain all of the information indicated on the form. The annual fee for a carriage license shall be as determined from time to time by separate resolution of the city council. The license administrator shall issue a carriage license, to the applicant who conforms to the provisions of this article and whose application reveals nothing of a nature that might endanger the health, safety and welfare of the general public as a result of the applicants' possession of a license. No license shall be issued to any applicant who is not first in compliance with all ordinances of the City of Aurora, including those pertaining to traffic violations. The numbered carriage license shall be displayed at all times on the carriage in plain view of the passenger. 
(2)  Carriage driver permit. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a horse-drawn carriage within the city without first having obtained a carriage drivers permit. Application for a carriage drivers permit shall be made by the carriage driver upon a form furnished by the city. Such application must contain all of the information indicated on the form, all applicants must possess a valid Illinois Drivers License and must demonstrate the ability to effectively operate a carriage in the downtown to the satisfaction of the license administrator. The annual fee for a carriage drivers permit shall be as determined from time to time by separate resolution of the city council. The license administrator shall issue a carriage drivers permit to the applicant who conforms to the provisions of this article and whose application reveals nothing of a nature that might endanger the health, safety and welfare of the general public as a result of the applicants' possession of a permit. No permit shall be issued to any applicant who is not first in compliance with all ordinances of the City of Aurora, including those pertaining to traffic violations. The carriage drivers permit shall be displayed at all times in the carriage on the person of the carriage driver in plain view of the passenger. It shall be unlawful to transfer any carriage drivers permit from one (1) driver to another. 
(3)  Special event license. It shall be unlawful to operate a horse-drawn carriage in the city for any special event unless a special event license has been approved by the license administrator. Said special event license shall be valid only for the specified special event. The streets to be used in the operation of any horse-drawn carriage for a special event must be approved in writing by the city traffic engineer. 
(Ord. No. O94-30, § 1, 4-19-94) 
Sec. 45-17. - Suspension or revocation of license. 
(a)  The licenses provided for in this article may be suspended or revoked by the license administrator and/or a fine imposed, if the licensee has: 
(1)  Failed to keep in force the insurance required by this article; 
(2)  Discontinued operations in the downtown for more than thirty (30) days from May 1 through October 31; 
(3)  Violated any ordinances of the City of Aurora or the laws of the State of Illinois or the United States of America, related to the fitness of the licensee to offer public passenger transportation; 
(4)  Obtained his/her license fraudulently or there has been any fraudulent use of the license by or with the consent of the licensee; 
(5)  Transferred his/her license in violation of this article. 
(b)  At least twenty (20) days prior to any suspension, revocation and/or fine, the licensee shall be given written notice of the proposed action, and shall have an opportunity to be heard by the mayor or his designee during such period. If a hearing is held before the mayor or his designee, a verbatim transcript shall be made and a decision rendered within five (5) business days of such hearing. The mayor or designee's decision shall be final and shall not be appealable to the city council. 
(Ord. No. O94-30, § 1, 4-19-94) 
Sec. 45-18. - Liability insurance required. 
    The licensee shall maintain in full force and effect general liability coverage in the amount of not less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) per occurrence with the City of Aurora an additional named insured. A certificate of insurance to that effect shall be filed with the City of Aurora prior to issuance of any license. 
(Ord. No. O94-30, § 1, 4-19-94) 
Sec. 45-19. - Carriage operation regulations. 
    In order to operate in the City of Aurora, all horse-drawn carriages must conform to the following: 
(1)  Carriages shall obey all traffic control devices and rules of the road applicable to motor vehicles; 
(2)  No carriage driver shall stand or park a carriage in a roadway other than parallel with the edge of the roadway headed in the direction of lawful traffic movement and with the curbside wheels of the carriage within twelve (12) inches of the curb or edge of the roadway. Double parking is prohibited; 
(3)  All carriages shall be driven in the right hand lane available for traffic or as close as practicable to the right hand curb or edge of the roadway; 
(4)  Carriages shall not pick up or solicit passengers from the streets while operating a tour, and shall only pick up and drop off passengers at a designated carriage stand; 
(5)  Carriages shall not park or stop in or at bus stops; 
(6)  All carriages shall be equipped with brakes, rearview mirrors, two (2) electrified white lights visible for one thousand (1,000) feet in front of the carriage, two (2) electrified red lights visible for one thousand (1,000) feet to the rear of the carriage, amber lights mounted at the rear capable of flashing and visible for at least one thousand (1,000) feet, electrified directional signals, and a slow moving vehicle emblem affixed to the rear of the carriage; 
(7)  All carriages shall have an attendant in addition to the driver located on the carriage while in operation at all times. 
(8)  All horses drawing carriages pursuant to this article shall be equipped with a "diaper" which shall prevent any horse manure from being deposited on the city rights-of-way. 
(9)  Carriage ride rates and the maximum number of passengers allowed must be posted at all times on the carriage. 
(10)  No person may drink any alcoholic liquor as defined by law while such person is operating or being transported by horse-drawn carriage, nor may any person transport, carry, possess or have any alcoholic liquor while being transported by horse-drawn carriage, except in the original package with the seal unbroken. 
(Ord. No. O94-30, § 1, 4-19-94) 
Sec. 45-20. - Hours of operation. 
    Licensed horse-drawn carriages shall be permitted to operate within the downtown only during the following days and hours of operation: 
(1)  Monday through Friday-6:30 p.m. until 12:00 a.m.; 
(2)  Saturday and Sunday-2:00 p.m. until 12:00 a.m.; 
(3)  Christmas Day, New Years Day, Memorial Day, Fourth of July, Labor Day and Thanksgiving Day-2:00 p.m. until 12:00 a.m.; 
(4)  During parades in the City of Aurora, no horse-drawn carriage shall operate unless authorized as a part of the parade. 
(Ord. No. O94-30, § 1, 4-19-94) 
Sec. 45-21. - Area of operation restricted. 
    Licensed horse-drawn carriages shall be permitted to operate on certain streets of the city, said streets to be established from time to time by the city traffic engineer. Said restricted area of operation may be changed only in the case of a weather or other emergency, special event approved by the license administrator, or any route change as approved in writing by the city traffic engineer. 
(Ord. No. O94-30, § 1, 4-19-94) 
Sec. 45-22. - Carriage maintenance. 
(a)  All carriages licensed pursuant to this article must be maintained so as to ensure the safety of passengers and the general public in a clean, well-kept manner. 
(b)  All carriage drivers shall be free of alcohol or drugs while operating the carriage and shall have adequate vision, hearing and command of all other faculties necessary for the safe operation of a public passenger vehicle. 
(c)  All horses utilized in the operation of horse-drawn carriages shall be fit for such work, kept clean and must receive adequate water and feeding and in all ways shall be treated humanely, outfitted with the proper and adequate equipment to perform this type of work. The director of animal control or his designee may order a horse to be examined by a licensed veterinarian of his/her choice to determine the animals fitness for such work. A horse for which such order has been issued shall not be used to draw a carriage thereafter until the director of animal control has received a written statement from the examining veterinarian that the horse is fit to perform such work. 
(Ord. No. O94-30, § 1, 4-19-94) 
ARTICLE III. - PROHIBITIONS AND PENALTIES 

Sec. 45-23. - Fixing of rates prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation licensed under the provisions of this chapter to conspire among themselves or with other persons to fix or control rates for hire within the city. It is the purpose of this chapter to provide for free and uncontrolled rates, except as to maximum rates set by the city, and any scheme, device or other subterfuge employed by any licensee to evade this purpose shall be deemed to be in violation of this article and grounds for revocation or suspension. 
(Ord. No. O93-06, § 1, 1-5-93; Ord. No. O94-30, § 1, 4-19-94) 
Sec. 45-24. - Enforcement. 
    The city license administrator shall ensure enforcement of all provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O93-06, § 1, 1-5-93; Ord. No. O94-30, § 1, 4-19-94) 
Sec. 45-25. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a Misdemeanor I. 
(Ord. No. O93-06, § 1, 1-5-93; Ord. No. O94-30, § 1, 4-19-94) 
Sec. 45-26. - Administrative review. 
    A written petition to set aside a determination of a violation of this chapter by the license administrator may be filed by a person accused of a violation in the manner and subject to the restrictions hereinafter set forth: 
(1)  The petition must be filed with the license administrator not later than fourteen (14) days from the date of the violation; 
(2)  Any administrative adjudication of any violation of this article shall be authorized and conducted pursuant to 65 ILCS 5/1-2.1 et seq. 
(Ord. No. O08-82, § 1, 8-26-08) 
Chapter 46 - TOWING SERVICES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O09-75, §§ 1, 2, adopted Aug. 25, 2009, amended Ch. 46 to read as set out herein. Former Ch. 46 pertained to similar subject matter. For a complete history of former Ch. 46 see the Code Comparative Table. 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 27; disposition of unclaimed towed vehicles, § 27-76 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - POLICE TOW ASSIGNMENTS AND SELECTION OF TOWING SERVICES 

Sec. 46-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Tow truck means a motor vehicle which has been altered or designed and equipped for and exclusively used in the business of towing vehicles by means of a crane, tow bar, tow line or dolly, or is otherwise exclusively used to render assistance to other vehicles. 
    Towing service means the provision of tow truck services in response to a dispatch or request from the police department or any other municipal department. 
    Truck means any truck weighing over ten thousand (10,000) pounds. 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Sec. 46-2. - Fees. 
    The fee to be paid to the city in order to be placed on the tow roster under section 46-4 is one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00). The initial fee is due and payable upon approval of the application provided for in this article. The renewal fee shall be paid on each anniversary date. 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Sec. 46-3. - Purpose and intent. 
    It is the intent of this article to prescribe the basic regulations for the operation of tow trucks in the removal of motor vehicles which are illegally parked, abandoned, involved in an accident, or which constitute an obstruction to traffic or snow removal operations, or which constitute a public nuisance, other than removal of certain inoperable or abandoned vehicles under sections 20-73 and 27-3 of this Code. It is the purpose of the city council in enacting this article to provide a fair and impartial means of distributing city requests for towing services among qualified firms, and to ensure that such services are prompt and reasonably priced and are provided in the best interest of the public, as well as the interest of efficient removal of such vehicles. In enacting this article, it is not the purpose of the council to regulate towing services other than those dispatched or requested by city personnel. 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Sec. 46-4. - Roster. 
    All firms selected and designated to provide towing services under this article shall be listed on a roster to be kept by the police department. The roster of towing firms shall, at all reasonable times, be open to public inspection. The maximum number of towing firms on said roster shall not exceed twelve (12) firms at any one time. The roster of towing firms shall be effective for a period of two (2) years commencing June 1, 2008. 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Sec. 46-5. - Eligibility. 
    Any towing firm shall become eligible to be listed on the roster and participate in the assignment of service calls by the police department if it has maintained its principal place of business in the city for a period of at least six (6) months prior to the date of application and meets the requirements set forth in this article. No person or towing firm shall be placed on the roster or operate a tow truck on tow roster calls if that person or towing firm has been convicted under the laws of Illinois or any other state of an offense which under the laws of Illinois would be a felony theft of a vehicle or a felony offense under article 1, chapter 4 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, or has been fined by the Illinois Commerce Commission. 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Sec. 46-6. - Application. 
    Any towing firm meeting the minimum eligibility requirements may submit a verified application to the city to participate in police towing operations. The application shall be in a form provided by the city clerk, and shall elicit the following information: 
(1)  Business operation: 
a.  Name of firm. Indicate whether a corporation or partnership, list all parties having a financial interest in the towing firm, including names and addresses, number of years business has been established in the city, and number of years that those persons holding financial interest in the firm have been residents of the city. 
b.  Experience. List number of years and locations of participation in similar police towing services, together with any commendations or written complaints received from governmental agencies in conduct of the business within the last five (5) years. 
c.  Stability. State business activities of firm aside from participation in police towing activities. 
d.  Attendants and drivers. List names and addresses of all attendants and drivers who will conduct the police towing service, as well as number of years employed, training received by attendants and drivers, and experience of the personnel in the conduct of the business. 
e.  Equipment. Describe available equipment to be used in police towing services, particularly in terms of comparative qualities or capacities as related to minimum eligibility requirements. 
f.  Communications. Describe the method of operation of the communications system between the place of business and operating tow trucks, as well as the means utilized for ensuring prompt dispatch of trucks upon receipt of call from the police department. 
g.  Other facilities and personnel available. List all provisions for record keeping, backup personnel and auxiliary services which might be required to effectively carry out a high level of service to the public in the business of tow truck operations. 
(2)  Business location and storage lot: 
a.  Primary business location. List location of primary business operation, including dimensions and types of facilities available. 
b.  Storage lot. List location of storage lots, zoning classification, dimensions thereof, relationship to primary business operation, and the type of protection provided at the lot(s). 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Sec. 46-7. - Review of applications. 
    It shall be the duty of the police chief or his designated agents to investigate all applications and renewals submitted under this article and place all eligible firms on the roster. The police chief shall disapprove of any application or renewal if, after due investigation, he finds that the applicant does not meet the minimum requirements set forth in this article or has violated section 46-15. The police chief shall notify an applicant in writing if an application or renewal is disapproved and state the reasons for such disapproval. 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Sec. 46-8. - Assignment. 
    Any towing firm listed on the roster shall not assign its place to other towing concerns nor assign any calls without written consent of the police chief. 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Sec. 46-9. - Tow trucks; minimum equipment standards. 
    Minimum equipment standards for tow trucks shall be as follows: 
(1)  Truck chassis: At least one (1) rig of one-ton capacity with rear dual wheels. The police officer on the scene shall determine if greater capacity is needed and shall call upon any service capable of providing that capacity regardless of whether or not the company is on the roster of the city or whether it is their period of time to receive police requests. 
(2)  Company name: Company name, address or phone number on both sides of tow car. 
(3)  Lights: Trucks must, at all times, be equipped with such headlights, taillights, red reflectors, stoplights, warning lights, etc., as required by state law, plus one (1) white utility light (adjustable or portable), and may be equipped with such other lights as the owner may desire which are not forbidden by law. 
(4)  Winch: To be power-driven by power takeoff from transmission equipped with safety dogs or equivalent braking devices. 
(5)  Additional equipment: Trucks must be equipped with red flares, lanterns or reflectors, hand tools, crowbar, rope, broom, shovel, dustpan, fire extinguisher (dry chemical type), portable red taillight and stoplight for towed vehicles, equipment for opening locked vehicles and safety snubber chain. Each tow company shall have at least one (1) set of dollies readily available at all times. 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Sec. 46-10. - Minimum business and storage lot requirements. 
(a)  Business and storage. The business and storage lot of a towing firm must be a reasonable distance from public transportation and the storage lot must be in close proximity to the place of business, and the storage area if not located within a building, must be located in an M-1 manufacturing district or have the right to the use of the subject property consistent with permitted uses of an M-1 district; except, if the area is located on a premises where an already existing principal use authorizes the storage of cars and trucks in the open as incidental to the principal use, the storage lot must have adequate storage space (at least fifty (50) feet by one hundred (100) feet or equivalent area) to accommodate thirty (30) cars, either under cover or well fenced. The firm must exercise ordinary care to keep stored vehicles and contents safe from pilfering. 
(b)  Hours. There shall be an attendant on call, capable of responding to police requests for towing, as well as to be present or available for the release of vehicles to the authorized party, twenty-four (24) hours a day, seven (7) days a week. An attendant shall be on call to be present or available for the recovery of personal items from towed vehicles by an authorized party Monday through Saturday from 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m., except for New Year's Day, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day, and Christmas Day. 
(c)  Records. Each garage shall keep a record of the vehicle and license number; date and time it was towed; location from which it was towed; name of officer ordering the towing; and whether the vehicle was impounded or towed at the owner's request. 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Sec. 46-11. - Dispatching requirements. 
(a)  All requests for towing service pursuant to this article shall be made through the police department. 
(b)  When it becomes evident that there will be a delay in responding to a request for towing service, the towing firm concerned shall advise the police department of this delay. 
(c)  Towing units shall be dispatched from the place of business, or a reasonable distance from the place of business, as determined by the police department. The police department may, from time to time, establish a policy with regard to distribution of requests for towing service among the successful applicants, provided that the policy is fair and equitable to all firms listed on the roster. 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Sec. 46-12. - Revision of rates; notice of hearing. 
(a)  The city council may, from time to time, amend, by resolution after a public hearing, the schedule of fees or rates which may be charged for towing and storage services. The maximum fees to be charged shall not exceed towing and thirty (30) days storage, unless authorized by the chief of police or his designee. 
(b)  Prior to the city council hearing, there shall be a publication, at least once, of notice of the hearing in a newspaper of general circulation within the city, at least ten (10) days before the hearing date. In addition thereto, the hearing shall be preceded by at least ten (10) days' notice of such hearing, given by letter from the city clerk to each firm then listed on the roster, such letter directed to the address contained in the application submitted under this article. 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Sec. 46-13. - Removal of hazards; police to determine necessity of removing vehicles. 
    After being dispatched by the police department to the scene, the tow truck operator shall cooperate with the police officers in removing hazards and illegally parked vehicles as requested. It is the duty of the police officers to determine when such a vehicle should be impounded or moved, and the tow truck operator shall abide by their decisions. 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Sec. 46-14. - Identification of tow cars. 
    Only tow trucks bearing the name of the towing firm called shall be dispatched to the scene of need. 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Sec. 46-15. - Conduct. 
    All owners of towing firms shall conduct their business in an orderly, and businesslike manner and use every means to avoid any conflicts between any interested parties. The primary measure to be used by the city in determining whether a towing firm has violated this section will be the number and type of complaints received by the city from the public. The police department is charged with the investigation of all complaints related to towing firms. 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Sec. 46-16. - Protection of vehicles. 
    Vehicles impounded by the police for special investigations, i.e., fingerprints, etc., shall be held in maximum security until cleared by the investigating officers. Contents of vehicles with a police hold shall not be removed. 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Sec. 46-17. - Responsibility for employees' acts. 
    The owners of towing firms participating in towing assignments by the police department shall be responsible for the acts of their employees while on duty. Towing firms shall be responsible for damage to vehicles while in their possession. 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Sec. 46-18. - Periodic inspection of records, equipment, facilities. 
    Towing firms on the roster shall be subject to periodic checks of all records, equipment and storage facilities by police officers. A towing firm that fails to produce tow records or allow for inspections of its equipment and facilities at the request of the police, shall be immediately suspended from the roster until the investigation in question is resolved. 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Sec. 46-19. - Damage appraisals. 
    All vehicles stored or impounded as a result of the tow ordered by the police department shall be made available to the owner of the vehicle or his representative, appropriate insurance agent, insurance adjuster, or appropriate body shop or car dealer, for the purpose of estimating or appraising damages, except vehicles with a police hold. 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Sec. 46-20. - Access to vehicles. 
    Vehicles to be impounded by a towing firm shall be accessible to police department personnel. An employee of the towing firm may be required to assist. 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Sec. 46-21. - Itemized statements, when required. 
(a)  A person conducting towing operations shall furnish an itemized statement of services performed, labor and special equipment used in completing the tow of a vehicle and the charges made therefor to and upon the request of: 
(1)  The person requesting the towing service; 
(2)  The registered owner of the vehicle towed; 
(3)  The insurance carrier of either paragraph (1) or (2) above; 
(4)  The duly authorized agent of paragraph (1), (2) or (3) above. 
(b)  A person conducting towing operations shall furnish a copy of the statement to any person authorized by this section to receive the statement without demanding payment as a condition precedent. The chief of police or his designee shall have authority over determining who may have access to towed vehicles ordered by the city during any dispute that may arise from this section. 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Sec. 46-22. - Vehicle repair or alteration, when permitted. 
    A person conducting towing operations shall refrain from making any repairs or alterations to a vehicle without first being authorized by one (1) of the persons listed in subsections 46-21(a)(2), (a)(3) or (a)(4). Parts or accessories shall not be removed from vehicles without authorization except as necessary for security purposes. Under such circumstances, the parts or accessories removed shall be listed on the itemized statement and stored in the business office. This section shall not be construed to prohibit persons conducting towing operations from making emergency alterations necessary to permit the removal by towing of vehicles. 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Sec. 46-23. - Facilities to conform to building code. 
    Towing firms' storage lots, buildings, fencing, driveways, etc., must conform with building code requirements. 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Sec. 46-24. - Zoning requirements. 
    Business and storage lots of towing firms must conform with the zoning regulations of the city. 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Sec. 46-25. - Storage lot capacity. 
    At no time shall the storage lot of a towing firm be filled to more than ninety (90) percent capacity. Should the lot be filled greater than that limit, the city may suspend towing services pursuant to this article until such time as the number of the vehicles in the lot is reduced to within the above-stated capacity. 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Sec. 46-26. - Deviation from roster. 
    Any and all tow truck operators not selected and designated pursuant to this article are prohibited from removing from the public streets and towing away any vehicles involved in the situations as set forth in the preamble of this article; provided, however, that the owner or operator of the vehicle involved in the aforesaid situations may designate any towing service to be used for the towing away of the vehicle and/or may designate the destination of the towed vehicle. 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Sec. 46-27. - Insurance. 
(a)  Each towing firm listed on the roster, as of December 10, 2002, shall have in full force and effect, during the period the firm remains on the roster, public liability, property damage and fire and theft insurance coverage. The city shall be listed as an additional insured on each policy. Proof of such coverage shall be a minimum eligibility requirement. The amounts of public liability and property damage coverage shall not be less than: 
(1)  Public liability, five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) per each accident. 
(2)  Property damage, fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) per each accident. 
(b)  Each towing firm listed on the roster after December 10, 2002, including those firms who are renewing prior applications, shall have in full force and effect, during the period the firm remains on the roster, insurance coverage meeting the minimum requirements as follows: 
(1)  Comprehensive general liability: Must include the following industry standard forms of insurance: 
a.  Premises/operation coverage; 
b.  Products and completed operations coverage; 
c.  Blanket contractual liability; 
d.  Five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) combined single limit, or five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) bodily injury and two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) property damage. 
(2)  Comprehensive auto liability: Must include the following endorsements: 
a.  All owned autos, hired-car coverage, and employers non-owned auto coverage; 
b.  The policy shall not contain a radius restriction of less than fifty (50) miles; 
c.  Fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) on hook liability. 
(3)  Garage keepers legal liability or motor truck cargo: The towing firm shall provide coverage for the vehicles in their custody. Either a motor truck cargo policy, listing all storage lots as terminal locations or garage keepers' legal liability shall be required. The minimum amount of coverage shall be no less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00). 
(4)  Workers' compensation and employers' liability: Statutory limits for workmen's compensation and a one hundred thousand dollar ($100,000.00) employers' liability limit. 
(c)  Each towing firm shall supply the city with a certificate of insurance, which indicates coverage for the above mentioned minimum insurance requirements and carries the provision that said insurance shall not be cancelled without giving the city at least thirty (30) days' notice of cancellation or material change. The certificate of insurance shall also name the city as additional insured. 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Sec. 46-28. - Police department held harmless. 
    If any firm listed on the roster performs towing services in a manner not in accordance with the provisions contained in this article, the police department is held harmless from any and all liability or damage arising therefrom. 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Sec. 46-29. - Removal or suspension from roster. 
(a)  Any deviation from the requirements established in this article, except for violations of section 46-18, or failure at any time to provide reasonable, quick and efficient service at the rates prescribed may result in the temporary suspension for no more than thirty (30) days or removal of the name of such firm from the roster upon the recommendation of the police chief. 
(b)  The police chief shall provide the tow operator with written notice at least fifteen (15) days prior to the effective date of the suspension/removal by delivering said notice to the tow operator's place of business. Said written notice shall include; 1) the effective date of the suspension/removal; 2) whether the suspension/removal is temporary or permanent; 3) the allegations which form the basis of the suspension/removal; 4) the actions, if any, the tow operator may take to prevent the suspension/removal from occurring; and 5) the procedure which the tow operator must follow to request a hearing to appeal the suspension/removal. If a hearing is requested, the city's administrative hearing officer shall act as hearing officer. The hearing shall be informal and provide both sides with the opportunity to present all evidence relevant to the suspension/removal. The hearing officer shall issue a written decision based upon a preponderance of the presented evidence within seven (7) days of the hearing. The opinion will be sent to the tow operator's business address with a copy retained in the tow operator's application file. The city or the tow operator may contest the decision of the hearing officer in any manner provided by law. 
(c)  A tow operator must request a hearing by: 1) calling the city law department within ten (10) days of receiving a notice of suspension/removal; and 2) scheduling a hearing. Leaving a message with the city law department will not satisfy this requirement. The law department must provide a time for the hearing that is within ninety-six (96) hours of the request, provided there is one (1) complete business day within the ninety-six-hour time period. If there is no complete business day in the ninety-six-hour period, the hearing shall be held on the first business day after the ninety-six-hour time period. If the tow operator is unavailable at the time provided by the city, the city shall not be bound by the ninety-six-hour period and the suspension/removal will not be stayed. If the city is unable to provide a hearing time within the applicable time period, all action on the suspension/removal shall be stayed until the hearing. 
(Ord. No. O09-75, § 1, 8-25-09) 
Secs. 46-30-46-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PRIVATE PROPERTY TOWING 

Sec. 46-50. - Removal of vehicles from private property without consent of owner. 
    The towing or removal of any vehicle from private property within the City of Aurora without the consent of the registered owner or other legally authorized person in control of the vehicle is subject to compliance with the following conditions and restrictions. 
(1)  Any towed or removed vehicle must be stored at the site of the commercial relocator's place of business. The site must be open during business hours, and for the purpose of redemption of vehicles, during the time that the person or firm towing such vehicle is open for towing purposes. The site must be open for a period of a minimum of two (2) hours after the vehicle is towed in order to allow the owner to retrieve his vehicle. The commercial relocator must be open the day following the day of the tow a minimum of four (4) consecutive hours during the regular business day between 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. 
(2)  The commercial relocator shall, prior to any towing or removal, notify the Aurora Police Department of such towing or removal. The notification shall include a complete description of the vehicle, including the year, make, model, color and license plate number and state; the vehicle registration number if possible; the location from which the vehicle was removed; the location to which the vehicle is being moved; the reason for tow, tow truck number and operator ID number; the time of removal; and information whether the tow was based on a call or patrol. The person making the notification shall also obtain and record the name of the person at the Aurora Police Department to whom such information is reported. The commercial relocator's duty to notify the Aurora Police Department prior to removing any vehicle is effective twenty-four (24) hours a day, seven (7) days a week. 
(3)  The commercial relocator shall, within thirty (30) minutes of completion of such towing or removal, notify the Aurora Police Department of such towing or removal via facsimile. The notification shall include a complete description of the vehicle, including the year, make, model, color and license plate number; the vehicle registration number if possible; the location from which the vehicle was removed; the location to which the vehicle has been or is being moved; and the time or removal. 
(4)  If the registered owner or legally authorized person entitled to possession of the vehicle arrives at the scene prior to actual removal or towing of the vehicle, the vehicle shall be disconnected from the tow truck, and that person shall be allowed to remove the vehicle without interference and without charge to the owner or operator of the vehicle. 
(5)  The rebate or payment of money or any other valuable consideration from the commercial relocator or its owners, managers or employees to the owners or operators of the premises from which the vehicles are towed or removed, for the privilege of removing or towing those vehicles, is prohibited. 
(6)  Except for property appurtenant to, and obviously a part of a single-family residence, and except for instances where notice is personally given to the owner or other legally authorized person in control of the vehicle that the area in which that vehicle is parked is reserved or otherwise unavailable to unauthorized vehicles, and that such vehicles are subject to being removed at the owner or operator's expense, any property owner or lessor, prior to towing or removing any vehicle from private property, or causing the towing or removing of any vehicle from private property without the consent of the owner or other legally authorized person in control of that vehicle, must post a notice meeting the following requirements: 
a.  The notice must be prominently placed at each driveway, access or curb cut allowing vehicular access to the property within five (5) feet from the public right-of-way line. If there are no curbs or access barriers, the signs must be posed not less than one (1) sign each one hundred (100) feet of lot frontage, or any other conspicuous place approved by the city. 
b.  The notice must be at least twenty-four (24) inches in height and thirty-six (36) inches in width; and must indicate clearly, in not less than two (2) inch high light-reflective letters on a contrasting background, that unauthorized vehicles will be towed away at the owner's expense. 
c.  The notice must include a general statement indicating who is allowed to park in the area and a warning that unauthorized vehicles will be towed. The notice must also provide the name and current telephone number of the commercial relocator towing or removing the vehicle, the maximum fee that the relocator may charge the owner or owner's agent of the vehicle as a condition of reclaiming the vehicle and any restrictions on the form of payment that will be accepted by the relocator. 
d.  The sign structure containing the required notices must be permanently installed with the bottom of the sign not less than four (4) feet above ground level and no higher than eight (8) feet from the ground, and must be continuously maintained on the property for not less than twenty-four (24) hours prior to the towing or removing of any vehicle. 
(8)  Any commercial relocator that tows or removes vehicles from property within the City of Aurora and proposes to require the owner, operator, or person in control of the vehicle to pay the costs of towing and storage prior to redemption of the vehicle must file and keep on record with the Aurora Police Department a complete copy of the current rates to be charged for such services, post at the storage site an identical rate schedule and keep any written contracts with property owners, lessors, or persons in control of property, who authorize the commercial relocator to remove vehicles as provided in this section. 
(9)  No person shall engage in the removal of vehicles from private property as described in this section without first obtaining a commercial relocator license as set forth in section 46-56, License. 
(10)  No removal of a vehicle from private property in the City of Aurora shall be done except upon the express written instruction of the owner or person in legal possession and/or control of the private property on which the vehicle is said to be trespassing. 
(11)  This section shall not apply to law enforcement, fire fighting, rescue, ambulance, or other emergency vehicles which are marked as such or to property owned by any governmental agency. 
(12)  The owner or operator of any relocated vehicle shall have the opportunity to inspect the interior and exterior of such vehicle, and shall be entitled to receive from the commercial relocator a copy of the ICC consumer rights provisions pertaining to the towing of vehicles, prior to the payment of fees for the release of such vehicle. 
(13)  No towing vehicle shall operate within the municipal limits of the City of Aurora in connection with any vehicle relocation service except in compliance with the following requirements: 
a.  There shall be painted or firmly affixed to such vehicle on both sides thereof in a color or colors vividly contrasting to the color of the vehicle in a manner that is clearly legible and in letters no less than two (2) inches in height, the name, address and telephone number of the operator thereof. 
b.  There shall be carried in the power unit of such vehicle a certified copy of the currently effective licenses. Copies may be photographed, photocopied or reproduced or printed by any other legible and durable process. Any person guilty of not causing to be displayed a copy of his license, may in any hearing concerning such violation be excused from the payment of the penalty hereinafter provided, upon a showing that such license was issued, but was subsequently lost or destroyed. 
c.  The tow vehicle shall be listed on the commercial relocator's license application or renewal thereof and shall be properly equipped as specified in section 46-56 License. 
d.  The tow vehicle shall be equipped with a four-by-four (4 x 4) and spacer block, or a similar apparatus designed to protect automobile bodies from damage, and with a set of dollies to transport four wheel drive vehicles and vehicles with locked wheels.
