Editor's note- Ord. No. O00-188, § 1, adopted Dec. 26, 2000, repealed §§ 47-61-47-64 in their entirety. Formerly, said sections pertained to weeds. See the Code Comparative Table. 

Secs. 47-61-47-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EUROPEAN BARBERRY 

Sec. 47-76. - Prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful and it is declared a nuisance for any person to plant or permit the growth, upon any premises, of the bush of the species of tall, common or European Barberry, further known as Berberis vulgaris, and its horticultural varieties, in the city. 
(Code 1969, § 46-66) 
Sec. 47-77. - Notice to remove. 
    It shall be the duty of the division of inspections, permits and zoning enforcement to serve a notice in writing upon the owner, agent, occupant or person in possession, charge or control of any lot, building or premises in or upon which Barberry bush may be found, requiring them to remove, destroy and carry the same away and off such premises within ten (10) days thereafter. 
(Code 1969, § 46-67) 
Sec. 47-78. - Removal by city. 
    If the person notified in accordance with section 47-77 shall refuse or neglect to comply with such order within the time and in the manner specified, the division of inspections, permits and zoning administration shall cause the abatement of such nuisance at the expense of the party or parties responsible for or permitting the same. 
(Code 1969, § 46-68) 
Chapter 48 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Franchises, Ch. 19; garbage and trash, Ch. 20; water supply and sanitary sewer systems in floodplain, § 18-71 et seq. 
State Law reference- Powers of home rule units, Ill. Const. art. VII, § 6. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 48-1. - Jurisdiction of city. 
    The systems of water supply distribution and waterworks and sewage collection heretofore established, built and constructed by the city are hereby continued as its property under its control, jurisdiction and management. The systems shall at all times be maintained, repaired, enlarged, controlled and extended under the authority and ownership of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 47-1) 
Sec. 48-2. - Preparation, service of citations. 
    The public works director, finance director, water billing manager or their designees are deemed peace officers and may prepare and serve citations personally or by certified mail for violations of section 48-29, 48-72 or 48-44. 
(Code 1969, § 47-5; Ord. No. O02-94, § 1, 9-10-02) 
Sec. 48-3. - Fees. 
    The fees required by this chapter are as determined from time to time by separate ordinance or resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1969, §§ 47-33(f), (h), 4-34(f), 4-66(c), 47-67; Ord. No. O88-08, § 1, 1-19-88; Ord. No. O88-143, § 1, 12-6-88; Ord. No. O90-03, § 1, 1-16-90) 
Sec. 48-4. - Extension of services outside corporate limits. 
(a)  Any person owning property outside the corporate limits of the city who now or hereafter desires to avail himself of the use of the city's water supply and distribution system, sewage collection system or both shall first pay to the city such charges and proportionate share of the cost of such improvements as determined by resolution of the council from time to time. 
(b)  Any person outside the corporate limits shall annex their property so as to be in the corporate limits of the city prior to receiving any such services. Any person outside the corporate limits who cannot lawfully annex shall sign an agreement to annex which shall require immediate annexation upon the removal of the legal impediment to annexation of the subject property into the city. 
(c)  Any service connections made hereunder shall be under the approval of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 47-6; Ord. No. O87-5617, § 3, 2-3-87) 
Secs. 48-5-48-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MUNICIPAL UTILITY SERVICE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 48-21. - "Consumer" defined; liability for charges. 
    The word "consumer" when used in this article shall mean the owner of the premises to which water service and/or sewer service is provided, or the owner and occupant of such premises jointly and severally. All new accounts shall be contracted for by such consumer and all deposits shall be in the name of such consumer. Whenever an occupant of such premises seeks to open a new account he shall be presumed to be authorized by the owner of the premises to obligate him for the payment of charges for water and/or sewer service jointly and severally with such occupant as herein provided, and any deposit made by such occupant shall be presumed to be made by the owner and occupant jointly and severally. 
(Code 1969, § 47-16; Ord. No. O88-52, § 1, 5-3-88) 
Sec. 48-22. - Application for service. 
    An application for turning on water service shall be made to the office of the department of public works. Upon all applicable forms furnished by such department, the cost of the meter shall be payable in advance and deposit as herein provided to be made at the time of ordering. Every application for water service shall express that the same is signed subject to all the rules and regulations then in force or that may thereafter be adopted for the government of the water system. 
(Code 1969, § 47-17; Ord. No. O02-94, § 2, 9-10-02) 
Sec. 48-23. - Taps and connections. 
(a)  No person shall open, tap or make any connection to the water supply, transmission or distribution system of the city, except as provided in this section. 
(b)  Any person desiring such opening, tap and/or water connection must first file a properly completed application upon such form as furnished by the public works department and addressed to the public works director. Upon approval of the application by the director, or his office, the supply, transmission or distribution main may be opened, tapped at and/or connected at locations set forth in the application. 
(c)  The public works department shall then furnish and insert at the tap and/or connection thus made, a valve which shall be known as the corporation cock. After installation, the contractor must furnish and install as provided in section 48-24 the service line, curb valve and curb valve shutoff box. The curb valve shall be turned to and left in the off position until the installation of the remainder of the service line, water meter, meter holding device and shutoff valve; all in accordance with the provisions of this article, or by authority of the public works director. 
(d)  The public works department shall make all necessary openings and taps (after the contractor has opened, exposed and prepared the water main) when and where required in any and all water mains of the city only after all applicable charges as required in the application form noted above have been paid to the city. The contractor shall supply and install all tapping saddles where required and the department shall furnish all necessary corporation cocks and saddles where required through the two-inch tap size. For each three-inch connection and larger, the contractor must furnish and install the tapping sleeve and valve prior to the city making the tap. After the tap is completed, the contractor shall install the valve shutoff box. 
(e)  Each location for metered water service must have a separate opening, tap, connection, service line, curb valve shutoff and curb valve shutoff box as noted above. Each location for unmetered fire service installed after April 15, 1985, must have a separate opening, tap, connection, fire service line, curb valve shutoff and curb valve shutoff box or value vault. 
(f)  The charges for tapping and installing such connections shall be as specified in section 48-3. 
(g)  The contractor, who must be licensed and bonded with the city, for whom the opening and tap is made shall excavate at the location approved by the public works department. He shall prepare the water main involved for work to be done by department personnel and after such work is completed, the contractor shall backfill and restore the excavation site to the condition in which it was found. 
(h)  For each new service connection made to the water system, a connection charge shall be paid to the city in the amount specified in section 48-3, excluding fire services. 
(Code 1969, § 47-33; Ord. No. O88-143, § 1, 12-6-88; Ord. No. O02-94, § 3, 9-10-02; Ord. No. O05-125, § 1, 11-8-05) 
Sec. 48-24. - Installation of service connections and curb valves. 
(a)  After a tap is complete as provided in section 48-23, any person desiring to attach service pipes, irrigation systems, back flow preventers, and other similar devices to the corporation cock must obtain a plumbing permit for construction of such installation in complete accordance with the plumbing code of the city. The service installation shall include a curb valve shutoff and curb valve shutoff box in public property set at a point just beyond that line defined as the street curb and not to exceed that line defined as the nearer edge of the sidewalk or as approved by the director of public works or his designees. 
(b)  In those areas zoned planned unit development, or similar in nature without public property next to the street, the above curb valve shutoff installation set point will apply. 
(c)  After installation, the curb valve shutoff shall be left in the closed position, and the public works department shall not turn water into the service pipe beyond the curb valve until application for water service shall have been made and approved as required by this article. 
(d)  After proper flushing and testing of the service line, a suitable meter as specified in the approved application shall be installed in the meter holding device. 
(e)  No person other than an authorized representative of the public works department shall operate or open the curb valve shutoff or turn water into the service pipes. 
(Code 1969, § 47-34; Ord. No. O88-52, § 10, 5-3-88; Ord. No. O95-28, § 1, 5-16-95; Ord. No. O02-94, § 4, 9-10-02) 
Cross reference- Plumbing code, § 12-16 et seq. 
Sec. 48-25. - Installation of service pipes and accessories. 
    The installation of service pipes, curb box, curb cock, meters and meter shutoff valve must conform in every particular to the following specifications: 
(1)  Rule 1. Water service to be installed before pavement of streets: 
a.  To prevent destruction of paved streets, water services must be installed for all unserved property before paving. 
b.  Whenever a street is paved, all private mains paralleling the main of the public works department must be abandoned and new services installed and connected with the city water main. 
c.  Wherever existing old water services are found to be in such state of bad repair that connection with the new main would be inadvisable, new service pipes must be installed and connected to the city main at the homeowner's expense. 
d.  New service connections shall be refused at any time on a paved street unless all requirements of the city ordinances regarding cutting or digging up street paving have been satisfied. 
(2)  Rule 2. All service pipes placed in connection with the city water mains shall be of approved Type K copper or ductile iron pipe and installed in complete accordance with the building code. 
    When the service pipe is larger than two (2) inches, it shall be constructed of class 52 or greater ductile iron pipe as far as the meter using slip-on joints and/or mechanical joints. The service pipe must be installed at least five and one-half (51/2) feet below the surface of the earth. From the curb cock, the service pipe must consist of Type K copper or class 52 ductile iron pipe as far as the meter. 
    The corporation cocks, and valves and sleeves, curb cock, curb box, back flow preventers, meter shutoff, meter and meter box must all be of a type approved by the city. The service pipe as far as and including the meter must be inspected by a representative from the public works department before the same is covered. 
(Code 1969, § 47-35; Ord. No. O02-94, § 5, 9-10-02) 
Sec. 48-26. - Responsibility for installation, maintenance. 
(a)  The owner of property being furnished water service by the city must at his own expense make connection to the corporation stop and install service pipes and accessories and furthermore must not do anything which might damage the service pipes, curb box, service valve, meters and meter shutoff valves or prevent all meters and valves from being accessible and capable of being operated. 
(b)  The owner of property being furnished water service by the city shall own and be responsible for the maintenance, repair and replacement of the entire water service facility, beginning at the public water main, including, without limitation, frozen pipes, replacement of facilities due to deterioration or as otherwise required by mandate of city, state or federal laws or regulations. 
(c)  The owner of property which is furnished water service under the conditions imposed by this article must notify the city whenever he has knowledge through his own observation or through information brought to his attention of water leaking from the pipes and accessories under his control. 
(d)  The city may choose to repair a water service facility at the city's expense, in the discretion of the water and sewer superintendent, based upon the following: 
i.  The city has not performed more than two (2) repairs previously of the water service facility; 
ii.  Domestic water service pipes: 
A)  When the public water main and the curb box are located in a public right-of-way; 
B)  When the public water main is located in a public right-of-way or easement and the curb box is located on private property, the city may repair the service pipe and valve from the public water main to the limit of the public right-of-way. 
C)  When the public water main and the curb box are located on private property, the city may repair the service pipe and valve from the public water main to the service valve; 
D)  When the city has notified a property owner of the need to repair or replace a domestic water service pipe, curb box and/or valve located either on private property or in the public right-of-way, and the work has not been completed within a reasonable time, as determined by the water and sewer superintendent, the city may then choose to shut off the domestic water service until the work has been completed, or repair or replace said facility(s) at the private property owner's expense, and record a lien on the property for the reasonable cost of the repair or replacement if the property owner fails to pay the city for the cost of the repair or replacement within thirty (30) days of receiving an invoice from the city. 
iii.  Fire protection service pipes and combined fire/domestic service pipes. The private property owner shall be solely responsible for maintaining and repairing the service pipe, curb box, corporation stop and valves from the public water main; 
iv.  Water meters. The city shall be responsible for maintaining and repairing water meters which become non- functioning after normal use/life. The city may repair or replace, in the sole discretion of the water and sewer superintendent, a frozen or damaged water meter on private property, but the repair or replacement will be made at the private property owner's expense after the water and sewer superintendent has provided the property owner with reasonable notice of his or her intent to repair or replace the water meter In the event that a property owner fails to pay the city for the cost of repairing or replacing a frozen or damaged water meter within thirty (30) days of receiving an invoice from the city, the city shall have the right to record a lien against the property for the cost of the repair or replacement. Notwithstanding any repair or replacement of a water meter by the city, the private property owner shall continue to own the water meter. 
(e)  The city will not be responsible for making any repairs, or paying any repair expenses, that are caused by the negligent, reckless or intentional acts or omissions of the owner or occupant of the real property, or the acts or omissions of the property owner or occupant's agents, employees, volunteers, contractors or subcontractors of any tier. 
(Code 1969, § 47-39; Ord. No. O98-24, § 1, 2-24-98; Ord. No. O02-94, § 6, 9-10-02; Ord. No. O17-050, § 1, 8-8-17) 
Sec. 48-27. - Right of entry of city employees. 
    All property owners, tenants and persons in charge or control of premises must permit any person duly authorized by the city to enter the premises for the purpose of inspection and to examine, test or operate meters, valves, reading devices and any appurtenant devices and also for the installation and removal of meters as well as any other necessary repairs that may be required. The city treasurer, or his designee, is authorized to discontinue water service to any property where said entry is refused. 
(Code 1969, § 47-40; Ord. No. O98-24, § 1, 2-24-98; Ord. No. O01-02, § 1, 1-16-01; Ord. No. O02-94, § 7, 9-10-02) 
Sec. 48-28. - Service outside city; prohibition of private and public wells. 
(a)  The city may furnish water service to a person, firm or corporation outside the corporate limits of the city. The providing of such service shall be at the option of the city. The city may discontinue such service at any time. The classification and charges of rates for the services shall be those as set forth in section 48-56 and section 48-57 as amended from time to time. 
(b)  The requirements of section 48-4, subsection (b) shall apply as a condition to the furnishing of water service to properties outside the corporate limits of the city. 
(c)  Private wells shall not be constructed within the jurisdiction of the city after December 31, 2007. 
(d)  Operation of private wells in existence on or before December 31, 2007, is permitted; except that such wells are deemed a legal nonconforming use of the property, and cannot in any way be altered, expanded, enlarged or deepened, but may be repaired only. 
(e)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this Code, except for uses or methods in existence before the effective date of this subsection prohibiting such use, the use or attempt to use, as a potable water supply (any water used for human or domestic consumption including, but not limited to, water used for drinking, bathing, swimming, washing dishes or preparing foods), groundwater from within the boundaries of the property described below by the installation or drilling of wells or by any other method is hereby prohibited, including points of withdrawal by the city. 
(1)  All areas within the boundaries of E. Downer Street to the north, N. LaSalle Street to the east, Bluff Street to the south, and the Fox River to the west. 
(2)  Beginning at the intersection of North Lincoln Avenue and Flagg Street running south on Lincoln Avenue to East Galena Boulevard; then running east along Galena Boulevard to Anderson; then running north on Anderson to Spring Street; then running east on Spring Street to North Spencer Street; then running north on North Spencer Street to Fulton Street; then running east on Fulton Street to North Union Street; then running north on North Union Street to College Avenue; then running west on College Avenue to North Root Street; then running south on North Root Street to Flagg Street; then running west on Flagg Street back to the intersection of North Lincoln Avenue and Flagg Street. 
(f)  Variations from the provisions contained in the preceding paragraphs may be applied for by filing an application with the public works department for referral to and consideration and approval by the city council. 
(Code 1969, § 47-43; Ord. No. O87-5617, § 2, 2-3-87; Ord. No. O88-52, § 12, 5-3-88; Ord. No. O02-94, § 8, 9-10-02; Ord. No. O07-73, § 1, 6-26-07; Ord. No. O07-137, § 1, 12-11-07; Ord. No. O16-034, § 1, 5-10-16) 
Sec. 48-29. - Hydrant jurisdiction; use. 
(a)  All hydrants now installed or to be installed shall be under the jurisdiction of the public works director. 
(b)  Hydrants are installed for use in extinguishing fires, and other uses as may be authorized. 
(c)  Only members of the fire department and persons specifically authorized by the public works director or his designee shall open or operate hydrants. Other persons specifically authorized to open or operate hydrants are required to place a deposit with the city for a hydrant water meter that is to be used to obtain water from the hydrants. The deposit shall be equivalent to two (2) times the cost of a hydrant water meter at the time of the request. The meter shall be returned in the same condition that it was received, normal wear and tear excepted. Any damages to or replacement of the meter will be deducted from the deposit posted. Any person or entity which loses, damages or fails to return a meter or fails to pay outstanding debts due to the city may be prohibited from obtaining a meter under this chapter. A monthly charge of five dollars ($5.00) shall be paid for handling in addition to the regular monthly usage charge set forth in section 48-56. All meters must be brought to the meter shop, during normal working hours, for the purpose of having the meters read and checked on a monthly basis. It is the responsibility of the meter user to schedule to check. Additionally, a deposit of five hundred dollars ($500.00) for water usage shall be posted when renting a meter from the city. The water rate charged for the water passing through the meter shall be double the regular water rate paid by the party requesting the meter. If the final water usage bill is paid in full, then the security deposit shall be returned to the renter. Any outstanding amounts for water usage at the conclusion of the rental shall be deducted from the deposit, prior to the refund of the deposit. 
(d)  Any unauthorized person who shall open, close, operate or tamper with any hydrant shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall also be responsible for payment of a fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per day for each day of violation. 
(e)  The public works director may require additional hydrants which he deems necessary for protection of the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Code 1969, § 47-44; Ord. No. O88-52, § 13, 5-3-88; Ord. No. O02-94, § 9, 9-10-02; Ord. No. O05-125, § 2, 11-8-05) 
Cross reference- Fine schedule for violations, § 1-11. 
Sec. 48-30. - Installation of oversize mains by developers. 
(a)  Where in any subdivision now within the city or within one and one-half (11/2) miles of the city limits, which normally would require an eight-inch water main, but which, for the purpose of complying with the plan of development of the city's water system to provide an adequate water supply, not only to the particular subdivision, but also to subdivisions which in the future may become a part of the city, and where the public works director has determined that water mains of a larger diameter than eight (8) inches, and the size thereof, shall be installed, then the director shall inform the subdividers, builders and developers of the subdivision by a written notice of that fact and require them to install such oversized water mains and at the same time, in the notice, inform them of the size to be installed. 
(b)  Upon being so notified as provided in subsection (a), no subdivider, builder or developer shall install any water main in such subdivision of any size other than that specified to him by the notice. 
(c)  At such time as the installation of the oversized water main pipe shall have been completed in accordance with the plans and specifications submitted to the city for such installation and also in accordance with the notice specified in this section, and all such installations shall have been inspected and approved by the proper corporate authorities as provided for by the ordinances of the city, then the city will pay any such subdivider, builder or developer who has installed oversized water main pipe, as above provided, the difference of the cost at current prices, as of the time of the installation, between the water main pipe which was originally planned to be used and the cost of the oversized pipe which the corporate authorities directed to be used. 
(d)  The public works director will determine the type of pipe to be used. 
(e)  When the public works director deems necessary to provide for adequate fire protection from the city's water supply, subdividers, builders and developers must, at their own expense, upsize the water mains within their subdivisions to the size required by the public works director in order to provide for adequate fire flows, within their subdivision or building. 
(Code 1969, § 47-45; Ord. No. O02-94, § 10, 9-10-02) 
Sec. 48-31. - Water conservation. 
(a)  Definitions: The following words and phrases when used in this section shall, for the purposes of this section, have the following meanings: 
(1)  Drip irrigation system means an irrigation system that saves water by allowing water to drip slowly to the roots of plants, either onto the soil surface or directly onto the root zone. Such systems include but are not limited to soaker hoses. 
(2)  Handheld watering system means a method of watering that requires the watering device to be held in order to operate, including watering cans, buckets, and hoses equipped with automatic shutoff valves. This also includes the handheld use of a hose, provided it is continuously attended. 
(3)  Harvested rain water means water that is accumulated and stored during times of precipitation, such as through rain barrels and cistern systems, is prevented from entering the stormwater treatment system, and is redirected for reuse onsite. 
(4)  Irrigation system means a system consisting of pipes, valves and sprayers connected to the potable water supply to manually or automatically irrigate lawns or landscaping. 
(5)  Lawn means the area of the property planted with grass. 
(6)  Lawn sprinkler means a device attached to a hose designed to allow for the unattended watering of lawns or landscaping, but does not include a drip irrigation system. 
(7)  Lawn watering means any means or methods of applying water to a lawn. 
(8)  Reclaimed greywater means water that is produced by treating onsite wastewater generated by household activities, such as laundry, dishwashing, and bathing, is prevented from entering the municipal wastewater treatment system, and is redirected for reuse onsite. 
(9)  Recycled effluent means water that was formerly municipal wastewater and has been treated to remove solids and impurities for reuse for non-potable purposes. 
(b)  Application of ordinance: 
(1)  The provisions of this section shall apply to: 
a.  Any person using water that is provided by the city's public/municipal water supply system, regardless of where or how the water is received. 
b.  Any property located within the municipal boundaries of the city where an alternative water supply exists where that alternative supply originates from the same aquifer or raw water source as the city's public/municipal supply. 
(2)  The provisions of subsection (c) of this section shall apply year-round, subject to any modifications thereof, including application of these or other regulations during this or any other time, by an emergency proclamation. 
(c)  Permitted hours and days for specified uses. Except as provided in subsection (d), water from the city's water distribution system may only be used for the watering or sprinkling of gardens, lawns, shrubs or other outdoor plants, or for filling swimming pools as follows: 
(1)  All properties with street addresses ending in 0, 2, 4, 6, or 8 may use city distributed water for plant watering or pool filling on even-numbered calendar dates between the hours of 6:00 a.m. to 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. to 9:00 p.m. prevailing time. 
(2)  All properties with street addresses ending in 1, 3, 5, 7, or 9 may use city distributed water for plant watering or pool filling on odd-numbered calendar dates between the hours of 6:00 a.m. to 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. to 9:00 p.m. prevailing time. 
(3)  All properties which cannot be readily identified as having even- or odd-numbered street addresses are hereby designated as even-numbered for water conservation purposes. 
(4)  No property will be allowed to use water for lawn watering on July 31 and August 31 of the calendar year. 
(d)  Special regulations. Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (c), the following special regulations shall apply: 
(1)  Trees, shrubs, flowers and gardens may be watered at any time so long as such watering is done with a properly attended hand-held hose not larger than one-inch diameter with a positive shut-off nozzle or with an automatic root feed or drip-type irrigation device. 
(2)  Swimming pools with a volume of fifty (50) gallons or less may be filled at any time. 
(3)  Vehicles may be washed at any time, so long as such washing is done with a hand-held hose equipped with a positive shut-off nozzle. 
(4)  Plant watering where such watering is done using reclaimed greywater, recycled effluent, or harvested rainwater may be performed at any time. 
(5)  Waste of water prohibited: No person shall allow a continuous stream of water to run off into any gutter, ditch, drain, or street inlet while using water for permitted purposes, nor shall a person spray or sprinkle streets or sidewalks. 
(6)  Exceptions: The provisions of this section shall not apply to any commercial or industrial entity for which the use of water is necessary to continue normal business operations, or to maintain stock or inventory. This exception shall not apply to any uses of water not essential to normal business operations or maintenance of inventory or stock, and specifically shall not apply to lawn watering. 
(7)  Sod laying and seeded lawn installation water usage: 
a.  Notwithstanding the above provisions, sod laying, lawn seeding, and the planting of other landscaping for the establishment of a new lawn or new landscaping is prohibited from July 1 through August 31 each year, unless the source of watering for said sod, lawn seeding or planting of landscaping is derived from reclaimed greywater, recycled effluent, or harvested rainwater. The prohibition shall not apply to soil erosion and sedimentation plans required pursuant to city ordinances (with approved plans) or for restorations due to required repairs of public utilities (e.g., water main breaks). 
b.  Except for the period of July 1 through August 31 of each year or during an emergency proclamation event, water from the public/municipal supply system or private wells may be used for the establishment of sod or seeded turf lawns planted or installed in the current year following the below permissions: 
i.  Upon the issuance of an extended watering permit from the city's building and permits division, or the public works division. 
ii.  The first day sod is placed or seed planted, the property owner may water the sod or seed for any eight (8) hours. 
iii.  The second through tenth days after sod is placed or seed planted, the property owner may water the sod every day between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. and 9:00 p.m. prevailing time. 
iv.  On the eleventh and subsequent day(s) after sod is placed or seed planted, the provisions of subsection (c) shall be in effect. The director of public works shall have the discretion to modify the extended watering permit for lawns and landscaping associated with commercial developments based on the size of the development and the condition of the city's water supply. 
(8)  Commercial enterprises wishing to use city distributed water for landscaping purposes other than as provided above may apply for a special permit from the city's building and permits division, or the public works division. 
(e)  Emergency proclamation: Whenever in the judgment of the mayor the public exigency as to the water supply bears out the need for emergency action, then the mayor by appropriate public proclamation shall so limit such use as the mayor deems proper. The proclamation shall set forth the limitations for use of city distributed water. Upon issuing said proclamation, the mayor shall immediately notify all members of the city council of the nature of the emergency and the regulations that have been imposed. The emergency proclamation of the mayor and the regulations imposed thereby shall remain in full force and effect until either the mayor determines the emergency no longer exists, or the city council modifies, repeals or makes permanent the emergency proclamation and the regulations imposed thereby by means of a properly passed ordinance. 
(1)  In the case of regional dry periods or drought, the mayor may take into account the recommendations of the regional water supply planning group, the Northwest Water Planning Alliance (NWPA), on making the decision to issue an emergency proclamation. 
(2)  Such regulation may provide for limitations on the usage of water, limitations on days and hours of use of water for some or all purposes, and the prohibition of specified uses of water. The following shall constitute the default emergency regulations: 
a.  In the case of moderate to severe drought conditions or similar regional water supply constraints, as advised by the NWPA or others, the use of sprinkler systems shall be prohibited. Outdoor use of water shall still be allowed for those exempted uses in subsection (d) and do not have to follow hour or day permissions. 
b.  In the case of extreme to exceptional drought conditions or similar regional water supply constraints as advised by the NWPA or others, the use of water outdoors for any purpose shall be prohibited. 
(3)  Any city employee or officer may, at the direction of the mayor, notify and warn any person of the effect of said emergency proclamation and direct said person to comply with said emergency water use restrictions. If any said person, after first being warned about said restrictions of the emergency proclamation, shall continue to violate said emergency proclamation restrictions, they shall be deemed to be in violation of this section. 
(f)  Penalties: Violation of this section shall result in a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first offense. Each subsequent offense shall result in a fine that increases by increments of fifty dollars ($50.00) up to a maximum fine amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per violation. Payment of fines shall be completed within thirty (30) days of the date of the violation notice. Each day a violation occurs or continues shall be considered a separate violation for the purposes of this section. 
(Code 1969, § 47-46; Ord. No. O02-94, § 11, 9-10-02; Ord. No. O06-52, § 1, 6-13-06; Ord. No. O13-026, § 1, 5-28-13) 
Sec. 48-32. - Installation of water-efficient fixtures. 
    The installation of plumbing fixtures and trim in new construction and/or replacement of plumbing fixtures and trim in existing construction shall comply with the city's building code. 
(Code 1969, § 47-47; Ord. No. O02-94, § 12, 9-10-02) 
Sec. 48-33. - Water and sewer fund. 
    All revenues derived from the operation of the city's water supply and sewage collection system shall be deposited in the city's water and sewer fund, which the city treasurer shall administer in accordance with all applicable city ordinances and state statutes. All such revenues shall be held by the city treasurer separate and apart from all other city funds not more than ten (10) days after receipt of the same, or at such more frequent intervals as may from time to time be directed by the city council. 
(Ord. No. O00-46, § 1, 5-9-00) 
Sec. 48-34. - Accounts. 
    The city treasurer shall establish a proper system of accounts and shall keep proper books, records and accounts in which complete and correct entries shall be made of all transactions relative to the water and sewer system, and at regular annual intervals he shall cause to be made an audit by an independent auditing concern of the books to show the receipts and disbursements of the water system. In addition to the customary operating statements, the annual audit report shall also reflect the revenues and operating expenses of the water facilities, including replacement cost. The financial information to be shown in the audit report shall include the following: 
1)  Flow data showing total gallons at the water plant for the current fiscal year. 
2)  Billing data to show total number of gallons billed per fiscal year. 
3)  Debt service for the next succeeding fiscal year. 
4)  Number of users connected to the system. 
5)  Number of non-metered users. 
(Ord. No. O00-46, § 1, 5-9-00) 
Sec. 48-35. - Access to records. 
    The Illinois Environmental Protection Agency or its authorized representative shall have access to any books, documents, papers and records of the city which are applicable to the city system of user charges for the purpose of making audit, examination, excerpts and transcripts thereof to insure compliance with the terms of the special and general conditions to any state grant and the loan agreement and rules of any state loan. 
(Ord. No. O00-46, § 1, 5-9-00) 
Secs. 48-36-48-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - METERS 

Sec. 48-41. - Size. 
(a)  The size of meter required for any metered water supply shall be governed by the size and character of the premises served or to be served. All residences shall be 3/4 inch, unless otherwise approved by the director of public work or his designee. 
(b)  Size of meters shall be designated by the public works department at the time of application for water supply. The size of meters so specified by the department shall be subject to change from time to time thereafter as demand or other conditions may require. 
(c)  The right is reserved to require an increase in the size of meter, as in these rules provided, in any case where in the discretion of the city the use of water exceeds the capacity of the meter. 
(Code 1969, § 47-36; Ord. No. O02-94, § 13, 9-10-02) 
Sec. 48-42. - Remote readers and meter holding devices. 
(a)  All new construction, remodeling or alterations requiring new water service shall install then current reading technology. The city reserves the right to require such installation to include a conduit for meter wire to be installed between the water meter and the remote reading receptacle. A radio-frequency device shall be installed inside the structure in a specific location determined by the meter maintenance division for the radio signal to be best received from the device by the division of meter reading and billing. 
(b)  A meter holding device and ball valve approved by the director of public works shall be used for water meters one (1) inch or less in size. Such meter holding device shall be located so as to be readily accessible for meter installation and removal. However, such meter holding device, ball valve and meter may be located in a crawl space or other possible inaccessible area; provided, however, that prior to the installation thereof written approval of the location is obtained from the director of public works. The city may withhold service if the meter is not accessible and approval for its location has not been obtained in accordance with this section. 
(Code 1969, § 47-37; Ord. No. O02-94, § 14, 9-10-02; Ord. No. O05-125, § 3, 11-8-05) 
Sec. 48-43. - Primary and secondary meters. 
(a)  Where water is supplied through two (2) or more meters to one (1) consumer, or to two (2) or more premises owned by one (1) person, in no instance will the readings of such meters be combined, but a bill rendered as per meter reading of each meter. The division of water meter reading and collection will not recognize a secondary or subtraction meter nor will it render any bill or bills on same. The water will always be charged against the property as registered by a primary meter. 
(b)  If secondary or subtraction meters are desired for recording the subdivision of any water supply, such meters may be installed at the consumer's expense and the owner must assume all responsibility of reading and maintaining the same. 
(Code 1969, § 47-38) 
Sec. 48-44. - Required; tampering with prohibited. 
    Any and all water, except fire sprinkler systems, furnished to consumers must be passed through and measured by a meter, such meter to be of a type approved by the city and obtained by the property owner from the division of water meter maintenance and installed entirely at the expense of the property owner. All meters thus furnished shall be charged to the consumer at their initial cost plus the charges incurred in handling them. All meters shall be closed by a seal and when tampering has occurred, such as breaking the seal, causing the same to be broken or removing the meter without the prior approval of the city and consuming unmetered water, the owner and/or consumer shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. If the citation issued pursuant to the misdemeanor above remains unpaid for more than fifteen (15) days, then the fine may be placed upon the water bill of the consumer or owner of the premises wherein the misdemeanor occurred. At all times the meter shall remain the property of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 47-41; Ord. No. O88-52, § 11, 5-3-88; Ord. No. O02-94, § 15, 9-10-02; Ord. No. O05-125, § 4, 11-8-05) 
Cross reference- Fine schedule for violations, § 1-11. 
Sec. 48-45. - Accuracy; maintenance. 
(a)  Water meters will be considered as inaccurate and in need of repair when the variation or departure from one hundred (100) percent accuracy shall be in excess of two (2) percent. 
(b)  Whenever any meter shall be proven to be inaccurate or in need of repair, the city shall cause the meter to be removed, tested, recalibrated and replaced, the cost and expense of such removal, repair and replacement to be charged against the owner of the property on whose premises the water meter belongs, and the above charges shall be collected in the same manner as are water charges. 
(c)  The above charges for removal, repair and replacement will be charged regardless of whether the city or property owner ordered the removal, repair and replacement of meter. 
(Code 1969, § 47-42) 
Secs. 48-46-48-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RATES, CHARGES AND COLLECTION PROCEDURES 

Sec. 48-56. - Classification of consumers. 
(a)  The city council shall at all times have the power and authority to set and determine what shall be the character of water service such as domestic water pressure, continuity of service, fire pressure, etc. 
(b)  All consumers to whom water service and sewer service are furnished by the city are hereby classified for convenience in setting rates and collecting charges into the following classes: 
(1)  Class 1: All consumers not included in Class 2, 3, or 4 shall be placed in Class 1. 
(2)  Class 2: Consumers who qualify for the "senior citizen homestead exemption" according to section 15-170 of the Property Tax Code (35 ILCS 200/15-170), as amended, whether or not they reside within the corporate limits of the city. This classification takes effect on January 1 of the calendar year following the granting of the exemption and upon proper notification to and approval by the city. 
(3)  Class 3: All consumers (other than Class 2 or 4) located outside the corporate limits of the city. 
(4)  Class 4: All consumers (other than Class 2) receiving water service only, and not sewer service (i.e., septic system used). 
(Code 1969, § 47-18; Ord. No. O87-5671, § 1, 6-2-87; Ord. No. O88-52, § 2, 5-3-88; Ord. No. O00-66, § 1, 6-27-00) 
Sec. 48-57. - Charges for services. 
(a)  All rates and charges for services contained in this section shall be based upon a two (2) month billing period or any portion thereof. 
(b)  All charges shall be due and payable on or before the twenty-first day after the date when statements of such charges are rendered, and shall become delinquent if remaining unpaid thereafter. There shall be a ten (10) percent additional charge for delinquent accounts to cover the cost of maintenance, processing, and loss of availability of funds to cover the cost of operations of the system. 
(c)  All consumers shall be charged a basic fee for availability of water to a premise notwithstanding any usage of water. The basic fee rate charged shall be determined according to the size of the meter or water service pipe diameter installed. Effective for billings made subsequent to the dates indicated below, the basic availability charges shall be as follows: 
Current 7/1/16 Effective 7/1/17 Effective 7/1/18 Availability Charge $13.65 $16.35 $19.05  
    These charges shall not be applicable for premises which the city has determined to not be available for occupancy and metering devices that have been removed from the premises at the request of the consumer or a determination by the city. 
(d)  For apartment buildings or other multifamily dwellings served by one (1) water meter, a basic fee for availability of water shall be charged for each apartment unit or family unit served by the water meter whether occupied or not. The amount of the charge per unit shall be the amount as set forth in subsection (c) above for one (1) inch or less. 
(e)  In addition to the basic fee set forth hereinabove, the rates to be charged for water services and sewer services for various purposes shall be as follows, effective for billings made subsequent to the dates indicated below:

(g)  In addition to the fees set forth hereinabove, the city council has enacted a drainage project user fee set forth in article IV of chapter 18 of this Code. 
(h)  In addition to the fees set forth hereinabove, the city council has enacted an environmental refuse disposal fee in article I, section 20-2 of chapter 20 of this Code. 
(i)  In addition to the fees set forth hereinabove, the city council has enacted an EPA-mandated long-term control plan fee in article VI, section 18-300 of chapter 18 of this Code. 
(Code 1969, § 47-19; Ord. No. O87-5671, § 2, 6-2-87; Ord. No. O88-52, § 3, 5-3-88; Ord. No. O89-45, § 1, 5-16-89; Ord. No. O90-56, § 1, 6-5-90; Ord. No. O91-54, § 1, 7-16-91; Ord.
