No. O01-59, § 1, 6-12-01; Ord. No. O03-65, § 1, 5-27-03; Ord. No. O05-120, § 1, 10-25-05; Ord. No. O07-69, § 1, 6-12-07; Ord. No. O07-148, § 1, 12-18-07; Ord. No. O09-60, § 1, 7-14-09; Ord. No. O11-030, § 1, 6-28-11; Ord. No. O11-031, § 2, 6-28-11; Ord. No. O13-047, § 1, 8-27-13; Ord. No. O15-032, § 1, 6-23-15; Ord. No. O17-019, § 1, 4-25-17) 
Secs. 48-58, 48-59. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O88-52, §§ 4, 5, adopted May 3, 1988, repealed §§ 47-19.1 and 47-19.2 of the 1969 Code, which sections had been included as §§ 48-58 and 48-59 herein, and which pertained to minimum charge for new residential housing units and rates for apartment buildings and multifamily dwellings. Said §§ 48-58 and 48-59 have been reserved by the editor for future use. 
Sec. 48-60. - Private fire protection systems. 
    Private sprinkler and fire protection water systems may be connected with city water mains, subject to the following provisions and regulations, and provided the applicant is a consumer taking water supply for other uses from the city, at regular rates for such uses. 
(1)  Whenever sprinkler or fire protection services are desired, application shall be made to the public works department of the city for the privilege of installing such service, which application shall include complete specifications and plans of the installation contemplated. If the application is approved by the department the applicant shall enter into an agreement with the city for connection to city mains subject to the provisions of this article. 
(2)  City water will be turned into any sprinkler or fire protection system only when such installation has been subjected to and passed such inspection and pressure tests as may be required by the public works department. All pipes in connection with such system shall be left exposed until such tests have been made and the system approved. No cross-connections between private water supplies and services connected to city mains shall be permitted. 
(3)  Any premises, defined as a distinct and definite locality, including but not limited to shops, stores, buildings, or other areas, held under separate ownership or lease, and which has installed a sprinkler or fire protection system which is connected, directly or indirectly, with the water mains of the city shall not be metered or charged for such water as may be necessary to use in making the usual and ordinary tests of such systems under the underwriters' rules, or for actual fires. Should it be found that water is used from same for purposes other than for the usual tests or for fire fighting, the city is empowered to require the installation of a meter for charges to be made. 
(4)  Any and all premises connected to city water mains for sprinkler or fire protection services shall be subject to inspection by a representative of the public works department at any time for count and conformity to the city regulations. 
(Code 1969, § 47-20; Ord. No. O88-52, § 6, 5-3-88) 
Sec. 48-61. - Deposit-Required. 
    Before water is supplied to any consumer, other than property occupied by owner/consumer, whether the consumer is applying for water service for the first time or whether through change of address or otherwise, is applying for water service at a new or other premises, such consumer, as a condition precedent to the supplying of such water, shall deposit with the city treasurer the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) as a guarantee of the payment of water and sewer rates or rents. 
(Code 1969, § 47-21; Ord. No. O97-46, § 2, 5-27-97; Ord. No. O02-94, § 16, 9-10-02) 
Sec. 48-62. - Same-Disposition; return to consumer. 
(a)  The water deposit shall be retained to the credit of the consumer and deposited in a separate account. When such consumer discontinues the use of water service this deposit shall be returned to such consumer if, as and when all charges for water supplied to the premises or for water services have been paid and claim for a refund of said deposit has been made by the consumer. 
(b)  Should a consumer vacate premises and within sixty (60) days fail to notify city and claim a refund or transfer of said deposit, the city shall attempt to notify consumer at the latest known address through the U.S. mail service of any portion of deposit available for refund. 
(c)  Should the consumer fail to notify the city of a claim for refund within sixty (60) days after the city sends notice through the U.S. mail service, the balance of the deposit shall be transferred to the operations and maintenance account of the water and sewer fund. The city shall maintain a record of this transfer for a period of two (2) years from the date the city becomes aware of the consumer vacating the premises. 
(d)  If the consumer files a claim for refund of the deposit within a period of two (2) years from vacating the premises, the city will make such refund from the operations and maintenance account of the water and sewer fund. If no claim is filed, the account will be considered closed with the deposit having been charged for the cost of handling and maintaining the records. 
(Code 1969, § 47-22; Ord. No. O88-5, § 7, 5-3-88) 
Sec. 48-63. - Same-Using to pay delinquent accounts. 
    If any consumer shall allow a bill for water rates, rents or services to become delinquent and remain delinquent for thirty (30) days, then the deposit so made or so much of it as is necessary shall be applied to pay such delinquency. 
(Code 1969, § 47-23) 
Sec. 48-64. - Discontinuing service. 
(a)  Water and sewer service may be shut off and discontinued to any property in which an owner/consumer has allowed billing charges to become delinquent as defined in section 48-66. 
(b)  It shall be the responsibility of any party requesting the restoration of water and sewer service to pay all fees, deposits, and delinquent charges, attributable to the property for which water and sewer service is provided. 
(c)  When the ownership of property is transferred to a new owner, it shall be the responsibility of the new owner to pay all fees, deposits, and delinquent charges prior to water and sewer service being turned on or otherwise restored to property. 
(d)  Water and sewer service shall not be turned on or otherwise restored to a property until all fees, deposits, and delinquent charges have been paid in full. 
(e)  Water and sewer services may be shut off and discontinued to any property in which an owner/consumer has become delinquent in payment for penalties, fines, taxes and any other indebtedness due the City of Aurora or any other State of Illinois unit of local government. Water and sewer services shall not be turned on or otherwise restored to a property until delinquent payments have been paid in full. 
(f)  If it becomes necessary for the city to cause the buffalo box to be repaired in order to terminate water and sewer services because of delinquency in payment, the charges of the repairs shall be charged to the owner/consumer and collected in the same manner as the water bill. 
(Code 1969, § 47-24; Ord. No. O88-52, § 8, 5-3-88; Ord. No. O95-27, § 2, 5-16-95; Ord. No. O02-94, § 17, 9-10-02) 
Sec. 48-65. - Charges for restoring services. 
    If water service is discontinued because of a delinquent account as set forth in this article or for any other reason, there shall be a forty dollar ($40.00) fee payable in advance either by the consumer or the owner of the property before water service to the premises is turned back on during regular scheduled working hours. If water service to the premises is turned back on during a time period requiring overtime charges, the fee shall be eighty dollars ($80.00). 
(Code 1969, § 47-25; Ord. No. O88-52, § 9, 5-3-88; Ord. No. O95-27, § 3, 5-16-95) 
Sec. 48-66. - When bills delinquent; notice. 
    Any consumer against whom a water bill is charged that remains unpaid thirty (30) days after billing shall be construed and defined as delinquent in the payment of the water bill. The division of water meter reading and billing shall mail or cause to be mailed to the premises against which the water bill is charged a statement setting forth the nature and the amount of the bill then remaining unpaid as soon as practicable after the date of such delinquency, but failure to mail such notice shall in no way affect the obligation of the consumer to pay the bill. If any such bill remains unpaid after the expiration of a period of thirty (30) days from the date of the delinquency, the public works department shall cause the water service to such premises to be at once discontinued by turning off the water from the water mains into the premises, and such water service shall not be turned on again except as provided in sections 48-64 and 48-65. 
(Code 1969, § 47-26) 
Sec. 48-67. - Remedies for collection of delinquent accounts. 
    In addition to the turning off of the water service as provided in this division, and in addition to the creation and enforcement of a lien upon the premises, as provided for in sections 48-68, 48-69 and 48-70, the division of water meter reading and billing may adopt any or all methods for the collection of unpaid accounts that are legally available, including, but not limited to, the prosecution of a lawsuit for the amount unpaid and costs, and the enforcement of the resulting judgment by execution, garnishment or otherwise. 
(Code 1969, § 47-27) 
Sec. 48-68. - Creation of lien. 
    The city shall have a continuing lien upon the premises and real estate upon or for which water is used or supplied for all water rents, charges or benefits accruing by benefit of the reasons of this article. Every such lien shall, upon compliance with the conditions set forth in this division become and be prior and superior to the rights and interests of creditors, encumbrances, purchasers and other parties in interest in the premises and real estate. 
(Code 1969, § 47-28) 
Sec. 48-69. - Filing of lien; defects not fatal. 
    Whenever a bill for water rates, charges, services or benefits remains unpaid for a period of thirty (30) days after the due date thereof, the corporation counsel shall file with the recorder of deeds of the county, a statement of lien claims verified by the affidavit of himself or by the affidavit of some other person having knowledge of the facts. The statement as contained in the affidavit shall contain a sufficiently correct description of the lot, lots or tracts of land to identify the same, the balance due after allowing all credits, and a statement that the city claims a lien for this amount, as well as for all charges for water supplied subsequent to the period covered by the statement. No such lien shall be defeated to the proper amount thereof because of an error or overcharge on the part of the city, nor shall any such lien be defeated upon proof that such water was used or contracted for by a tenant of the premises or occupant thereof other than the owner. 
(Code 1969, § 47-29; Ord. No. O88-71, Exh. A, 6-21-88) 
Sec. 48-70. - Foreclosure of lien. 
(a)  If payment shall not be made, as provided in this division, of any amount due for water rents, charges, services or benefits when the same becomes due, the city may file or cause to be filed a complaint in the circuit court for a foreclosure of such lien or, upon becoming a defendant in any pending suit affecting any premises or real estate, by answer to the complaint in the nature of an intervening petition or cross complaint, the city may proceed in its corporate name to foreclose such lien in like manner and with like effect as provided by the statutes of the state in foreclosure of mechanics liens or other statutory liens. Such suits shall be commenced or answered by cross-complaint filed within two (2) years after the accrual of such water rates, charges or benefits. Any decree rendered in the court may be enforced and collected as other decrees or judgments of such court. 
(b)  The corporation counsel shall institute such proceedings in the name of the city in the circuit court against any premises or real estate for which the water bill remains unpaid. 
(c)  The remedy provided in this section for the collection of delinquent water rates, charges, services or benefits shall not be construed to abridge or in any manner interfere with the right and power of the city to enforce a collection thereof by any other action or otherwise, but the remedy shall be taken and held as an additional means to enforce payment of such water rents, rates, charges, services or benefits. 
(Code 1969, § 47-30) 
Sec. 48-71. - Settling disputed bills. 
    If a water consumer disputes the amount of the water bill charged him, or a consumer questions the accuracy of the meter for which data for computing the bill was obtained, then the city will, at the written request of the consumer, cause tests and examinations of the meter to be made to determine its accuracy. If it is found as a result of such test that the meter registers a greater or less amount of water than is actually passed through it in excess of the allowable variation of two (2) percent, the division of water meter reading and billing shall have authority to adjust the error either positively or negatively so that the water charge against the consumer shall be that computed for the amount of water that actually passed through such meter. In no case, however, where water service has been rendered for six (6) months or a portion thereof, shall the bill be adjusted below the minimum charges as set by this article, and provided also, that no such adjustment shall be made if request for adjustment has not been made prior to the time such bill becomes delinquent. No charges shall be made for water leaking from the service pipe that has not passed through the meter nor shall any deduction or allowance be made with respect to the bill on account of leakage after water has passed through the meter. 
(Code 1969, § 47-31) 
Sec. 48-72. - Unauthorized turn-on after service discontinued. 
    Any owner or consumer who shall turn on, cause to be turned on, tamper with the buffalo box, or consume the supply of water to any premises from which the supply of water has been turned off by order of the city treasurer on account of nonpayment of water services, rents, charges or benefits, without receiving permission or authority so to do, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Each and every day for which the water is turned on after the water is turned off shall be construed as a separate and distinct offense. 
(Code 1969, § 47-32; Ord. No. O02-94, § 18, 9-10-02; Ord. No. O05-125, § 5, 11-8-05) 
Sec. 48-73. - Final bill. 
    Any person or party vacating any premises receiving city water shall request a final reading of the water meter by the city before vacating said premises. All requests to the city for a final reading of the water meter shall be made no less than five (5) days prior to the date of the anticipated property transfer or vacation. Upon receiving such a request the city shall take a final reading of the water meter and prepare a bill to be submitted to the consumer for payment. In accordance with section 44-224 of this Code, the city treasurer shall not issue any real estate transfer tax stamps for the subject property until said bill is paid. In the event a final reading of the water meter is not possible prior to the transfer of property for which real estate transfer tax stamps are required, the consumer shall pay a reasonable amount as determined by the city. In the event the final reading shows the consumer still owes the city money, said consumer shall promptly pay the city any outstanding sums. In the event the final reading shows the consumer has paid in excess of the amount due, the city shall promptly refund said excess to the consumer. 
(Ord. No. O00-145, § 1, 11-14-00) 
Secs. 48-74-48-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SEWERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 48-86. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Industrial waste or wastes means and includes any and all wastes, whether liquid or solid, in solution or in suspension, arising or produced by factories, industries, plants, garages and other business or manufacturing institutions which are injurious or detrimental to the sewers, sewerage system or treatment works of the Fox Metro Water Reclamation District or the city or any of the appurtenances thereof or injurious or detrimental to the bacterial or chemical action of any of the sewage treatment works; and such industrial wastes shall also include and are and shall be further construed and defined to be: 
(1)  Waste containing or carrying settleable solids of any character, and any and all floating material of whatever character. 
(2)  Waste containing or carrying either soluble or insoluble solids of organic nature, or containing or carrying either suspended or soluble matter which: 
a.  Is putrescible or capable of putrefaction; or 
b.  Adversely affects bacterial action. 
(3)  Waste containing or carrying chemicals, acids, alkalies, corrosive, metallic or other compounds, whether soluble or insoluble, organic or inorganic, which: 
a.  Are putrescible or capable of putrefaction; 
b.  Adversely affect bacterial action; or 
c.  Injure or tend to injure by deposition or by corrosion the outlets, sewers, sewerage system or works, or any other structures or instrumentalities of the Fox Metro Water Reclamation District or the city. 
(4)  Waste carrying, containing or composed wholly or in part of volatile or inflammable materials, fats, oils, grease, tar, kerosene, gasoline or other similar materials or other floating material. 
(5)  Waste containing or carrying any chemicals, acids, alkalies, corrosive, metallic or other compounds, sediment or suspended matter, or mineral matter in solution, or any other material, substance, liquid or thing which is detrimental to or interferes or tends to interfere with the operation of the outlets, sewers, sewerage system or works, or any structures, instrumentalities or processes of the sewerage system by causing or resulting in deposits therein by settlement, precipitation or otherwise or in any other manner injuring, damaging or interfering with any of the instrumentalities, works or processes of such sewage system. 
    Infiltration means the water entering a sewer system and service connections from the ground through such means as, but not limited to, defective pipes, pipe joints, connections or manhole walls. Infiltration does not include, and is distinguished from, inflow. 
    Infiltration/inflow means the total quantity of water from both infiltration and inflow without distinguishing the source. 
    Inflow means the water discharged into a sewer system and service connections from such sources as, but not limited to, roof leaders, cellar, yard and area drains, foundation drains, cooling water discharges, drains from springs and swampy areas, manhole lids, cross-connections from storm sewers and combined sewers, catch basins, stormwater, surface runoff, street wash waters or drainage. Inflow does not include, and is distinguished from, infiltration. 
    Sanitary sewage means and includes domestic sewage, and sewage discharged from the sanitary conveniences of dwellings and other buildings and places in which sanitary conveniences are used or installed. 
    Sanitary sewer means a sewer that is designed to carry liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions. 
    Sewage means and includes any and all such wastes as are liquid and solid matter, flowing in or from residences, human habitations, institutions, stables, garages, business and trade buildings and industries, whether such wastes are in their original form or in combination with groundwater, stormwater, surface or other water. 
    Sewer means any sewer constructed, maintained and/or operated by the Aurora Sanitary District or the city, including any and all manholes, intercepting chambers or other appurtenances connected therewith. 
    Solid wastes means and includes trash, garbage, ashes, rags, manure of domestic animals, foodstuffs and the waste thereof other than normally contained in domestic sewage, offal, dead animals or portions thereof, and any and all other solid objects, materials, refuse and debris. The term "ashes" shall include the residuum resulting from the combustion of coal, coke, wood or any other material or substance and shall include soot, cinders, slag and charcoal. 
    Storm sewer or storm drain shall mean a sewer for conveying water, groundwater or unpolluted water from any source. 
    Stormwater shall mean runoff water resulting directly from rainfall or other natural precipitation. 
    Works or sewerage system includes the disposal or treatment plant and pumping stations together with any and all appurtenances thereof and also any and all sewers, manholes and other devices used to carry or bring sewage to any treatment plant, belonging to either the city or the Fox Metro Water Reclamation District. 
(Code 1969, § 47-58; Ord. No. O02-94, § 20, 9-10-02) 
Sec. 48-87. - Violation declared public nuisance. 
    The violation of any of the terms and provisions of this article is declared to be a public nuisance. 
(Code 1969, § 47-59) 
Sec. 48-88. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating or failing to comply with any of the terms or provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction shall be punished as provided in section 1-10. 
(Code 1969, § 47-60) 
Sec. 48-89. - General supervision. 
    All sewers and drains in the streets, alleys or public places of the city shall be under the charge and control of the public works director and they shall be kept in good order and condition and clean and free from obstructions. The director shall cause to be made such repairs thereof and of the catch basins, culverts, manholes and openings connected therewith as may from time to time become necessary. 
(Code 1969, § 47-62) 
Sec. 48-90. - Obstructing, damaging sewers, sewer facilities. 
    No substance, article or thing of any kind which shall obstruct, block up or clog or cause to obstruct, block up or clog any sewer, shall be placed, thrown or deposited in any receiving basin, drain or sewer. Any person so offending or causing any such obstruction or clogging or substance to be placed so as to be carried into such basin or sewer shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Any person injuring, breaking or removing any portion of any receiving basin, covering flag, manhole, vent or any part of any sewer or drain shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1969, § 47-63) 
Sec. 48-91. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. O95-28, adopted May 16, 1995, repealed § 48-91, which pertained to permit required for work affecting sewers and derived from Code 1969, § 47-64. 
Sec. 48-92. - Approval of permit for connection to unassessed property. 
    Any person desiring to make any connection with the city's existing sewerage system for the discharge of sewage, stormwater, surface or subterranean drainage of any lot, block or parcel of land not heretofore assessed for such sewage, stormwater or subterranean drainage connection purpose shall make application for such privilege to the city council. No such applicant shall make any such connection with the existing city's sewerage system unless permitted to do so by the city council authorizing the public works director to issue a permit therefor. 
(Code 1969, § 47-65) 
Sec. 48-93. - Connection permit application, bond, fee. 
    No sewer connection permit shall be issued until the applicant for such permit has: 
(1)  Filed with the public works director or his designee a written application in the form provided for by this article, stating definitely what work is to be done, together with a full and complete description thereof, and where the public works director or his designee shall so require, a copy of the plans and specifications therefor. 
(2)  Filed with the public works director or his designee a bond in the form provided by this article or such other form as the council shall require, in the sum of at least five hundred dollars ($500.00) signed by the applicant and a good and responsible bonding company or by two (2) or more persons residing within the city and owning real estate situated therein, which bond if good and sufficient shall be approved by the director or his designee; provided, however, the council may require a special bond in accordance with the provisions of section 48-99. Such bond shall be conditioned for the performance of any and all covenants and agreements of the applicant in the application contained and for the performance of the work in conformity with all ordinances and regulations of the city and in accordance with the description of the work in the application contained and the plans and specifications, if any are required by the director or his designee, thereunto attached and in such manner as to restore all sewers, appurtenances, streets, alleys, sidewalks and pavements disturbed, injured and/or damaged to as good condition as they existed at the time of the commencement of the work and to indemnify and save harmless the city from any and all loss, cost, damage and expense which may come to the city by reason of or in any manner growing out of or connected with said work, including any and all liability for and on account of any accident or accidents, injury or death, damage or damages caused or in any manner arising from, growing out of or connected with the work; provided, however, that the liability, if any, of the applicant to the city shall not be limited to the amount of such bond nor to the specific liabilities mentioned and set forth therein, but the applicant shall in any event be liable to the city for any and all loss, cost, damage and expense of every kind and character arising from or connected with such work. 
(3)  Paid to the city the fees specified in section 48-3 to cover the cost of the issuance of such permit and inspection of the work. 
(Code 1969, § 47-66) 
Cross reference- Alternative to bonds, § 2-318. 
Sec. 48-94. - Connection fee when property not previously assessed. 
    A sewerage connection fee shall be charged to the owner of property abutting on any new sewer extension which has not previously been assessed for sewage, stormwater or subterranean drainage connection purposes. The amount of said fee shall be specified in section 48-3. Payment shall be made to the city treasurer before such connection is made and the payment shall satisfy the charge for connecting the sewer outlet to the city's existing sewerage system only and shall not include in whole or in part the expense of constructing sewer mains or individual house connections to the city's sewerage system, which latter expense shall be borne by the property owner of the territory so served. 
(Ord. No. O97-65, § 1, 8-26-97) 
Sec. 48-95. - Qualifications of person doing work. 
    No sewer connection shall be made or connecting sewer constructed except by a skilled and responsible sewer building or drain layer and whose name shall be stated in the application for the permit; provided, however, if the applicant is unable to state the name of such sewer builder or drain layer at the time of making application, the application may nevertheless be granted, but in such case before commencing the work, the applicant shall secure the approval in writing of the public works director or his designee of the party or person employed to do the work. 
(Code 1969, § 47-68) 
Sec. 48-96. - Form for application for connection. 
    The sewer connection application required by this article shall be in the form prescribed by the public works department. 
(Code 1969, § 47-69) 
Sec. 48-97. - Form of bond. 
    The bond required by this article shall be in the form approved by the public works department. 
(Code 1969, § 47-70) 
Sec. 48-98. - Form of sewer connection permit. 
    The permit required by this article shall be in the form approved by the public works department. 
(Code 1969, § 47-71) 
Sec. 48-99. - Special bond. 
    If the council of the city shall so require or determine, any applicant for a permit under the terms of this article may be required to give a special bond in such amount and upon such conditions as the council shall require to protect the city from loss and damage. 
(Code 1969, § 47-72) 
Sec. 48-100. - Notice required before beginning work under permit. 
    Any person to whom a permit is issued pursuant to the terms of this article shall notify the public works department at least twenty-four (24) hours prior to the commencement of any work authorized to be done by such permit. 
(Code 1969, § 47-73) 
Sec. 48-101. - Concealing work before inspection. 
    No materials used and no work done under or pursuant to any permit issued under the terms of this article shall be covered, nor any trench which has been excavated shall be filled, until the same has been inspected and approved by the public works department. 
(Code 1969, § 47-74) 
Sec. 48-102. - North trunk-East New York Street sanitary sewer connection charges. 
(a)  For all parcels of property located within the following described territory [description not set out herein] there shall be a connection charge to the owner or owners thereof paid prior to connection of each sewer outlet into the north trunk-East New York Street sanitary sewer system, computed as provided in subsection (b) hereof. 
(b)  [Computation of connection charge:] 
(1)  For each parcel within the territory described in subsection (a) hereof, there shall be a charge of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per acre or prorated for a fraction thereof, except that the flat charge for subdivided residential lots of ten thousand (10,000) square feet or less shall be two hundred twenty-five dollars ($225.00). 
(2)  Additionally, for each such parcel which is adjacent to the said north trunk-East New York Street sanitary sewer system line: 
a.  There shall be a charge of ten dollars ($10.00) per lineal foot or fraction thereof for all frontage of the parcel abutting the said line; 
b.  For parcels adjacent to the said line on more than one (1) lineal side, the frontages shall be averaged for purposes of the charge specified in subparagraph a. hereof; and 
c.  Where the said line traverses a parcel, the charge specified in subparagraph a. hereof shall be computed for lineal footage along both sides of the said line so traversed. 
(c)  Recapture of proportionate costs for construction of off-site extensions shall be allowed for all such parcels not adjacent to the said north trunk-East New York Street sanitary sewer system line, recoverable from owners of other nonadjacent parcels connecting to such off-site extensions. 
(Ord. No. O88-39, § 1, 4-19-88) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O88-39, § 1, adopted Apr. 19, 1988, added § 47-67.1 to the 1969 Code. Pursuant to instructions from the city, said new section has been designated as § 48-102 herein. It should be noted that the legal description referred to in subsection (a) of § 48-102 and attached to Ord. No. O88-39 is not set out herein, and may be found on file in the office of the city clerk. 
Sec. 48-103. - Special provisions for sewer construction within the combined sewer system. 
(a)  New residential, commercial or industrial building construction in areas served by combined sewers or areas whose stormwater drainage or sanitary sewage or both are tributary to areas served by combined sewers are subject to the following additional sewer construction specifications: 
(1)  Connections to combined sewers shall be designed in such a way as to minimize and/or delay inflow contribution to the combined sewer system. This may be accomplished by constructing storage facilities or alternative drainage systems. 
(2)  New building construction shall be designed in such a way that the building sanitary sewage and/or industrial waste collection is distinct from the building and site stormwater runoff conveyance system, in order to facilitate its disconnection of the stormwater conveyance system from the combined sewer should a storm sewer become available. The storm sewer system may be rejoined in the public right-of-way to the combined sewer if no sewer is available. 
(b)  In the event a storm sewer is constructed in close proximity to a parcel of property that currently discharges inflow into a combined sewer, the property owner shall reroute this inflow connection to the newly constructed storm sewer. Said connection shall be completed within twelve months after completion of the new storm sewer. 
(c)  A general description of the geographic areas of the city served by combined sewer systems shall be on file with the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. Ord. No. O02-32, § 1, 4-9-02) 
Sec. 48-104. - Special sewer P.E. use fee in the city's Fox River Corridor Area. 
(a)  The city council hereby finds as follows: 
(1)  The City of Aurora has a population of more than twenty-five thousand (25,000) persons and is, therefore, a home rule unit under Section 6(a) of Article VII of the Illinois Constitution of 1970. 
(2)  Subject to the limitations set forth in Section 6 of Article VII of the Illinois Constitution of 1970, a home rule unit may exercise any power and perform any function pertaining to its government and affairs for the protection of the public health, safety, morals and welfare. 
(3)  Pursuant to Resolution No. R06-133, approved on March 28, 2006, the city entered into an Intergovernmental Agreement ("agreement") with the Fox Metro Water Reclamation District for the construction of improvements to the combined storm and sanitary sewer system ("improved system") serving the Fox River Corridor Area ("corridor area") of the city which area had been served by the said combined storm and sanitary sewer system ("combined system"). 
(4)  Said combined system was at capacity, and overflows would occur during periods of heavy rain. 
(5)  As a result of the overflows of the combined system, new construction and redevelopment, which increase the flows into said combined system beyond the flows occurring prior to said new construction and redevelopment, could not take place without negatively impacting the environment and the health, safety and welfare of the residents of the city, and further overburdening said combined system. 
(6)  Said improved system contemplated by the agreement has been completed and has allowed and will continue to allow new construction and redevelopment to occur in the corridor area of the city in an environmentally safe manner. 
(7)  That re-developments of existing buildings and the construction of new buildings within the corridor area of the city, which is graphically depicted in Exhibit A-1 attached to Ordinance No. 010-09 and made part hereof [as if fully set out] (the "ordinance") and legally described in Exhibit A-2 attached to the ordinance and made part hereto [as if fully set out], including properties adjoining or contiguous to said area which are or will be connected to the improved system, which take place after the completion of the improved system and the enactment of the ordinance, will have a benefit from the improved system, and should, as part of the sewer connection/building permit process, pay their proportionate share of the costs of said improved system. 
(8)  Pursuant to the agreement, an additional twenty-two thousand five hundred (22,500) population equivalents (P.E.) were created within the improved system for the benefit of the corridor area. 
(9)  That based on the cost for the improved system, (inclusive of debt service costs in relation thereto), the cost per newly created P.E. within the improved system for the benefit of the corridor area is hereby established as eight hundred and forty dollars ($840.00), unless otherwise provided for in any redevelopment agreement entered into by the city prior to the effective date of the ordinance, in which case the cost per newly created P.E. for the property covered by any such redevelopment agreement shall be as set forth in said redevelopment agreement, with five hundred seventy-one dollars and twelve cents ($571.12) of said per P.E. amount to be reimbursed to Fox Metro Water Reclamation District to cover half of the total improved system project cost including debt service. 
(b)  For any redevelopment of an existing building or the construction of a new building within the corridor area, including properties adjoining or contiguous to said corridor area, or which are adjacent to a right of way that is part of the perimeter of the corridor area, and which are or will be connected to the improved system, which occurs after __________, 2010, and requires a building permit (the "post-system improvement development"), an additional fee of eight hundred forty dollars ($840.00) per P.E. is required (the "Fox River Corridor Area P.E. Use Fee"). The determination of the amount of said fee due and payable at the time of obtaining building permit shall be made by city staff using the pre-redevelopment/construction P.E. for the property in question and the post-redevelopment/construction P.E. for the property in question. In this regard, where a building existed on the property on March 28, 2006, but has since been demolished, the P.E. of said building, as opposed to the vacant land P.E., shall be used as the pre-redevelopment/construction P.E. for the property in question. The determination as required by this subsection shall be made in accordance with the following criteria: 
(1)  The pre-redevelopment/construction P.E. and post development/construction P.E. shall be determined by the P.E. properly documented and on file with the city from previous permit applications or by plans of the existing and proposed building(s), submitted to the city by the developer, that identify the total P.E. for the property in question pursuant to a plumbing plan of the existing and proposed plumbing fixtures and outlets and/or residential use or any combination thereof. 
Any such plans or documentation shall be prepared and signed/sealed by an Illinois licensed professional engineer or architect. 
(2)  For residential occupancy uses, the pre-redevelopment/construction P.E. and the post-redevelopment/construction P.E. shall be determined using the following P.E. amounts: 
Type P.E. per Unit Efficiency or Studio Unit 1 1 Bedroom Unit 1.5 2 Bedroom Unit 3 3 Bedroom Unit 3 Single-Family Detached Dwelling 3.5 Mobile Home 2.25  
(3)  For non-residential occupancy uses, the pre-redevelopment/construction P.E. and post-redevelopment/construction P.E. shall be determined by using the chart set forth in subsection (iii) below, based on the total number of plumbing outlet units (hereinafter "POUs"). POUs for non-specific uses shall be determined based on the type and total number of plumbing fixtures as set forth in subsection (i) below. POUs for specific uses shall be based on the specific use as set forth in subsection (ii) below. The total POUs shall be the sum of the non-specific use POUs and the specific use POUs applicable to the non-residential occupancy use, rounded to the nearest whole number, with partial POUs of five-tenths (0.5) or greater being rounded up to the next highest whole number. For buildings that are divided into individual non-residential units, the total POUs shall be determined for each non-residential unit address individually and not for the building as an aggregate of the individual units.
